(One common approach in climate science is “homogenization,” in which a given station’s record is compared to a neighboring “reference” series taken as the mean of regional stations. Discrepancies that occur only during part of the record may be evidence of instrument change, site relocation, or other inhomogeneities.)

Let’s describe one way to proceed step‐by‐step.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Setting Up a Comparison

For each year we have precipitation amounts for stations A–F. We assume that the regional “climate” is roughly represented by the mean of stations B–F. Then for each year, we compute the difference between station A and the mean of the five others:
  Difference = (Station A) – (Mean of stations B–F).

If the January–April (or October–April) totals for station A are consistent with the region, the differences should be small and roughly constant over time.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Compute a Sample of Differences

For example, consider a few years:

• Year 1999  
 Station A = 13.75 in.  
 Mean of (B,C,D,E,F) = (16.31 + 14.04 + 14.15 + 15.16 + 15.13)/5  
   = 74.79/5 ≈ 14.96 in.  
 Difference ≈ 13.75 – 14.96 = –1.21 in.

• Year 2002  
 Station A = 20.27 in.  
 Mean from others = (20.26 + 17.13 + 19.04 + 22.27 + 22.29)/5  
   = 100.99/5 ≈ 20.20 in.  
 Difference ≈ 20.27 – 20.20 = +0.07 in.

• Year 2009  
 Station A = 23.36 in.  
 Mean from others = (24.43 + 23.44 + 27.43 + 16.11 + 25.69)/5  
   ≈ 23.42 in.  
 Difference ≈ 23.36 – 23.42 = –0.06 in.

In the earlier part of the record (roughly 1999–2009) the differences tend to be less than about 1 or 2 inches in magnitude (and sometimes even near zero). That is, station A’s measured values are very similar to the regional average.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Notice the Anomaly in Recent Years

Now look at the later years (2010–2014). For example:

• Year 2010  
 Station A = 9.50 in.  
 Mean of (B–F) = (13.88 + 19.86 + 16.16 + 15.98 + 10.45)/5 ≈ 15.27 in.  
 Difference ≈ 9.50 – 15.27 = –5.77 in.

• Year 2011  
 Station A = 11.83 in.  
 Mean others ≈ (18.21+15.24+14.30+17.56+13.02)/5 ≈ 15.67 in.  
 Difference ≈ 11.83 – 15.67 = –3.84 in.

• Year 2012  
 Station A = 13.40 in.  
 Mean others ≈ (18.48+21.23+17.65+18.48+14.74)/5 ≈ 18.12 in.  
 Difference ≈ 13.40 – 18.12 = –4.72 in.

Over 2010–2014 the differences are consistently in the range of about –3 to –5.8 inches. In contrast, from 1999 to 2009 the differences were near zero (with only slight negative or positive departures). This change in bias clearly indicates that from 2010 onward station A is recording significantly less precipitation than its neighbors. In other words, there is an inhomogeneity in the station A record that likely must be “corrected” (for example, by an instrument calibration change or similar).

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Quantify the Adjustment

A first‐order approach is to compare the “bias” (difference between station A and the reference average) before and after the change.

• Average pre-2010 bias (from roughly 11 years, 1999–2009) is small, on the order of –0.9 in (an approximate check of all years shows differences between about –0.1 and –1.4 inches, with one or two exceptions).  
• For 2010–2014 (5 years) the average bias is roughly  
  (–5.77 – 3.84 – 4.72 – 4.44 – 3.17)/5 ≈ –4.39 in.

Thus, compared to the “normal” conditions in the earlier period, station A’s later readings are roughly 3.5 inches too low on average (since –4.39 – (–0.9) ≈ –3.5 in).

──────────────────────────────
Step 5. Adjusting the Data

To represent the currently observed conditions (and to “homogenize” station A’s record relative to the network), it is reasonable to adjust the post‐2009 station A data upward by about 3.5 inches.

That is, for any year from 2010 onward, the “adjusted” precipitation, P_adj, at station A may be given by:

  P_adj = P_A (raw) + 3.5 inches.

Thus the adjusted values become:
  2010: 9.50 + 3.5 = 13.00 in.  
  2011: 11.83 + 3.5 = 15.33 in.  
  2012: 13.40 + 3.5 = 16.90 in.  
  2013: 11.23 + 3.5 = 14.73 in.  
  2014: 13.14 + 3.5 = 16.64 in.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

a) For years 2010–2014, the adjusted values for station A are given by  
  P_adj = P_A + 3.5 inches.  
Thus, for example, in 2010: 
  \boxed{13.00 \text{ inches}}.

b) In general, to represent current conditions the station A record for later years should be raised by about 3.5 inches, i.e., for any year ≥2010: 
  \boxed{P_{\text{adj}} = P_A + 3.5 \text{ inches}}.

──────────────────────────────
Conclusion

The analysis shows that the station A data are consistent with its peers before 2010 but, starting in 2010, the values are systematically about 3.5 inches lower than the local reference mean. Hence, to “adjust” or “homogenize” station A’s record for current conditions, one should add approximately 3.5 inches to each season’s reported total for the years 2010 and later.

question:
The yearly precipitation levels at station X along with the average annual precipitation for 12 neighboring stations are listed on the subsequent page.  
a. Evaluate whether the data from station X is consistent.  
b. Identify the year when the breakpoint (shift in pattern) took place.  
c. What is the uncorrected average annual flow at station X?  
d. Calculate the corrected mean annual flow based on the latest regime conditions.  
e. Draw the double-mass curve using the adjusted data.  

| Annual Precipitation (mm) |  |  | Annual Precipitation (mm) |  |  |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Year | Station X | 12-Station Mean | Year | Station X | 12-Station Mean |
|  |  |  | 2000 | 447 | 325 |
| 1986 | 517 |  | 2001 | 396 | 442 |
| 1987 | 264 |  | 2002 | 385 | 364 |
| 1988 | 462 |  | 2003 | 308 | 299 |
| 1989 | 397 | 338 | 2004 | 319 | 429 |
| 1990 | 275 | 299 | 2005 | 352 | 430 |
| 1991 | 385 | 390 | 2006 | 429 | 455 |
| 1992 | 378 | 338 | 2007 | 275 | 338 |
| 1993 | 337 | 340 | 2008 | 330 | 377 |
| 1994 | 407 | 339 | 2009 | 253 | 364 |
| 1995 | 385 | 364 | 2010 | 407 | 442 |
| 1996 | 638 | 520 | 2011 | 374 | 429 |
| 1997 | 358 | 338 | 2012 | 330 | 455 |
| 1998 | 350 | 312 | 2013 | 308 | 438 |
| 1999 | 290 | 286 | 2014 | 297 | 325 |
response:
We shall show how to “read” the data and use a double‐mass approach to decide if the record is internally consistent. In many hydrometeorological applications one “plots” the cumulative precipitation at the “problem” station versus the cumulative regional (here “12‐station”) mean. In a “consistent” record the plotted points will lie approximately along a straight line. An abrupt change in slope suggests that something (in the station’s measurement method, for example) changed at a “break‐point.”

Below we explain step‐by‐step what we do and then give our final numerical answers.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Evaluating consistency (Part a)

Looking at the table we have two series:
 • For station X the annual precipitation (in mm) varies year‐to‐year.
 • With “neighbor” values given by the 12‐station mean.
Typically one examines the ratio between station X and the regional mean. Note, for example, that for the “pre–break” period (roughly the 1990’s) the ratios (X/mean) are near unity (generally between about 1.0–1.2) while in the later period (2000–2014) the corresponding ratios are systematically lower (in many cases well below 1). (An informal “eyeball” of the numbers: in 1996 we have 638/520 ≈ 1.23, whereas in 2009 the ratio is 253/364 ≈ 0.69.) 

This change in the relationship between Station X and the 12‐station mean is most easily seen from a double–mass plot (i.e. plotting the cumulative precipitation at station X vs. that for the neighboring stations). In such a plot the data for a “consistent” station would lie along a line with constant slope. Here, however, the slope clearly changes at a certain year. 

Thus, we conclude that the station X record is not internally consistent.

So, our answer for (a) is that the data are not consistent, showing an abrupt change in the relationship to the regional average.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Determining the breakpoint (Part b)

When one “connects the dots” on a double–mass plot the break in slope indicates a change in either the measurement regime or something else in the data‐collection. In our table the transition is clearly between the two groups:
 – the “old regime” (roughly data through 1999) and
 – the “new regime” (from 2000 on).
One “sees” that the abrupt shift in the ratio occurs between 1999 and 2000.

Thus the breakpoint (shift in measurement or sampling pattern) is taken to have occurred in the year 2000.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Uncorrected mean annual flow (Part c)

For our purposes the “flow” is simply the annual precipitation at station X. (Sometimes one speaks of “flow” when making runoff estimates, but here we assume that the precipitation, properly averaged, is the “flow‐value”.) 

Station X has data for 29 years (from 1986 to 2014). Adding up the precipitation values from each year we obtain

  1986: 517, 1987: 264, 1988: 462, 1989: 397, 1990: 275,
  1991: 385, 1992: 378, 1993: 337, 1994: 407, 1995: 385,
  1996: 638, 1997: 358, 1998: 350, 1999: 290, 2000: 447,
  2001: 396, 2002: 385, 2003: 308, 2004: 319, 2005: 352,
  2006: 429, 2007: 275, 2008: 330, 2009: 253, 2010: 407,
  2011: 374, 20012: 330, 2013: 308, 2014: 297.

A quick calculation gives a total of about 10 653 mm over the 29 years. (You can verify by summing the above numbers.) Thus the uncorrected average annual precipitation is

  Average = 10 653 mm / 29 ≈ 367 mm.

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Correcting to the latest regime (Part d)

Since the double–mass analysis shows that prior to 2000 the station’s record lay on a different “regime” than the later (and assumed more reliable) period, we “correct” the early data. A common method is to compute the average ratio of station X to the regional mean for the two periods and then multiply the “old‐regime” data by a correction factor that brings its average ratio into agreement with that of the “new regime.”

A simple (approximate) look at the numbers shows that:
 – For the pre–2000 period the average ratio (X/12–station mean) is roughly 1.08,
 – For the 2000–2014 period the average ratio is roughly 0.89.
Then the correction factor (applied to the pre–2000 data) is

  correction factor = (post–2000 average ratio) / (pre–2000 average ratio)
    ≈ 0.89/1.08 ≈ 0.825.

Thus, we multiply all “pre–2000” data (i.e. the years 1986–1999) by 0.825. 

Let S₁ be the sum of station X data for 1986–1999, and S₂ the sum from 2000–2014.
We have calculated S₁ ≈ 5 443 mm and S₂ = 10 653 – 5 443 = 5 210 mm.
After correction, the “old” data become

  S₁,corrected = 5 443 × 0.825 ≈ 4 490 mm.

Then the total “corrected” sum becomes

  S_total,corrected = 4 490 + 5 210 = 9 700 mm.

Since the record still covers 29 years, the corrected mean annual precipitation is

  9 700 mm / 29 ≈ 335 mm.

──────────────────────────────
Step 5. Drawing the double–mass curve (Part e)

To “draw” the double–mass (cumulative) curve one proceeds as follows:
 1. For each year, compute the cumulative total of the precipitation recorded at station X (vertical axis).
 2. In parallel, compute the cumulative total of the corresponding regional (12‐station) mean values (horizontal axis).
 3. Plot the resulting pairs. (One typically uses the raw (uncorrected) station X data to begin with.)
 4. You will notice that the points lie approximately on a straight line until about 1999, and then the line “kinks” (i.e. its slope changes) after the breakpoint in 2000.
 5. Finally, one can re–plot the curve using the “corrected” (adjusted) values for the early period. That plot should show a straight line (or at least a much improved linearity), which confirms that the correction has been applied properly.

A sketch of the double–mass curve should show cumulative station X on the vertical axis and cumulative 12–station mean on the horizontal axis, with a distinct change in slope at a cumulative 12–station value corresponding to about 2000.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

a) The station’s record is inconsistent because the relationship (i.e. the slope in the double–mass plot) between station X and the 12–station mean changes abruptly.

  \boxed{\text{The station X data are inconsistent.}}

b) The breakpoint, where the slope changes, occurs between 1999 and 2000. We identify the year 2000 as the change‐point.

  \boxed{2000}

c) The uncorrected (raw) average annual flow (precipitation) at station X is approximately 367 mm.

  \boxed{367\text{ mm}}

d) After adjusting the pre–2000 data (multiplying them by about 0.825) so that they match the “new regime” (2000–2014) behavior, the corrected mean annual flow comes to roughly 335 mm.

  \boxed{335\text{ mm}}

e) The double–mass curve is drawn by plotting for each year the cumulative precipitation at station X (vertical axis) against the cumulative 12–station mean (horizontal axis). In the “raw” plot the data follow one straight line until about 2000 (breakpoint) and then change slope; after correction (multiplying pre–2000 values by 0.825) the entire curve falls along a unique straight line indicating internal consistency.

  \boxed{\text{A double–mass plot with a clear slope change at 2000, and a corrected straight–line curve after adjustment.}}

These are our detailed conclusions based on the data provided.

question: Using the precipitation data for different durations provided in Example 2.6, construct the intensity-duration-frequency curves for return periods of 5 years and 3 years.
response:
Below is a step‐by‐step explanation of how one would go about constructing the intensity–duration–frequency (IDF) curves, followed by the final expressions for the 5‐year and 3‐year return period curves.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 1. Data Preparation

Typically, one starts with a series of precipitation “depths” measured for several durations. In Example 2.6 (as given in your text), precipitation amounts (in millimeters) are provided for a number of storm durations (e.g., 5, 10, 15, 30, 60 minutes) for several return periods. The first step is to compute a rainfall intensity for each observation. The intensity is defined as

  Intensity, I = (precipitation depth) / (duration)  .

If the precipitation depth is in mm and the duration is given in minutes, you may convert the duration to hours (if desired) so that your intensity is in mm/hr.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 2. Assume an IDF Functional Form

Experience and theory often suggest that the dependency of rainfall intensity on the duration follows a power‐law form. Therefore, for a given return period T, one assumes:

  I(t) = a / t^b         (1)

or, equivalently, 

  I(t) = a t^(–b).

Here,
• t is the duration (usually in minutes or hours),
• a and b are regression parameters that can be determined from the data.
  
In many studies, a logarithmic transformation is applied to linearize Eq. (1):

  ln I = ln a – b ln t.     (2)

─────────────────────────────  
Step 3. Regression for Each Return Period

Using the precipitation data of Example 2.6, you would separate the dataset by return period. For each return period (in our case, T = 5 years and T = 3 years), you have a set of intensity values computed from the measured depths and durations. Then, by performing a least-squares linear regression on the transformed data (ln I versus ln t), you obtain the values for ln a and b:
  • a = exp(intercept)
  • b = (slope).

These parameters will typically be different for different return periods. Let’s denote them as (a₅, b₅) for T = 5 years and (a₃, b₃) for T = 3 years.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 4. Constructing the Curves

Once you have the regression parameters, you can “construct” the curve by calculating the intensity I(t) for any desired duration using Eq. (1). The curves are usually plotted on a log–log plot with duration on the horizontal axis and intensity on the vertical axis. In many practical engineering applications, the curves are drawn with the fitted power–law lines superimposed over the “observed” rainfall intensities obtained from the data.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 5. Final IDF Equations for the Two Return Periods

If, for example, the regression analysis gives you (note these are example numbers – in your work you will use the values obtained from your data analysis):

For the 5‑year return period:
  a₅ = 175 (mm·min^(b₅)/hr if t is measured in minutes)  and  b₅ = 0.53,

so that

  I₅(t) = 175 t^(–0.53).

For the 3‑year return period:
  a₃ = 145  and  b₃ = 0.53,

so that

  I₃(t) = 145 t^(–0.53).

These expressions mean that for a storm of duration t (in minutes) the estimated rainfall intensity is computed by these formulas.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answers

a) For the 5‐year return period, the IDF relationship is:

  \boxed{I_{5}(t)=175\,t^{-0.53}}

b) For the 3‐year return period, the IDF relationship is:

  \boxed{I_{3}(t)=145\,t^{-0.53}}

─────────────────────────────  
Additional Remarks

• In practice the parameters a and b could depend on the region and the quality of the dataset.  
• A log–log plot is frequently used because if the data follows a power law, the transformed data (ln I vs. ln t) will appear as a straight-line relationship.  
• The constants given above (175, 145, and 0.53) are specifically for this hypothetical example. You would replace them with the actual values obtained from your regression analysis of the Example 2.6 data.  

This step–by–step procedure shows how intensity–duration–frequency curves are constructed from available rainfall data.

question:
Near a reservoir, pan measurements recorded the following data on a specific day. Calculate the daily evaporation using (a) the basic formula with $K=0.7$, and (b) the modified formula, with $K^{\prime}=1.5$ at 4 m.

1. Pan evaporation $=15 \mathrm{~mm}$
2. Average air temperature at $4 \mathrm{~m}=23^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
3. Highest reservoir temperature $=18^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
4. Lowest reservoir temperature $=15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
5. Highest pan temperature $=24^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
6. Lowest pan temperature $=18^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
7. Relative humidity $=47 \%$. (c) Use the aerodynamic method of evaporation at 4 m to solve the problem if the wind speed is $23 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ at 4 m level and $C_{E}=1.3 \times 10^{-3}$ at 4 m. (d) Resolve the problem for evaporation using the energy balance method. The Bowen ratio is 0.1, $n / N=0.85$, and the location is at $70^{\circ} \mathrm{N}$ latitude, with an extraterrestrial radiation of $42.5 \mathrm{MJ} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$ day. Ignore the soil heat index. (e) Determine the evaporation by the combination method, utilizing data from parts c and d.
response:
We wish to “estimate” the water‐surface (reservoir) evaporation from a measured pan evaporation and several “meteorological” data. In many practical studies a “pan” (usually a well‐exposed Class A pan) is used so that the (overestimated) pan evaporation (E_pan) is then “converted” into an estimate of the evaporation from a large open-water body by means of an empirical “pan‐coefficient.” Often one writes

  E_reservoir = K · E_pan   (basic “pan‐method”)

and sometimes one “modifies” the expression to try to “remove” the effect of a difference between the water temperatures of the pan (which is heated by radiation) and the reservoir. One very simple way (among several proposed in the literature) is to assume a linear relation such as

  E_reservoir = E_pan – K′ [T_pan,avg – T_res,avg]   (modified formula)

where K′ is an empirical “temperature‐correction” coefficient (with typical units mm/(°C·day)) and the “average” temperatures are computed from the highest and lowest readings in the day. (Several authors have suggested different forms. Here we follow one simple “text‐book” approach.) In addition, one may estimate evaporation by more “physically based” methods – an aerodynamic method (which depends on the wind‐speed and the humidity difference between the air and that just above the water) and an “energy‐balance” approach (which partitions the net available radiation between the latent heat flux and the sensible heat flux, using a Bowen ratio). Finally, one may “combine” these two estimates to yield a “best–estimate”. (In practice, one must be aware that a given set of data and a combination of equations is only as good as the available calibration data.) 

We are given:

• E_pan = 15 mm/day 
• Air temperature at 4 m: T_air(4 m) = 23 °C 
• Reservoir water temperatures: T_max,res = 18 °C and T_min,res = 15 °C 
• Pan water temperatures: T_max,pan = 24 °C and T_min,pan = 18 °C 
• Relative humidity = 47%

and additional data for the aerodynamic and energy‐balance methods:
• Wind speed at 4 m: U = 23 m/s 
• Aerodynamic transfer coefficient: C_E = 1.3×10⁻³ (dimensionless) 
• Bowen ratio = 0.1 
• “n/N” = 0.85 (n is net available energy at the water surface whereas N is the extraterrestrial radiation) 
• Extraterrestrial radiation: N = 42.5 MJ/m²·day 
• (Soil heat flux is ignored.)

A few remarks: (1) In many “pan–coefficient” studies a “basic” value near 0.7 is used so that the reservoir evaporation is only about 70% of the measured pan value. (2) Because the pan water is usually “warmed” relative to the reservoir, one may try a correction that subtracts an extra amount proportional to the temperature excess. One simple modified formula is

  E_res = E_pan – K′ (T̄_pan – T̄_res).

Below we work “step‐by step.”

──────────────────────────────
Part (a). Basic formula with K = 0.7

The basic conversion is simply

  E_res = K × E_pan.

Here,
  E_pan = 15 mm/day  and K = 0.7.

Thus,
  E_res = 0.7 × 15 = 10.5 mm/day.

We conclude

  (a) E_res = \boxed{10.5\text{ mm/day}}.

──────────────────────────────
Part (b). Modified formula with K′ = 1.5 (mm/(°C·day))

One common “modified” approach is to try to reduce further E_pan by subtracting an extra factor proportional to the temperature difference between the pan and the reservoir. For our purposes we take

  E_res = E_pan – K′ (T̄_pan – T̄_res).

Here we first compute the daily “average” water temperatures in the pan and in the reservoir:
  T̄_pan = (T_max,pan + T_min,pan) / 2 = (24 + 18)/2 = 21 °C,
  T̄_res = (T_max,res + T_min,res) / 2 = (18 + 15)/2 = 16.5 °C.

The temperature difference is
  T̄_pan – T̄_res = 21 – 16.5 = 4.5 °C.

Now, with K′ = 1.5 mm/(°C·day),

  Extra correction = K′ (T̄_pan – T̄_res) = 1.5 × 4.5 = 6.75 mm/day.

Thus the modified reservoir evaporation is

  E_res = 15 – 6.75 = 8.25 mm/day.

So we have

  (b) E_res = \boxed{8.25\text{ mm/day}}.

──────────────────────────────
Part (c). Aerodynamic method at 4 m

In the aerodynamic method the evaporation rate (mass flux) is taken to be proportional to the wind speed (U) and to the difference in specific humidity between the saturated value at the water surface (assumed here to be the same as that at the measurement level determined by the air temperature) and the actual specific humidity in the air. A common formulation is

  E (kg/(m²·s)) = C_E · U · (q_sat – q_actual).

We assume the meteorological measurements at 4 m represent the “air‐layer” just above the surface. (In more detailed studies one might “adjust” for aerodynamic roughness lengths; here we use the given C_E directly.) To obtain evaporation in mm/day, we note that 1 kg m⁻² = 1 mm of water. 

Step 1. Compute the saturation vapour pressure at T_air = 23 °C. A commonly used formula is
  e_s(T) = 0.611 exp[17.27 T/(T + 237.3)]   (e in kPa).

For T = 23 °C:
  Exponent = (17.27×23)/(23+237.3) = (397.21)/(260.3) ≈ 1.525.
  exp(1.525) ≈ 4.60.
Thus, 
  e_s(23 °C) ≈ 0.611 × 4.60 ≈ 2.81 kPa.

Step 2. The actual vapour pressure is given by the relative humidity:
  e_actual = RH × e_s = 0.47 × 2.81 ≈ 1.321 kPa.

Step 3. Convert these vapour pressures to specific humidity. Under the assumption of a near‐standard pressure (P ≈ 101.3 kPa) one uses
  q = 0.622 e / (P – 0.378 e).

For saturation:
  q_sat = 0.622 × 2.81/(101.3 – 0.378×2.81).
  Calculate 0.378×2.81 ≈ 1.062, so denominator ≈ 101.3–1.062 = 100.238 kPa.
  q_sat ≈ (1.749)/100.238 ≈ 0.01744 kg/kg.

For the actual air:
  q_actual = 0.622 × 1.321/(101.3 – 0.378×1.321).
  0.378×1.321 ≈ 0.499, so denominator ≈ 101.3–0.499 = 100.801 kPa.
  q_actual ≈ (0.822)/100.801 ≈ 0.00814 kg/kg.

Thus, the specific humidity deficit is
  Δq = q_sat – q_actual ≈ 0.01744 – 0.00814 = 0.00930 kg/kg.

Step 4. Now insert into the aerodynamic formula using:
  U = 23 m/s and C_E = 1.3×10⁻³.
Then the evaporation rate as a mass flux is
  E = C_E × U × Δq = (1.3×10⁻³) × 23 × 0.00930 ≈ 1.3×10⁻³ × 0.2139 ≈ 0.0002781 kg/(m²·s).

Step 5. Convert to mm/day: Multiply by the number of seconds per day, 86400 s/day:
  E_day = 0.0002781 × 86400 ≈ 24.0 mm/day.

Thus we have

  (c) E_res ≈ \boxed{24\text{ mm/day}}.

──────────────────────────────
Part (d). Energy balance method

In the energy‐balance method one assumes that the net available energy at the surface is partitioned into latent heat flux (E, the energy used for evaporation) and sensible heat flux (H). The Bowen ratio is defined by
  B = H/E.
For a very “wet” surface the Bowen ratio can be small; here B = 0.1. If one denotes the net available energy at the surface by n and ignores the soil heat flux, then
  n = H + E = E (B + 1)  ⟹ E = n/(1+B).

However, we are not given n directly; instead we are told that n/N = 0.85 where N is the extraterrestrial radiation, here given as 42.5 MJ/m²·day. Thus
  n = 0.85 × 42.5 = 36.125 MJ/m²·day.

Then the latent heat flux (energy available for evaporation) is
  E_energy (in MJ/m²·day) = n/(1+B) = 36.125/1.1 ≈ 32.84 MJ/m²·day.

To convert this energy into an equivalent water depth, we use the latent heat of vaporization: L_v ≈ 2.45 MJ/kg. (Since 1 kg m⁻² = 1 mm of water over the area, we get mm/day directly.)

Thus the evaporation is
  E (mm/day) = (32.84 MJ/m²·day) / (2.45 MJ/kg) ≈ 13.4 mm/day.

So,

  (d) E_res = \boxed{13.4\text{ mm/day}}.

──────────────────────────────
Part (e). Combination method

A “combination method” is sometimes used in which the estimates from (c) the aerodynamic method and (d) the energy–balance method are merged. (There is no unique choice; a common simple choice is to take an arithmetic mean.) Here, we combine the two estimates simply as
  E_comb = [E_aero + E_energy] / 2.
That is,
  E_comb = (24.0 + 13.4)/2 = 37.4/2 ≈ 18.7 mm/day.

Thus,

  (e) E_res = \boxed{18.7\text{ mm/day}}.

──────────────────────────────
Summary of Answers

a) Basic pan–method:   E_res = 0.7 × 15 =      \boxed{10.5\text{ mm/day}}

b) Modified method (subtracting a temperature–excess correction):
  E_res = 15 – 1.5×(21 – 16.5) = 15 – 6.75 =   \boxed{8.25\text{ mm/day}}

c) Aerodynamic method:
  E_res ≈                  \boxed{24\text{ mm/day}}

d) Energy–balance method:
  E_res ≈ 36.125/1.1 /2.45 ≈      \boxed{13.4\text{ mm/day}}

e) Combination method (arithmetic mean of (c) and (d)):
  E_res ≈ (24 + 13.4)/2 ≈      \boxed{18.7\text{ mm/day}}

Each of these estimates is based on a particular set of assumptions and empirical coefficients; in practice the “best” estimate must be judged in light of local conditions and calibration data.

question:
The average temperature and relative humidity for October are given as follows. Throughout the month, the pan recorded an evaporation level of 19 cm. Calculate the monthly evaporation from the lake using (a) the simple formula with $K=0.75$, and (b) the revised formula with $K^{\prime}=1.5$.
8. Monthly average air temperature at $4 \mathrm{~m}=17^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
9. Monthly average maximum lake temperature $=13^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
10. Monthly average maximum pan temperature $=16^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
11. Monthly average relative humidity $=60 \%$. (c) Address the problem using the aerodynamic method for evaporation at 4 m. The wind speed is $47 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ at the 8 m level. Assume the mean lake temperature is $85 \%$ of the maximum. $C_{E}$ is $1.1 \times 10^{-3}$. Use the reference height $Z_{0}$ pertinent to the water surface. (d) Solve the problem for evaporation using the energy balance method. The lake is positioned at $30^{\circ} \mathrm{N}$ latitude. The Bowen ratio is $0.05$ and $n / N=0.8$. Omit the soil heat flux. (e) Resolve the problem for evaporation using the combination method, incorporating data from problems c and d.
response:
We will show that one acceptable solution is to “translate” the pan reading of 19 cm/month into a lake evaporation value by several methods. (Note that in real‐world work the numbers are sensitive to assumptions and local conditions; here we adopt one set of reasonable assumptions.) In what follows the basic data are

 • Pan evaporation (Eₚ) = 19 cm/month

 • Monthly average air temperature (at 4 m) = 17 °C

 • Monthly average maximum lake temperature = 13 °C

 • Monthly average maximum pan temperature = 16 °C

 • Monthly average relative humidity = 60 %

In what follows we “derive” the answers step‐by‐step.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): The “simple” method

A common simple “pan‐to‐lake” conversion is

  E (lake) = K · Eₚ

with a conversion factor K. Here K = 0.75. Thus

  E = 0.75 × 19 cm = 14.25 cm.

Thus we write as our answer

  (a)                  
    \boxed{14.25\,{\rm cm}}

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): The “revised” formula

Sometimes one finds a revised conversion in which the lake evaporation is “boosted” relative to the pan by using a larger coefficient. For example, if one uses

  E (lake) = K' · Eₚ

with K′ = 1.5 then

  E = 1.5 × 19 cm = 28.5 cm.

This gives

  (b)                  
    \boxed{28.5\,{\rm cm}}

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): The aerodynamic method

One form of the aerodynamic (bulk‐transfer) formulation is that the evaporation flux (mass per unit area and time) is given by

  Eₐ = ρ_air · C_E · U · (q_s – q_a).

Here

 • ρ_air ≈ 1.2 kg/m³ is the air density,
 • C_E = 1.1×10⁻³ is an exchange coefficient,
 • U is the wind speed (at the height where evaporation is evaluated),
 • q_s is the saturation mixing ratio at the “surface” (here taken to be the water temperature) and
 • q_a is the ambient mixing ratio.

Because the wind–speed is given at 8 m (U(8)=47 m/s) and we wish to know it at 4 m we must “descend” it using the logarithmic wind–profile law:

  U(z) = (u* / κ) ln(z/z₀).

Here κ ≃ 0.4 is von Karman’s constant and z₀ is the roughness length for an open water surface. A typical value is z₀ ≃ 2×10⁻⁴ m. Using the wind–speed at 8 m we have

  47 = (u* / 0.4) ln(8/z₀).

With z₀ = 2×10⁻⁴ m we find

  ln(8/2×10⁻⁴) = ln(40000) ≃ 10.5966 → u* = 47×0.4/10.5966 ≃ 1.775 m/s.

Now the wind speed at 4 m is

  U(4) = (1.775/0.4) ln(4/2×10⁻⁴)
     = 4.4375 × ln(20000)     (20000 = 4/(2×10⁻⁴))
     ln(20000) ≃ 9.9035  → U(4) ≃ 4.4375×9.9035 ≃ 43.92 m/s.

Next, we need (q_s – q_a). The saturation mixing ratio (approximate formula) is
  q = 0.622 e/(P – e)
and since the vapor pressures are small compared to atmospheric pressure (P ≃ 1013 mb) we approximate
  q ≃ 0.622 e/1013.
We must choose a temperature for eₛ. In the aerodynamic method the water’s “skin‐temperature” is used. We are told to take the “mean lake temperature” as 85% of the maximum so

  T_lake ≃ 0.85 × 13 °C ≃ 11.05 °C.
Using for example the Tetens formula,
  e_sat(T) = 6.112 exp[17.67 T/(T+243.5)]
(in millibars) gives
  e_sat(11.05) ≃ 6.112 exp[17.67×11.05/(11.05+243.5)]
             ≈ 6.112 exp(0.766) ≃ 6.112×2.151 ≃ 13.15 mb.
For the ambient air at 17 °C, the saturation vapor pressure is (using the same formula)
  e_sat(17) ≃ 6.112 exp[17.67×17/(17+243.5)].
A quick calculation gives
  exponent ≃ 17.67×17/260.5 ≃ 1.152 → exp(1.152) ≃ 3.166,
so that
  e_sat(17) ≃ 6.112×3.166 ≃ 19.37 mb.
Since the relative humidity is 60 %, the actual vapor pressure in the air is
  e_a = 0.60×19.37 ≃ 11.62 mb.

Thus the difference is

  Δe = e_sat (water side) – e_a = 13.15 – 11.62 = 1.53 mb.

Converting to a mixing–ratio difference (in kg/kg),

  Δq ≃ 0.622 × (1.53/1013) ≃ (0.622×1.53)/1013 ≃ 0.00094 kg/kg.

Now the evaporative mass flux is

  F = ρ_air · C_E · U(4) · Δq
    = 1.2 × 1.1×10⁻³ × 43.92 × 0.00094 kg/(m²·s).

Let us evaluate step‐by‐step:
  1.2 × 1.1×10⁻³ = 0.00132,
  0.00132 × 43.92 ≃ 0.05789,
  0.05789 × 0.00094 ≃ 0.0000544 kg/(m²·s).

To convert to cm/month, note that 1 kg/m² of water is equivalent to 1 mm depth of water. There are 86,400 seconds in a day so in one day

  E_day = 0.0000544 kg m⁻² s⁻¹ × 86400 s/day ≃ 4.70 kg/m²/day (or mm/day).

For a 30‐day month this is

  E_month ≃ 4.70 mm/day × 30 ≃ 141 mm, i.e. about 14.1 cm.

Thus we may write

  (c)                  
    \boxed{14.1\,{\rm cm}}

──────────────────────────────
Step (d): The energy–balance method

In the energy balance approach one writes for the lake the “surface energy‐budget”

  Rn = LE + H,
 
with LE (latent heat flux) giving the evaporation and H the sensible heat flux. The Bowen ratio is defined as

  B = H/LE.
 
If we neglect soil heat flux and any heat storage, then the entire net radiation Rn (available energy) is partitioned into latent and sensible heat. Thus

  LE = Rn/(1+B).

We are told that the ratio of the “observed” net radiation to the “clear–sky” (or extraterrestrial) radiation is n/N = 0.8. Although N (the maximum value) depends upon latitude and time of year – here the lake is at 30°N – one may adopt a typical value of, say, 18 MJ/m²/day for October. Then

  n = 0.8×18 = 14.4 MJ/m²/day.
 
Taking B = 0.05 we have

  LE = 14.4/(1.05) ≃ 13.71 MJ/m²/day.
 
Since the latent heat of evaporation is approximately L = 2.45×10⁶ J/kg, the rate of evaporation (in kg/m²·day, and numerically equal to mm/day) is

  E_day = (13.71×10⁶ J/m²/day) / (2.45×10⁶ J/kg) ≃ 5.60 mm/day.

For a 30–day month

  E_month ≃ 5.60 mm/day × 30 ≃ 168 mm, i.e. about 16.8 cm.

Thus we obtain

  (d)                  
    \boxed{16.8\,{\rm cm}}

──────────────────────────────
Step (e): The combination method

Often one combines the aerodynamic and energy–balance estimates in order to take advantage of both the mass–transfer and energy arguments. One simple procedure is to take an (unweighted) average of the two values. Thus from (c) and (d) we have

  E_comb = (14.1 + 16.8) / 2 ≃ 15.45 cm.

So we state

  (e)                  
    \boxed{15.5\,{\rm cm}}

──────────────────────────────
A Note on the Answers

Notice that depending on the chosen “conversion factor” one may get a very different answer: the simple method gave about 14.3 cm and the revised formula, 28.5 cm. Many investigators in evaporation studies compare several methods because each is based on different assumptions. In our example the aerodynamic and energy balance methods gave intermediate values of about 14–17 cm while a combination method gives about 15.5 cm/month.

Thus one acceptable set of answers is:

a) \boxed{14.25\,{\rm cm}}

b) \boxed{28.5\,{\rm cm}}

c) \boxed{14.1\,{\rm cm}}

d) \boxed{16.8\,{\rm cm}}

e) \boxed{15.5\,{\rm cm}}

question:
Calculate the daily reference crop (alfalfa) evapotranspiration for the month of June in Boston, MA, located at approximately $42^{\circ} \mathrm{N}$ latitude. The average meteorological data are provided as follows:

1. Average air temperature (June) $=24.2^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
2. Relative humidity $=65 \%$
3. Wind speed at $2 \mathrm{~m}=1.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$
4. Average $\%$ sunshine $=70 \%$

Ignore the soil heat flux.
response:
We wish to “back‐calculate” the daily reference evapotranspiration for a tall‐crop (alfalfa) using the Penman–Monteith formulation. In the FAO‐56 procedure a different set of “surface” coefficients are used for a tall‐crop than for a short‐crop. In particular, for the tall‐crop the FAO “standardized reference evapotranspiration” is given by

  ETₐₗ𝒻 = {0.408 ∆(Rₙ – G) + γ [1600/(T + 273)] u₂ (eₛ – eₐ)}
        / {∆ + γ (1 + 0.38 u₂)},         (1)

where

• ∆ is the slope of the saturation vapor‐pressure curve (kPa/°C),
• Rₙ is the net radiation at the crop surface (MJ m⁻² d⁻¹),
• G is the soil heat flux (MJ m⁻² d⁻¹; here taken = 0),
• γ is the psychrometric constant (kPa/°C),
• T is the mean air temperature at 2 m (°C),
• u₂ is the wind speed at 2 m (m s⁻¹), and
• eₛ and eₐ are the saturation and actual vapor pressures (kPa), respectively.

Below we detail approximate calculations step‐by‐step given the following average June data for Boston, MA:

  T = 24.2 °C  
  RH = 65 %  
  u₂ = 1.8 m/s  
  % sunshine ≈ 70 %  

We make a number of reasonable approximations to illustrate the method.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 1. Compute the Saturation Vapor Pressure and Slope, ∆

The saturation vapor pressure (in kPa) at temperature T is approximated by

  eₛ(T) = 0.6108 exp[(17.27 T)/(T + 237.3)].

For T = 24.2 °C:
  • Compute the exponent:  
    [17.27 × 24.2] / (24.2 + 237.3)  
      = (417.53)/(261.5) ≈ 1.597.
  • Thus, eₛ ≈ 0.6108 exp(1.597) ≈ 0.6108 × 4.94 ≈ 3.02 kPa.

Next, the slope of the saturation vapor‐pressure curve is

  ∆ = [4098 eₛ(T)] / (T + 237.3)².
  With (T + 237.3) = 24.2 + 237.3 = 261.5, so (261.5)² ≈ 68,490,
    ∆ ≈ (4098 × 3.02) / 68,490 ≈ 12,380/68,490 ≈ 0.1806 kPa/°C.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 2. Determine the Actual Vapor Pressure

Assuming the actual vapor pressure is 65% of the saturation value:

  eₐ = 0.65 × 3.02 ≈ 1.96 kPa.
Then the vapor‐pressure deficit is
  (eₛ – eₐ) ≈ 3.02 – 1.96 ≈ 1.06 kPa.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 3. Estimate Net Radiation (Rₙ)

The net radiation is given by
  Rₙ = (Rₙ,shortwave) – (Rₙ,longwave).
A common procedure is to compute:
  Rₙ,shortwave = (1 – α) Rs,
with albedo α ≈ 0.23. We must estimate Rs, the incoming solar (shortwave) radiation.

Because the “% sunshine” is 70% (i.e. the day isn’t fully clear), we can assume that Rs is about 70% of the extraterrestrial radiation, Ra. (Several empirical formulas exist; here we adopt the simple scaling.)
 
• Compute Ra. For a given day the extraterrestrial radiation (MJ m⁻² day⁻¹) is computed from
  Ra = (24 × 60/π) G_sc d_r [ω_s sin φ sin δ + cos φ cos δ sin ω_s],
with
  – G_sc = 0.0820 MJ m⁻² min⁻¹ (solar constant),
  – φ the latitude (42°N → 0.733 rad),
  – δ the solar declination. Near the summer solstice, δ ≈ 23.45° ≈ 0.409 rad,
  – ω_s the sunset hour angle, given by ω_s = arccos(–tan φ tan δ).
  For φ = 42° and δ = 23.45°:
    tan 42° ≈ 0.900,  tan 23.45° ≈ 0.435,
    so tan φ tan δ ≈ 0.391 and ω_s ≈ arccos(–0.391) ≈ 1.97 rad.
  – d_r is the inverse‐relative distance Earth–Sun. For a day near June 21, one finds d_r ≈ 0.967.
  Now, note that
    24×60/π ≈ 1440/3.1416 ≈ 458.4.
  Next compute the bracketed term:
    sin φ sin δ = sin 42° sin 23.45° ≈ 0.669 × 0.399 ≈ 0.267,
    so ω_s sin φ sin δ ≈ 1.97 × 0.267 ≈ 0.526.
    cos φ cos δ = cos 42° cos 23.45° ≈ 0.743 × 0.918 ≈ 0.682,
    and sin ω_s ≈ sin 1.97 ≈ 0.919,
    so cos φ cos δ sin ω_s ≈ 0.682 × 0.919 ≈ 0.627.
  Thus the sum is ≈ 0.526 + 0.627 = 1.153.
  Finally,
    Ra = 458.4 × 0.0820 × 0.967 × 1.153 ≈ 41.93 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹.

• Then, approximate the measured solar radiation as
  Rs ≈ 0.70 × Ra ≈ 0.70 × 41.93 ≈ 29.35 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹.

• Now, the net short‐wave radiation is:
  Rₙ,shortwave = (1 – 0.23) Rs ≈ 0.77 × 29.35 ≈ 22.61 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹.

For the net long‐wave radiation, a common formulation is
  Rₙ,longwave = σ ( (T_max,K⁴ + T_min,K⁴)/2 ) (0.34 – 0.14√eₐ) (1.35 (Rs/R_so) – 0.35),
where σ = 4.903×10⁻⁹ MJ m⁻² day⁻¹ K⁻⁴.  
Unfortunately only a mean T is given. One may assume typical daytime extremes for June in Boston; for example, take T_max ≈ 28 °C (301 K) and T_min ≈ 20 °C (293 K).

• Compute an approximate average of the fourth powers:
  Estimate 301⁴ ≈ 8.21×10⁹ and 293⁴ ≈ 7.48×10⁹; average ≈ (8.21 + 7.48)/2 ×10⁹ = 7.85×10⁹.
• Then σ × average ≈ 4.903×10⁻⁹ × 7.85×10⁹ ≈ 38.46 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹.
• The factor (0.34 – 0.14√eₐ) with eₐ ≈ 1.96 gives √1.96 ≈ 1.4, so
  0.34 – 0.14×1.4 = 0.34 – 0.196 = 0.144.
• The clear‐sky solar radiation, R_so, is estimated by
  R_so = (0.75 + 2×10⁻⁵ z) Ra. For low elevation (z ≈ 0), R_so ≈ 0.75 Ra ≈ 0.75 × 41.93 ≈ 31.45 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹.
  Thus Rs/R_so ≈ 29.35/31.45 ≈ 0.933, and so
  1.35 (Rs/R_so) – 0.35 ≈ 1.35×0.933 – 0.35 ≈ 0.91.
• Thus, Rₙ,longwave ≈ 38.46 × 0.144 × 0.91 ≈ 5.04 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹.

Finally, the net radiation:
  Rₙ = Rₙ,shortwave – Rₙ,longwave ≈ 22.61 – 5.04 ≈ 17.57 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 4. Calculate ETₐₗ𝒻 Using the Tall‐Crop Penman–Monteith Equation

Recall Equation (1):

  ETₐₗ𝒻 = {0.408 ∆ (Rₙ – G) + γ [1600/(T + 273)] u₂ (eₛ – eₐ)}
       / {∆ + γ (1 + 0.38 u₂)}.

We use:
  ∆ = 0.1806 kPa/°C,
  Rₙ = 17.57 MJ/m²/d,
  G = 0,
  γ = 0.066 kPa/°C (typical near sea‐level),
  T + 273 = 24.2 + 273 = 297.2 K,
  u₂ = 1.8 m/s,
  (eₛ – eₐ) ≈ 1.06 kPa.

Now calculate the two numerator terms:

a) The radiation term:
  0.408 ∆ (Rₙ – G) = 0.408 × 0.1806 × 17.57.
First, 0.1806 × 17.57 ≈ 3.17, and 0.408 × 3.17 ≈ 1.293 mm/d.

b) The aerodynamic term:
  γ [1600/(T+273)] u₂ (eₛ – eₐ) = 0.066 × (1600/297.2) × 1.8 × 1.06.
Compute 1600/297.2 ≈ 5.38; then 5.38 × 1.8 ≈ 9.68; then 9.68 × 1.06 ≈ 10.26; finally multiplying by 0.066 gives about 0.677 mm/d.

Thus, the numerator is
  1.293 + 0.677 ≈ 1.97 mm/d.

Now the denominator:
  ∆ + γ (1 + 0.38 u₂) = 0.1806 + 0.066 (1 + 0.38×1.8).
Compute 0.38×1.8 = 0.684, so 1 + 0.684 = 1.684; then 0.066×1.684 ≈ 0.111; thus, the denominator ≈ 0.1806 + 0.111 = 0.2916.

Thus,
  ETₐₗ𝒻 = 1.97 / 0.2916 ≈ 6.75 mm/day.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Result

For June in Boston, MA, the daily reference crop (alfalfa) evapotranspiration is approximately

  \boxed{6.75\text{ mm/day}}

Note:
• Because of various approximations (especially in estimating radiation and the long‐wave component) this value is an approximate “back‐of‐the‐envelope” calculation.
• More detailed computations could use measured solar radiation, daily T_max and T_min, and more site‐specific adjustments.

Thus, the detailed derivation leads to our final answer.

question:
For Boise, Idaho, at a latitude of approximately $44^{\circ} \mathrm{N}$, calculate the daily reference crop (grass) evapotranspiration for the month of July. The provided meteorological data includes:

1. Average July air temperature $=22.5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
2. Relative humidity $=45 \%$
3. Wind speed at $4 \mathrm{~m}=2.54 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$
4. Average percentage of sunshine $=82 \%$

Ignore the soil heat flux and use a reference height of 0.03 m.
response:
We wish to estimate the daily reference (grass) evapotranspiration ET₀ (in mm day⁻¹) for Boise, Idaho in July. A common method is to use the FAO-56 Penman–Monteith equation

  ET₀ = {0.408 Δ (Rₙ – G) + γ · [900/(T + 273)] u₂ (eₛ – eₐ)}⁄{Δ + γ · (1 + 0.34 u₂)}

where

 • ET₀ is in mm day⁻¹,
 • Δ is the slope of the saturation vapor pressure curve (kPa °C⁻¹),
 • Rₙ is the net radiation at the crop surface (MJ m⁻² day⁻¹),
 • G is the soil heat flux (MJ m⁻² day⁻¹; here we take G = 0),
 • γ is the psychrometric constant (kPa °C⁻¹),
 • T is the mean air temperature (°C),
 • u₂ is the wind speed (m s⁻¹) at 2 m height,
 • eₛ is the saturation vapor pressure (kPa) at T,
 • eₐ is the actual vapor pressure (kPa).

We now work through the steps.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Estimate the Saturation & Actual Vapor Pressure and Δ

A common formula for saturation vapor pressure is

  eₛ = 0.6108 · exp[(17.27 T)/(T + 237.3)]  (kPa)

For T = 22.5 °C:

  eₛ = 0.6108 · exp[(17.27 × 22.5)/(22.5 + 237.3)]
    = 0.6108 · exp[(388.575)/(259.8)]
    ≈ 0.6108 · exp(1.495)
    ≈ 0.6108 · 4.46
    ≈ 2.73 kPa.

With a relative humidity of 45% we have

  eₐ = 0.45 · eₛ ≈ 0.45 × 2.73 ≈ 1.23 kPa.

Now, the slope Δ [kPa/°C] is calculated as

  Δ = 4098 · eₛ / (T + 237.3)².

With T = 22.5 °C we have

  Δ = 4098 × 2.73 / (22.5 + 237.3)²
    = 4098 × 2.73 / (259.8)².

Since (259.8)² ≈ 67500, then

  Δ ≈ (4098 × 2.73)/67500 ≈ 11180/67500 ≈ 0.1657 kPa °C⁻¹.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Adjust Wind Speed to 2 m Height

The Penman–Monteith formula uses u₂ (wind speed at 2 m). We are given u at 4 m (u₄ = 2.54 m/s). A standard logarithmic profile conversion is

  u₂ = u_z · [4.87/(ln(67.8·z – 5.42))].

For z = 4 m:

  ln(67.8·4 – 5.42) = ln(271.2 – 5.42) = ln(265.78) ≈ 5.583.

So,

  u₂ = 2.54 · (4.87/5.583) ≈ 2.54 · 0.873 ≈ 2.22 m/s.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Estimate the Net Radiation Rₙ

Rₙ (MJ m⁻² day⁻¹) is the difference between incoming short‐wave and outgoing long‐wave radiation. We use the following steps:

a) Estimate daily solar radiation (Rₛ). When sunshine “duration” information is available, one common approach uses

  Rₛ = (aₛ + bₛ·(n/N)) · Rₐ,

where Rₐ is the extraterrestrial radiation and n/N is the fraction of possible sunshine. Typical coefficients for an interior location are aₛ = 0.25 and bₛ = 0.50. For Boise in July, Rₐ can be on the order of 41 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹. With n/N = 0.82 then

  Rₛ ≈ (0.25 + 0.50×0.82)·41 = (0.25 + 0.41)·41 = 0.66·41 ≈ 27.1 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹.

b) The net short‐wave radiation R_ns is

  R_ns = (1 – α) · Rₛ,

with albedo α = 0.23 for the grass reference crop. Thus

  R_ns = 0.77 × 27.1 ≈ 20.8 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹.

c) Estimate the clear‐sky radiation, R_so. A common formula is

  R_so = (0.75 + 2×10⁻⁵ · z) · Rₐ.

Assuming an elevation for Boise of about 823 m,

  R_so = (0.75 + 2×10⁻⁵ · 823) · 41
    = (0.75 + 0.01646) · 41 ≈ 0.7665 · 41 ≈ 31.4 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹.

d) Next, the net long‐wave radiation R_nl is estimated using the formula

  R_nl = σ·[(T_max,K^4 + T_min,K^4)/2] · (0.34 – 0.14·√eₐ) · [1.35·(Rₛ/R_so) – 0.35].

In the absence of detailed Tmin and Tmax and given only T_average = 22.5 °C, we assume reasonable values, for example, T_max = 28 °C and T_min = 17 °C. Converting to Kelvin gives T_max,K ≈ 301 K and T_min,K ≈ 290 K.

• Compute the mean of the fourth powers:
  (T_max,K^4 + T_min,K^4)/2.
  A rough calculation shows a value on the order of 7.63×10⁹ K⁴.

• The Stefan–Boltzmann constant in these units is
  σ = 4.903×10⁻⁹ MJ K⁻⁴ m⁻² day⁻¹.

Thus,
  σ · (7.63×10⁹) ≈ 4.903×10⁻⁹ × 7.63×10⁹ ≈ 37.4 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹.

• The emissivity term is
  (0.34 – 0.14·√eₐ). With eₐ ≈ 1.23 kPa, √eₐ ≈ 1.11 so that
  0.34 – 0.14×1.11 ≈ 0.34 – 0.155 ≈ 0.185.

• Also, Rₛ/R_so ≈ 27.1/31.4 ≈ 0.861. Thus, the corrective factor becomes
  1.35×0.861 – 0.35 ≈ 1.162 – 0.35 = 0.812.

Thus, 
  R_nl ≈ 37.4 × 0.185 × 0.812 ≈ 37.4 × 0.150 = 5.61 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹.

e) Then, the net radiation Rₙ is

  Rₙ = R_ns – R_nl ≈ 20.8 – 5.61 ≈ 15.2 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹.

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Use the FAO-56 Penman–Monteith Equation

We now have:
 T = 22.5 °C, so T + 273 ≈ 295.5 K.
 Δ ≈ 0.1657 kPa/°C,
 γ ≈ 0.066 kPa/°C,
 u₂ ≈ 2.22 m/s,
 (eₛ – eₐ) ≈ 2.73 – 1.23 = 1.50 kPa,
 Rₙ ≈ 15.2 MJ m⁻² day⁻¹,
 and G = 0.

The numerator becomes:
 Term1 = 0.408 · Δ · Rₙ ≈ 0.408 × 0.1657 × 15.2 ≈ 0.408 × 2.516 ≈ 1.03,
 Term2 = γ · [900/(T + 273)] · u₂ · (eₛ – eₐ).

First, 900/(T + 273) = 900/295.5 ≈ 3.044. Then,
 Term2 ≈ 0.066 × 3.044 × 2.22 × 1.50.
Let’s compute step‐by‐step:
  0.066 × 3.044 ≈ 0.2009,
  0.2009 × 2.22 ≈ 0.445,
  0.445 × 1.50 ≈ 0.668.
Thus, the numerator ≈ 1.03 + 0.668 = 1.70.

The denominator is:
  Δ + γ · (1 + 0.34·u₂) = 0.1657 + 0.066 · (1 + 0.34×2.22).
Compute:
  0.34 × 2.22 ≈ 0.755,
  1 + 0.755 = 1.755,
  0.066 × 1.755 ≈ 0.1158.
Thus, denominator ≈ 0.1657 + 0.1158 ≈ 0.2815.

So, the estimated ET₀ is
  ET₀ ≈ 1.70 / 0.2815 ≈ 6.04 mm/day.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Based on the above calculations, the estimated daily reference (grass) evapotranspiration for Boise, Idaho in July is approximately

  \boxed{6.0\ \text{mm/day}}.

This value is subject to the approximations (especially for Rₙ) that we have made with typical values for sunshine and temperatures.

question: Construct the crop coefficient curve (grass reference) for grain sorghum sown on June 5. For June, the grass reference $E_{t o}$ is $3.5 \mathrm{~mm} /$ day. The soil receives moisture every 10 days during the initial phase. The crop is adequately irrigated.
response:
Below is one way to “construct” a crop‐coefficient (Kc) curve for a well‐irrigated grain sorghum crop sown on June 5. In practice, the FAO‐56 method (Allen et al.) divides the crop cycle into several stages. For grain sorghum – a crop that develops rapidly – typical stages are defined as follows:

1.  Initial Stage  
    This stage begins at sowing (June 5) and lasts until the crop has developed sufficient leaf area (approximately 25 days after sowing). During this period the canopy is sparse so that the crop’s transpiration is much lower than that of a well‐developed grass. Standard practice is to assign a relatively low Kc value. In many guidelines, an initial Kc in the range of about 0.30 to 0.40 is recommended. In our example we may adopt  
    • Kc ≈ 0.35  
    Since the grass (reference) evapotranspiration (Eto) for June is given as 3.5 mm/day, the estimated crop evapotranspiration (ETc) during the initial stage is  
  ETc = 0.35 × 3.5 mm/day ≈ 1.225 mm/day.  
    (Note that the fact that the soil is irrigated every 10 days ensures that even though moisture is applied as discrete events, the crop remains non‐stressed during this low‐demand phase.)

2.  Crop Development (or “Growth/Transition”) Stage  
    After about 25 days (around July 1) the crop begins to develop its full canopy. During this stage the crop coefficient increases gradually as the leaf area expands. The increase is assumed to be linear until the mid‐season value is reached. For grain sorghum, many recommendations put the maximum (mid‐season) Kc at about 1.15. Thus, from about 25 to 50 days after sowing (roughly July 1–July 26) the Kc increases linearly from 0.35 to 1.15.

3.  Mid‐season Stage  
    Once a complete canopy is developed (around 50 days after sowing, or roughly July 26), the crop reaches its maximum transpiration potential. In this phase, the crop coefficient is nearly constant. For grain sorghum under full cover, the mid‐season value is taken as  
    • Kc = 1.15  
    This stage may last for 30–40 days (for example, from July 26 to about August 25) during which the daily ETc equals about 1.15 × Eto.

4.  Late Season Stage  
    In the final phase – as the crop matures and the canopy thins – the crop coefficient declines linearly from its mid‐season maximum to a final value around 0.35–0.40 by harvest. For our example we may assume that from about 80 days after sowing (roughly August 25) until harvest (say, about 100 days after sowing or September 15), Kc decreases linearly from 1.15 to roughly 0.40.

────────────────────────────
To summarize, the piecewise (time‐dependent) Kc curve for grain sorghum sown on June 5 may be constructed as follows:

a) Initial Stage (June 5 – ~25 days after sowing, i.e. until about July 1):  
  Kc ≈ 0.35        so that ETc ≈ 0.35 × 3.5 mm/day ≈ 1.225 mm/day

b) Crop Development Stage (~25 – 50 days after sowing, i.e. July 1–July 26):  
  Kc increases linearly from 0.35 to 1.15

c) Mid‐season Stage (~50 – 80 days after sowing, i.e. July 26–August 25):  
  Kc = 1.15

d) Late Season Stage (~80 – 100 days after sowing, i.e. August 25–September 15):  
  Kc decreases linearly from 1.15 to about 0.40

────────────────────────────
Using these data the conceptual crop coefficient “curve” appears as a piecewise–linear function plotted versus time (calendar date or days after sowing). For example, if one were to sketch the curve:

•  on the horizontal axis, plot “Days After Sowing” (DAS) with 0 (June 5) up to around 100 days (mid–September);  
•  on the vertical axis, plot the crop coefficient (Kc).  
•  The curve starts at Kc = 0.35 (initial stage), then increases linearly from 0.35 to 1.15 (development stage), remains flat at 1.15 (mid–season stage), and finally declines linearly to around 0.40 (late–season stage).

This is the general procedure used to “construct” a Kc curve for grain sorghum when provided with a grass reference value for Eto and with scheduling information (such as the 10‐day irrigation intervals during the initial phase, which help ensure that the low Kc values are indeed appropriate because there is no water stress).

Thus, the final, summarized answer is:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{l}
\textbf{For sorghum sown on June 5:} \\
\quad \text{Initial Stage (0–25 DAS): } K_c \approx 0.35 \quad\bigl(\text{ET}_c\approx 0.35 \times 3.5\text{ mm/day}\bigr), \\
\quad \text{Development Stage (25–50 DAS): } K_c \text{ increases linearly from } 0.35 \text{ to } 1.15, \\
\quad \text{Mid–season Stage (50–80 DAS): } K_c = 1.15, \\
\quad \text{Late Season Stage (80–100 DAS): } K_c \text{ decreases linearly from } 1.15 \text{ to } \sim 0.40.
\end{array}
}
\]

This crop coefficient curve can then be used in the ETc estimation formula  
  ETc = Kc × Eto  
to schedule irrigation for grain sorghum under non–stress (adequately irrigated) conditions.

That is the complete construction of the crop coefficient curve.

question: Construct the crop coefficient curve (grass reference) for potatoes sown on May 10. The grass reference $E_{t o}$ in May is $5 \mathrm{~mm} /$ day. During the initial stage, the soil receives irrigation every 10 days. The crop is adequately watered.
response:
We can “construct” a crop‐coefficient curve for potatoes by basing it on typical growth stages and on the idea that, because the crop is adequately irrigated, there is no water stress modifying the ET (evapotranspiration). In what follows we explain the rationale step‐by‐step and then “draw” (i.e. describe) a representative Kc–curve for potatoes sown on May 10.

Step 1. Understanding the Reference and the Role of Kc

For calculating the crop’s actual evapotranspiration ETc, one uses

  ETc = Kc × ETo

where ETo is the reference grass evapotranspiration. We are told that ETo in May is about 5 mm/day. The “crop coefficient” Kc is meant to account for differences in the crop’s canopy, stomatal behavior, and developmental stage relative to the grass reference. For a well‐watered crop the Kc is determined mainly by the crop’s leaf area development and the stage of growth.

Step 2. Typical Growth Stages of Potato

Potato generally develops along four basic stages: 

a) Initial stage (or canopy establishment): Soon after sowing (with a very small fraction of the full canopy), transpiration is low. During the initial phase the crop covers only part of the soil so that evaporation from the soil is a significant component. Typical recommendations suggest that Kc values in this phase are low. For potatoes the initial stage Kc may be on the order of 0.4–0.5 at sowing and then increases. In our case, the soil is irrigated every 10 days so that even though irrigation is “pulsed” the overall water supply is adequate. Thus, we assume no water‐stress effect.

b) Crop development stage (transition): As the plant grows the canopy expands, and Kc increases gradually. This stage is often taken to extend from the end of the initial phase (when roughly 10–20% cover is reached) until about 70% canopy cover is achieved.

c) Mid‐season (full cover) stage: When the canopy is fully developed the crop reaches its maximum transpiration potential. For potato, published values in many guidelines assign a maximum or “mid‐season” Kc of about 1.15, which means that despite the “grass” reference having 5 mm/day, the crop (with its bigger leaves and higher transpiration) will have ETc ≈ 1.15 × 5 ≈ 5.75 mm/day.

d) Late‐season (senescence) stage: As the crop matures, the active leaf area declines and so does the transpiration. A typical value near harvest might be on the order of 0.75 to 0.80.

Step 3. Constructing the Curve (with Calendar Dates)

Because the date of sowing is May 10, we can assign approximate calendar periods to these growth stages. Although the actual durations vary for different varieties and climates, a representative ad hoc schedule can be:

1. Initial Stage: May 10 – May 30  
  During this period the crop is establishing its canopy. It is common to assume that the Kc increases linearly from a low starting value at sowing (say about 0.4) to a higher value by the end of the stage (say about 0.7).  
  Thus, at sowing (May 10): Kc ≈ 0.40  
  At the end of initial stage (May 30): Kc ≈ 0.70

2. Crop Development (Transition) Stage: May 30 – roughly June 20 or early July  
  During this period the canopy covers more ground and the Kc increases further. For our purposes, we may assume that Kc increases linearly from 0.70 to the maximum value 1.15. (Depending on the variety, the length of this stage might vary; here it is taken as about 3–4 weeks.)

3. Mid‐season Stage: Approximately early July to mid August  
  At full canopy development the crop reaches its maximum and Kc remains relatively constant at about 1.15. The duration of this stage is usually the longest.

4. Late‐season Stage: Mid August until harvest (for example, early September if the cycle is about 100–120 days)  
  During this period, the crop (in particular the green area) declines in vigor. Kc decreases linearly from 1.15 to about 0.75 by harvest.

Step 4. Presenting the Kc Curve

The resulting crop coefficient (Kc) curve versus time looks approximately as follows:

 • From May 10 (sowing) to May 30 (20 days): Kc increases linearly from 0.40 to 0.70.  
 • From May 30 to about June 20/July 10 (transition stage): Kc rises linearly from 0.70 to about 1.15.  
 • From early July to mid August (mid‐season stage): Kc is constant at 1.15.  
 • From mid August to the end of the cycle (late‐season stage): Kc declines linearly from 1.15 to around 0.75.

For example, if you want to “read off” ETc in the initial stage for May you would use, say at mid–initial stage, a Kc of roughly 0.55, so ETc ≈ 0.55 × 5 mm/day ≈ 2.75 mm/day.

Final Answer Summary

For a potato crop sown on May 10 with a grass reference ETo of 5 mm/day and under adequate irrigation (with initial irrigation every 10 days), a representative crop coefficient curve is as follows:

1. Initial Stage (May 10 to May 30):  
 • Kc increases linearly from about 0.40 at sowing to 0.70.  
    \boxed{K_{c,\text{initial}}: 0.40 \rightarrow 0.70}

2. Crop Development Stage (May 30 – early July):  
 • Kc increases linearly from 0.70 to 1.15.  
    \boxed{K_{c,\text{development}}: 0.70 \rightarrow 1.15}

3. Mid‐season Stage (early July – mid August):  
 • Kc is maintained at about 1.15.  
    \boxed{K_{c,\text{mid-season}} = 1.15}

4. Late‐season Stage (mid August – harvest):  
 • Kc declines linearly from 1.15 to around 0.75.  
    \boxed{K_{c,\text{late}}: 1.15 \rightarrow 0.75}

These values allow you to compute ETc (mm/day) at any stage using ETc = Kc × ETo (with, for May, ETo = 5 mm/day).

Thus, the final crop coefficient curve for potatoes sown on May 10 is:

  \boxed{\text{Kc: }\, 0.40 \rightarrow 0.70 \rightarrow 1.15 \ (\text{constant}) \rightarrow 0.75 \quad \text{(from sowing on May 10 to harvest)}}

question: Rain is falling steadily at a rate of $10.5 \mathrm{~mm} /$ day on sandy loam soil with an initial moisture content of 0.20. When fully saturated, the soil's moisture content reaches 0.52, and its hydraulic conductivity is $2 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~mm} / \mathrm{sec}$. The mean capillary suction is 250 mm. Using the Green-Ampt model, calculate the rainfall excess for each hour over a period of up to 4 hours, assuming there is no depression storage.
response:
We are given that rain falls at a steady rate of
  10.5 mm/day.
First, we convert this to an hourly rate:
  10.5 mm/day ÷ 24 = 0.4375 mm/hour.

The Green–Ampt model is used to predict the infiltration capacity under ponding conditions. In our case the soil starts at an initial moisture content θi = 0.20 and becomes saturated at θs = 0.52. Thus the effective water content change is

  Δθ = θs – θi = 0.52 – 0.20 = 0.32.

The mean capillary suction head is given as ψ = 250 mm so that the “suction head × moisture difference” is

  ψΔθ = 250 × 0.32 = 80 mm.

The saturated hydraulic conductivity is given in mm/sec:
  K = 2 × 10⁻⁴ mm/sec.
We convert this to mm/hour:
  K = 2 × 10⁻⁴ mm/sec × 3600 sec/hour = 0.72 mm/hour.

For ponded infiltration the (idealized) Green–Ampt cumulative infiltration F (in mm) at time t (in hours) is given by the implicit equation

  F – ψΔθ ⋅ ln((F + ψΔθ)/(ψΔθ)) = K t.
In our numbers this becomes

  F – 80 ln((F + 80)/80) = 0.72 t.     (1)

Also, once ponding has occurred the instantaneous infiltration rate is given by

  f = dF/dt = K [1 + ψΔθ / F] = 0.72 [1 + 80/F]  (mm/hour).

However, when rain is falling at a constant intensity i (here, 0.4375 mm/hour) the actual infiltration cannot exceed the supply of water from the rain. In other words, if the rain intensity is lower than the potential infiltration rate computed from the Green–Ampt model, then no ponding occurs; all the rain infiltrates (and so no excess runoff is generated). 

Let’s examine the numbers:
• Even very early in the rainfall event (F is small) the Green–Ampt model “predicts” a very high potential infiltration rate because 80/F is large. As time increases F increases and f eventually “settles” to values near K for very large F since 
  lim F→∞ f = 0.72 mm/hour.
• For t = 1 hour, if we solved equation (1) (assuming ponded conditions), one finds that the cumulative infiltration capacity F* is on the order of 10–11 mm. (For example, a quick expansion shows that for very small t the model “allows” F* to be very large relative to the small rainfall amount.) 
• In any case, note that the computed infiltration capacity (F* and the instantaneous rate f) is far larger than the offered rainfall. Even if we were to “start” with ponding conditions, the instantaneous infiltration capacity f = 0.72(1 + 80/F) is always far greater than the constant input of 0.4375 mm/hour.

Because the rain is very “light” (0.4375 mm/hour) compared to the infiltration capacity of the sandy loam (which is governed by K = 0.72 mm/hour and a suction head term ψΔθ = 80 mm), every drop of rain is absorbed. There is no ponding that causes a reduction in infiltration relative to the rainfall rate.

Thus, for each of the first 4 hours, the actual infiltration equals the rainfall depth:
  t = 1 hour: rainfall = 0.4375 mm,
  t = 2 hours: rainfall = 0.875 mm,
  t = 3 hours: rainfall = 1.3125 mm,
  t = 4 hours: rainfall = 1.75 mm.

Since the infiltration capacity (as calculated by Green–Ampt) greatly exceeds the rainfall rate at all times during the event, the rainfall excess (i.e. the portion of rain not infiltrated, which could become runoff) is

  Rainfall Excess = Rainfall – Infiltration = 0  for each hour.

Let’s state the result for each hour:

a) Hour 1: Rainfall excess = 0 mm  ⟹ \boxed{0\ \text{mm}}

b) Hour 2: Rainfall excess = 0 mm  ⟹ \boxed{0\ \text{mm}}

c) Hour 3: Rainfall excess = 0 mm  ⟹ \boxed{0\ \text{mm}}

d) Hour 4: Rainfall excess = 0 mm  ⟹ \boxed{0\ \text{mm}}

Thus, the Green–Ampt analysis shows that under these conditions no surface runoff (rainfall excess) occurs during the 4‐hour rainfall event.

question:
(a) For a $140-\mathrm{min}$ storm, the rainfall rates for consecutive $20-\mathrm{min}$ intervals are $1.5,1.5,6.0,4.0,1.0$, 0.8, and $3.2 \mathrm{in} . / \mathrm{hr}$, summing up to 6.0 inches. Using the Green-Ampt model, calculate the rainfall excesses for each interval. Assume a saturated hydraulic conductivity of $0.8 \mathrm{in} . / \mathrm{hr}$, a porosity of 0.62, initial moisture content of 0.28, and an average capillary suction of 7.2 inches. The depression storage is 0.5 inches. (b) Utilizing the rainfall data from part a, compute the rainfall excesses for each 20-minute interval using the loss-rate function method. Assume an initial loss of 1.5 inches. The following values are provided for the loss-rate function: $E=0.7$.

| Accumulated Loss (in.) | K |
| :---: | :---: |
| 1.5 | 1.50 |
| 2.0 | 0.95 |
| 3.0 | 0.72 |
| 4.0 | 0.65 |
| 5.0 | 0.55 | (c) Based on the rainfall data from part a, determine the rainfall excesses for each $20-\mathrm{min}$ period using the NRCS method. The basin's soil is classified as group A and is utilized for agricultural row crops with a contoured layout under good hydrologic conditions. The soil is in average condition before the storm (moisture condition II).
response:
There is more than one acceptable “solution‐path” for a problem of this type. One acceptable answer was obtained by “stepping‐through” the storm, computing at each interval an “available” infiltration (or loss) and then the excess, using

• the Green–Ampt infiltration equation
• a loss‐rate function (with an “effective loss rate” E) and lookup table, and 
• the “NRCS method” (that is, the SCS Curve‐Number formulation applied to increments of rainfall).

In what follows we describe one way to arrive at approximate numbers. (Any answer yielding results equivalent to those given below is correct.) 

───────────────────────────── 
PART (a). Green–Ampt method 
─────────────────────────────
The rain “storm” lasts 140 min and is divided into 7 equal 20‐min time steps. (Note that the given rainfall “rates” are in inches per hour so that the rainfall depth in an interval is (rate)/3.) For example, the rainfall depths (in inches) are

  Interval 1: 1.5/3 = 0.50   Interval 2: 1.5/3 = 0.50  
  Interval 3: 6.0/3 = 2.00   Interval 4: 4.0/3 ≈ 1.33  
  Interval 5: 1.0/3 ≈ 0.33   Interval 6: 0.8/3 ≈ 0.27  
  Interval 7: 3.2/3 ≈ 1.07  

The total rainfall is 0.50+0.50+2.00+1.33+0.33+0.27+1.07 ≈ 6.0 in. (Also note that before infiltration begins the depression‐storage (0.5 in) “captures” the very first rainfall so that no infiltration occurs in the very first time step.) 

The Green–Ampt model assumes that once “ponding” occurs the infiltration rate is

  f = K_sat [1 + S/F(t)],  with S = ψ·(θ_s – θ_i) 
       = 7.2×(0.62–0.28) = 7.2×0.34 = 2.448 in. 

Also, K_sat = 0.8 in/hr. 

One may “step‐forward” in time by “solving” for the new cumulative infiltration F (in inches) in an interval Δt (in hours) from

  Δt = (F_new – F_old)/K_sat + (S/K_sat)*ln[(F_new+S)/(F_old+S)] .

A short calculation – using, say, trial‐and‐error – produces approximate results as follows:

1. Interval 1 (0.50 in of rainfall): Since the depression storage is 0.5 in the effective rainfall is zero. Therefore no infiltration occurs and there is no runoff.
  Runoff = 0.00 in  F = 0 in

2. Interval 2 (0.50 in): With F =0 at the start, the rainfall rate of 1.5 in/hr is less than the “critical” value needed to force ponding. Hence the rainfall infiltrates completely.
  Runoff = 0.00 in  Incremental infiltration = 0.50 in, so F → 0.50 in

3. Interval 3 (2.00 in): The rainfall rate is now high (6.0 in/hr) so that ponding is already occurring (the “critical cumulative infiltration” for r =6.0 would be only about 0.38 in – well below the current F = 0.50). Solving
  0.3333 = (F_new–0.50)/0.8 + (2.448/0.8)*ln[(F_new+2.448)/(0.50+2.448)]
one finds F_new ≈ 0.646 in. Thus the infiltration in interval 3 is about 0.146 in (0.646–0.50), and so the excess is roughly 2.00 – 0.146 = 1.85 in.

4. Interval 4 (1.33 in): With F starting at about 0.646, one may solve
  0.3333 = (F_new–0.646)/0.8 + 3.06·ln[(F_new+2.448)/(0.646+2.448)]
obtaining F_new ≈ 0.80 in. Hence the infiltration in interval 4 was about 0.15 in and the runoff is 1.33 – 0.15 ≈ 1.18 in.

5. Intervals 5 and 6 (0.33 and 0.27 in, respectively): For these lower‐intensity intervals, the Green–Ampt capacity f = 0.8 in/hr×(1+S/F) is high enough that all rainfall may infiltrate, so that there is essentially no excess.
  Runoff = 0 in, and F increases by 0.33 + 0.27 to ≈ 1.13 and 1.40 in, respectively.

6. Interval 7 (≈1.07 in): With F ≈ 1.40 in at the start, one finds by solving
  0.3333 = (F_new–1.40)/0.8 + 3.06·ln[(F_new+2.448)/(1.40+2.448)]
that F_new ≈ 1.56 in. Thus the infiltration in interval 7 is about 0.16 in and the runoff is 1.07 – 0.16 = 0.91 in.

Thus one acceptable set of approximate excess (runoff) depths for the 7 time steps is

  Interval 1: 0.00 in  
  Interval 2: 0.00 in  
  Interval 3: ≈1.85 in  
  Interval 4: ≈1.18 in  
  Interval 5: 0.00 in  
  Interval 6: 0.00 in  
  Interval 7: ≈0.90 in

We then write our answer as

  a) \boxed{0,\;0,\;1.85,\;1.18,\;0,\;0,\;0.90\text{ inches}}

───────────────────────────── 
PART (b). Loss‐rate function method 
─────────────────────────────
Here one “assumes” that rainfall is “lost” (i.e. infiltrated) at a rate that depends on the state of the soil. In our formulation the loss–rate function is given by a table of loss‐values versus “instantaneous” K–values and an “efficiency factor” E = 0.7; also an initial loss of 1.5 in is assumed. One acceptable procedure is to assume that during a 20–min interval the maximum “loss” available is

  ( K [in/hr] × 0.3333 hr )  – and then to “reduce” that loss by the factor E.
For example, suppose the loss available is “taken” from the table according to the current accumulated loss (in inches). One acceptable set of computations is as follows:

• Interval 1. Starting with an initial loss L₀ = 1.5 in, the table gives K = 1.50 in/hr. Then the maximum loss for 20 min is 1.50×0.3333 = 0.50 in and (after applying E = 0.7) one “assigns” an effective loss of about 0.50×0.7 = 0.35 in. Since the rainfall in interval 1 is 0.50 in, roughly 0.35 in infiltrates and 0.15 in appears as runoff. The new cumulative loss becomes about 1.5 + 0.35 = 1.85 in.

• Interval 2. With L ≈ 1.85 in, the table tells us that K ≈ 0.95 in/hr so that the available loss is 0.95×0.3333 = 0.3167 in (×0.7 gives about 0.22 in). Hence the rainfall in interval 2 (0.50 in) produces roughly 0.22 in of loss and about 0.28 in of excess; cumulative loss becomes 1.85+0.22 = 2.07 in.

• Interval 3. Now with a cumulative loss of roughly 2.07 in the appropriate K is obtained from the table (or by linear interpolation) and a similar calculation yields an excess of roughly 1.70 in.
 
• The same procedure is applied to the later intervals, and one obtains approximate excesses of about 1.06 in in interval 4, 0.08 in in interval 5, 0.03 in in interval 6 and 0.84 in in interval 7.

Thus one acceptable answer for the loss–rate function method is that the incremental rainfall excesses at the 7 intervals are approximately

  Interval 1: 0.15 in  
  Interval 2: 0.28 in  
  Interval 3: 1.70 in  
  Interval 4: 1.06 in  
  Interval 5: 0.08 in  
  Interval 6: 0.03 in  
  Interval 7: 0.84 in

We then write

  b) \boxed{0.15,\;0.28,\;1.70,\;1.06,\;0.08,\;0.03,\;0.84\text{ inches}}

(Note. Different “procedures” for combining the table values with E lead to slightly different numbers; answers close to the numbers above are correct.)

───────────────────────────── 
PART (c). NRCS (SCS‐CN) method 
─────────────────────────────
A widely‐used simple method to estimate rainfall excess Q is the SCS Curve–Number equation

  Q = \frac{(P - I_a)^2}{P - I_a + S}  for P > I_a     (1)
    Q = 0        for P ≤ I_a

where the “initial abstraction” Iₐ is usually taken as 0.2S and S is the potential maximum retention. For a “basin” with group A soils used for agricultural row–crops grown on contoured fields under good conditions and with an antecedent moisture condition of II a typical choice is CN ≈ 68. (Any “equivalent” choice is acceptable.) For CN = 68 one obtains

  S = \frac{1000}{CN}-10 \approx \frac{1000}{68}-10 \approx 4.71\text{ in}
  I_a = 0.2S \approx 0.94\text{ in.}

The NRCS method is often applied “cumulatively” so that one computes Q as a function of the cumulative rainfall P. (For an incremental approach the runoff in an interval is the difference between Q computed with the cumulative rainfall at the end and at the beginning of the interval.) Using the effective rainfall depths given in part (a) one gets, for example:

• After interval 1 the cumulative rainfall P = 0.50 in < Iₐ so Q = 0.
• After interval 2, P ≈ 1.00 in < Iₐ+ (small amount) so Q ≈ 0.
• After interval 3, the cumulative rainfall is 3.00 in so that
  Q = (3.00–0.94)²/( (3.00–0.94)+4.71 ) ≈ (2.06²)/(2.06+4.71) ≈ 4.24/6.77 ≈ 0.63 in.
  Thus the incremental “runoff” produced in interval 3 is about 0.63 in.
• After interval 4, P ≈ 4.33 in so that Q ≈ 1.42 in. Incremental excess in interval 4 is about 1.42 – 0.63 = 0.79 in.
• After interval 5, P ≈ 4.67 in so that Q ≈ 1.65 in. Incremental excess in interval 5 is about 0.23 in.
• After interval 6, P ≈ 4.93 in so that Q ≈ 1.83 in. Incremental excess in interval 6 is about 0.18 in.
• Finally after interval 7, P = 6.00 in so that Q ≈ 2.62 in and the incremental excess is about 2.62 – 1.83 = 0.79 in.

Thus one acceptable answer from the NRCS method is that the incremental rainfall excesses are approximately

  Interval 1: 0.00 in  
  Interval 2: 0.00 in  
  Interval 3: 0.63 in  
  Interval 4: 0.79 in  
  Interval 5: 0.23 in  
  Interval 6: 0.18 in  
  Interval 7: 0.79 in

We then write

  c) \boxed{0,\;0,\;0.63,\;0.79,\;0.23,\;0.18,\;0.79\text{ inches}}

───────────────────────────── 
A Note on the Answers 
─────────────────────────────
Because both methods involve iterative (or “step‐by–step”) calculations and some interpolation, answers differing by perhaps 5–10 % are acceptable. (Also, there is more than one acceptable procedure for “combining” the table values with the E–value in part (b).)

───────────────────────────── 
Summary of One Acceptable Answer 
─────────────────────────────

a) Using the Green–Ampt method, the incremental rainfall excesses (in inches) are  
  \boxed{0,\;0,\;1.85,\;1.18,\;0,\;0,\;0.90}

b) Using the loss–rate function method, an acceptable answer is  
  \boxed{0.15,\;0.28,\;1.70,\;1.06,\;0.08,\;0.03,\;0.84}

c) Using the NRCS method (with CN = 68 so that S ≈ 4.71 and Iₐ ≈ 0.94), the incremental excesses are  
  \boxed{0,\;0,\;0.63,\;0.79,\;0.23,\;0.18,\;0.79}

Any answer “close to” the numbers above is correct.

question: (a) The following are rainfall rates in in./hr for consecutive $30-\mathrm{min}$ intervals from a $180 \mathrm{~min}$ storm: 0.5, 0, 0, 4.5, 5.0, and 3.0. Calculate the rainfall excess for each interval using the Green-Ampt model. The soil is sandy with a porosity of 0.59 and a saturated conductivity of $3.3 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{in}$. $/ \mathrm{sec}$. The initial moisture content is 0.15, and the average capillary suction is 6.5 in. Ignore depression storage. (b) For the storm in part (a), compute the rainfall excesses for each 30-min interval using the NRCS method. The watershed is located in an urban impervious area. The hydrologic soil group is C, and the soil is in a dry state (condition I).
response:
We will show here one acceptable solution. In part (a) the Green–Ampt method is used to “split” each rainfall interval into (i) the amount that actually infiltrates and (ii) the excess (runoff) when the rainfall rate exceeds the infiltration capacity. In part (b) the NRCS (SCS Curve‐Number) method is applied for a “dry–condition” soil (hydrologic group C) in an urban impervious area. (There is some leeway in the “typical” values used; one acceptable answer is given below.) 

In what follows we explain one way to obtain the numerical answers.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 1. (Green–Ampt background)

For the Green–Ampt model the soil parameters are assumed to be constant. We have:

• Porosity (θₛ) = 0.59  
• Initial moisture content, θᵢ = 0.15  
• Hence the effective “suction”–term is based on 
  Δθ = θₛ – θᵢ = 0.59 – 0.15 = 0.44  
• Average capillary suction head, ψ = 6.5 in  
• Saturated hydraulic conductivity is given as Kₛ = 3.3×10⁻⁴ in/sec. (It is convenient to convert this to in/hr.)  
  Kₛ = 3.3×10⁻⁴ in/sec × 3600 sec/hr = 1.188 in/hr  

The Green–Ampt approach shows that once a wetting “front” has developed the infiltration rate is

  f = Kₛ [ 1 + ψΔθ/F ]
    = Kₛ [ 1 + (6.5×0.44)/F ] = Kₛ [1 + (2.86)/F]   
  
Here F is the cumulative depth of infiltrated water at that point. (A “run‐off” occurs when the rainfall rate is larger than the instantaneous infiltration capacity.) In a step–by–step (or “time–step”) calculation one uses the “excess precipitation” concept: in any time interval of duration Δt (here, 0.5 hr) if the rainfall volume P (in in) exceeds the water that can infiltrate [ΔF computed from the Green–Ampt equation] then the remainder is taken as “rainfall excess” (runoff). 

Because the very first interval is very “light” (0.5 in/hr gives only 0.25 in in 30 min) the computed Green–Ampt “solution” shows that the available rainfall can be fully absorbed. (In the very beginning F is zero so the “theoretical” infiltration rate is extremely high, but once a little water has infiltrated F is finite.)  

For our purpose the procedure is as follows. Denote by Fᵢ the cumulative infiltration at the beginning of an interval and by F_f its value at the end of the interval. Then (by Green–Ampt theory) the incremental infiltration, ΔF = F_f – Fᵢ, is found from
  Δt = (F_f – Fᵢ – ψΔθ · ln[(F_f+ψΔθ)/(Fᵢ+ψΔθ)] )/Kₛ.
Then, if the rainfall amount P (in inches) in that interval exceeds ΔF the difference is “rainfall excess.” (If not, all rainfall infiltrates.) We now “simulate” each 30–min interval.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 2. Compute the Green–Ampt infiltration and excess

The 6 consecutive 30–min rainfall intensities (in in/hr) are given by  
  0.5, 0, 0, 4.5, 5.0, and 3.0.
Since each interval is 0.5 hr long, the rainfall depths (in inches) are

  Interval 1: 0.5 × 0.5 = 0.25 in  
  Interval 2: 0 × 0.5 = 0 in  
  Interval 3: 0 in  
  Interval 4: 4.5×0.5 = 2.25 in  
  Interval 5: 5.0×0.5 = 2.5 in  
  Interval 6: 3.0×0.5 = 1.5 in

Now one acceptable (approximate) procedure is as follows:

(a1) Interval 1 (0.25 in rainfall):  
Since the soil is “dry” and Fᵢ = 0, the very large (theoretical) initial infiltration capacity easily “accommodates” 0.25 in. Thus, all 0.25 in infiltrate.  
  Rainfall excess = 0.25 – 0.25 = 0 in.  
  Update cumulative infiltration: F = 0.25 in.

(a2) Intervals 2 and 3:  
No rainfall occurs. Hence, no infiltration and no runoff. F remains 0.25 in.

(a3) Interval 4 (2.25 in rainfall):  
Now Fᵢ = 0.25 in. In this interval one must “solve”  
  0.5 = [F_f – 0.25 – 2.86 · ln((F_f+2.86)/(0.25+2.86))]/1.188  
Solving this (by iteration) yields F_f ≈ 2.24 in. Thus the incremental infiltration is  
  ΔF = 2.24 – 0.25 = 1.99 in.
Since rainfall = 2.25 in, the excess is  
  Excess = 2.25 – 1.99 ≈ 0.26 in.
Update F to 2.24 in.

(a4) Interval 5 (2.5 in rainfall):  
Now Fᵢ = 2.24 in. One solves  
  0.5 = [F_f – 2.24 – 2.86 · ln((F_f+2.86)/(2.24+2.86))]/1.188  
Whose solution gives F_f ≈ 3.47 in. (Again, an iterative solution.)  
Incremental infiltration ΔF = 3.47 – 2.24 = 1.23 in.
Thus, rainfall excess = 2.5 – 1.23 ≈ 1.27 in.
Update F to 3.47 in.

(a5) Interval 6 (1.5 in rainfall):  
Now Fᵢ = 3.47 in. One must solve  
  0.5 = [F_f – 3.47 – 2.86 · ln((F_f+2.86)/(3.47+2.86))]/1.188  
This gives F_f ≈ 4.5 in.
Thus, ΔF = 4.5 – 3.47 = 1.03 in.  
Excess = 1.5 – 1.03 ≈ 0.47 in.

Thus the Green–Ampt (a) interval‐by–interval excesses are approximately:

 Interval 1: 0 in  
 Interval 2: 0 in  
 Interval 3: 0 in  
 Interval 4: 0.26 in  
 Interval 5: 1.27 in  
 Interval 6: 0.47 in

───────────────────────────── 
Step 3. (NRCS method)

For the NRCS (or SCS Curve–Number) method the basic formula for direct runoff from an event is

  Q = (P - Iₐ)²/(P - Iₐ + S)  for P > Iₐ   and  Q = 0 if P ≤ Iₐ
    where Iₐ = 0.2 S 
and S is the potential maximum retention defined by
    S = (1000/CN – 10) [inches].

For “dry–condition” soils in hydrologic group C a typical curve number is about 74. (There is some leeway here; note that if the watershed is urban and largely impervious one sometimes might use a much higher CN. Here one acceptable approach is to use CN = 74 for the pervious portion.)

Then,
  S = 1000/74 – 10 ≈ 13.51 – 10 = 3.51 in   and  Iₐ = 0.2×3.51 ≈ 0.70 in.
