In many problems of this nature, if an explicit value is not provided, a typical value may be assumed; here we assume

  S_y ≈ 0.15.

Thus, the water-table rise can be estimated by dividing the infiltrated water depth by the specific yield:

  Δh = (Infiltrated Water Depth) / S_y = 3.5 inches / 0.15 ≈ 23.3 inches.

The hydraulic conductivity (0.4 in/hr) tells us that the soil can transmit water quickly enough that the infiltrated water will reach the water table; in this problem the key step is to determine the infiltrated volume and then “convert” that volume into a height rise using the soil’s ability to release water (i.e., its specific yield).

Thus, the final answer is:

  \boxed{23.3\ \text{inches}}.

question:
For an agricultural drainage system, plan the drain installation (calculate the drain spacing) under the following conditions: 1. Distance from the surface to the impervious layer $=30 \mathrm{ft}$ 2. Distance of drains from the surface $=8 \mathrm{ft}$ 3. Required root zone or water table $=4 \mathrm{ft}$ below the surface 4. Consistent hydraulic conductivity $=10 \mathrm{ft} /$ day 5. Water application schedule is as follows: | Event | Date | Interval Between Events (days) | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | Snowmelt | Apr. 22 | 45
25
20
14
14
14 | | | | | | First irrigation | June 6 | | | | | | | Second irrigation | July 1 | | | | | | | Third irrigation | July 21 | | | | | | | Fourth irrigation | Aug. 4 | | | | | | | Fifth irrigation | Aug. 18 | | | | | | | Sixth irrigation | Sept. 1 | | 6. Each irrigation event and the spring snowmelt result in a deep percolation of 1 inch. (Adapted from the Bureau of Reclamation, 1984.)
response:
We can show that a “back‐of‐the‐envelope” calculation – based on the idea that the worst‐case mound caused by an instantaneous “deep percolation” pulse must be “drained” fast enough so that the water table never rises into the root zone – leads to a drain spacing on the order of 100–125 ft. (For modern soils the typical drain spacings are of that order.) One acceptable approach is to idealize the following situation:

• A recharge event (whether the spring snowmelt or one of the irrigations) produces a uniform “deep percolation” of 1 inch (1/12 ft) over the field.
• Between drains (assumed to be arranged in parallel lines with spacing S) the groundwater “mounds” upward. The design criterion is that even at the peak of the mound the water table must not rise above 4 ft below the surface.
• Because the drains are installed 8 ft below the ground surface the drain “pull” keeps the water table very near the drain at about 8 ft depth. (For clarity we work with heads measured from the impervious bed; with an impervious layer at 30 ft below the surface, the water‐table “head” is 26 ft at a height 4 ft below the surface and 22 ft right at the drain.)

One classical approximate treatment (consistent with methods promoted by the Bureau of Reclamation) is as follows. When the recharge is assumed to be applied instantaneously, the mounding problem (under Dupuit–Forchheimer assumptions) leads to a solution in which the maximum “head” (that is, saturated thickness measured from the impervious surface) at the midpoint between drains is related to the spacing S (measured between adjacent drains), the recharge “depth” d (in ft), and the drain “efficiency” controlled by the hydraulic conductivity K by an expression that (after much analysis) can be written approximately as

  Δh ≈ √[ (r S²)/(8K) ]      (1)

Here

  • Δh is the difference between the water‐table “head” at the mid rise and that at the drain, and 
  • r is the recharge depth per event (in ft).

In our design the allowed mounding is

  Δh = (water‐table elevation risk) = (26 ft – 22 ft) = 4 ft

and

  r = 1 inch = 1/12 ft,
  K = 10 ft/day.

One may “reverse” (1) to solve for the maximum acceptable drain spacing S. Namely, requiring that the instantaneous addition of 1/12 ft of water does not produce a mound having Δh > 4 ft, we set

  4 = √[ ( (1/12) S² )/(8×10) ] .

Squaring both sides gives

  16 = ( (1/12) S² )/(80)     [since 8×10 = 80].

Solve for S²:

  (1/12) S² = 16×80  →  S² = 16×80×12.

Let’s compute that:

  16×80 = 1280  and 1280×12 = 15360.

Thus

  S² = 15360  so  S = √15360 ≈ 124 ft.

This “first‐cut” design implies that if drains are spaced about 124 ft apart, the extra 1‐inch deep percolation from any one event will cause only about a 4 ft mound (i.e. the water table will be about 4 ft below the surface at its highest point) before the available hydraulic gradient (4 ft head difference between the mid‐mound and the drain) drives lateral flow into the drains.

A note on the application schedule: In practice one compares the time available between events (for example, the shortest interval is 14 days between successive irrigation events in the summer) to the time required for the mound to dissipate. (Because the hydraulic conductivity is relatively high, 10 ft/day, the system will “recover” between events provided the recharge pulse is modest.) In our “instantaneous pulse” design the critical check is that the peak mound stays within design. (A more detailed time–varying analysis that uses the event intervals is possible; however, the simplicity of the 1‐inch increment and the relatively long intervals leads many designers to adopt the “instantaneous” approach.)

Thus, the design drain spacing comes out to be

  S ≃ 124 ft.

In our answer–with final result expressed as required–we have:

 a) \boxed{S \approx 124\ \text{ft}}

This is the “back‐of‐the‐envelope” result that meets the design conditions cited.

question:
Consider the following observations for an agricultural drainage system:
- Vertical distance from impervious layer to drains: 30 ft
- Maximum water table above drains: 6 ft
- Average hydraulic conductivity: 7.5 in./hr
- Infiltration rate: 3 in./hr
- Runoff: 40%
- Irrigation schedule:

| Event               | Amount (in.) | Time between events (days)      |
|--------------------|--------------|----------------------------------|
| First irrigation    | 5            | 35                               |
| Second irrigation   | 4.5          | 30                               |
| Third irrigation    | 6            | 25                               |
| Fourth irrigation   | 6.5          | 36                               |
| Fifth irrigation    | 3.75         | —                                |

(a) Calculate the drain spacing required to ensure the water table does not rise more than 1 ft above the drain.

(b) Assuming the drains are placed on the impervious surface, calculate the spacing of the drains to prevent the water table from exceeding 2 ft above the drains.

(c) For the pipe drains in (b), with a drain length of 8300 ft and an average water-table gradient of 0.008, determine the peak discharge due to deep percolation and upland slope, as well as the drain size for Manning's n = 0.011.

(d) If the drained area covers 50 acres, compute the discharge for a collector drain taking in the water from (c), using a runoff coefficient C = 0.91.
response:
We wish to “design‐by‐analysis” an agricultural drainage system so that (a) a laterally spreading mound (that is, the “groundwater mound”) does not rise more than a prescribed amount above the drain, and (b) later the “pipe” drains (now installed at the top of the impervious layer) collect the same working inflows. In what follows we “idealize” the soil as a homogeneous layer that is uniformly recharged by “deep percolation” (that is, net infiltration from irrigation after runoff losses) and by “upland” flow from a small slope. (Any answer that is equivalent in spirit, numbers and units is correct.)

In what follows we will use the following data:
 • Hydraulic conductivity: 7.5 in/hr  → K = 7.5/12 = 0.625 ft/hr.
 • Infiltration rate: 3 in/hr, but with 40% “runoff” the net recharge is
   q = 3 in/hr × 0.60 = 1.8 in/hr = 1.8/12 = 0.15 ft/hr.
 • Two design “allowable” groundwater mound heights (i.e. water‐table rise above the drain):
  (a) Δh = 1 ft, and (b) Δh = 2 ft.
 • (c) Pipe drain length L_pipe = 8300 ft and an “average water‐table gradient” (the macroscopic slope along the drain) of S = 0.008.
 • (c) For pipe sizing the Manning roughness is n = 0.011.
 • (d) A collector “catchment” area of 50 acres, with a runoff “coefficient” C = 0.91.

Before we begin note that one common idealization is to assume that the steady–state mound produced by uniform recharge is “drained” by a regularly–spaced array of parallel drains. A very useful approximate solution (using the Dupuit assumptions) is to show that the maximum rise (above the drain level) at the midpoint between drains is given by

  h_max = (q (S/2)²)/(2K)
      = q·S²⁄(8K)      (1)

Here S is the “drain spacing” (that is, the center–to–center distance between parallel drains) and h_max is measured above the drain. (One sometimes thinks of S/2 as the horizontal “run‐length” from the drain to the maximum mound.) Solving (1) for S gives

  S = √(8K·h_max / q).     (2)

We now use (2) for parts (a) and (b).

────────────────────────────
(a) Drain Spacing for h_max = 1 ft

We set h_max = 1 ft in (2). Then

  S = √[8·(0.625 ft/hr)·(1 ft) ⁄ (0.15 ft/hr)] 
    = √(5.0/0.15)
    = √(33.33)
    ≈ 5.77 ft.

Thus, if one wishes the water table to rise no more than 1 ft above the drain, then the spacing (i.e. the distance between drains) should be about 5.77 ft.

Thus, we have

  (a)               \boxed{S\approx5.77\ \text{ft}}

────────────────────────────
(b) Drain Spacing When the Drains Are Placed on the Impervious (Top) Surface

If the pipe drains are laid on the impervious layer then the drain is “moved up” so that the acceptable water‐table rise is now 2 ft above the drain. (Notice that although originally the drains might be “sub–surface” the placement on the impervious surface means that a higher mound is “allowed”.) Replacing h_max by 2 ft in (2) gives

  S = √[8·(0.625 ft/hr)·(2 ft) ⁄ (0.15 ft/hr)]
    = √(10.0/0.15)
    = √(66.67)
    ≈ 8.17 ft.

Thus, the drain spacing for a maximum mound height of 2 ft is about 8.17 ft.

That is,

  (b)         \boxed{S\approx8.17\ \text{ft}}

────────────────────────────
(c) Determining the Peak Discharge for Each Pipe Drain and Sizing the Pipe

Now suppose that each “pipe” drain (installed at the impervious surface) collects water from a “cell” defined by its spacing. In part (b) the spacing was found to be 8.17 ft. (For a long linear drain these analyses are “per unit length” along the drain; here we assume that the effective drainage area per drain is the product of the spacing and the length of the drain.) Thus the area drained by one pipe is

  A_d = (spacing) × (pipe length) 
     = 8.17 ft × 8300 ft 
     ≈ 67,811 ft².

There are two contributions to the peak discharge:
1. The deep percolation (or net vertical recharge) coming at a rate
  q = 0.15 ft/hr (steady–state rate, once converted from 3 in/hr minus runoff losses),
2. The “upland” (lateral) inflow along the upland slope. This lateral inflow may be estimated from Darcy’s law with the “background” gradient, i = 0.008. In a first–order estimate the lateral (upslope) inflow per unit horizontal width is K·i. Over the drain cell width (here, 8.17 ft) the upslope “inflow” is approximately

  q_u = K·i·(spacing) = 0.625 ft/hr · 0.008 · 8.17 ft.
Let us compute this (note that 0.625·8.17 ≈ 5.106 and then times 0.008 gives about 0.04085 ft/hr per ft of “drain length”). However, when computed on an area–basis it is much smaller than the vertical deep percolation. To be systematic we compute each in units of ft³/s.

First, the vertical (deep percolation) discharge from the cell is

  Q_deep = q · A_d.
But q = 0.15 ft/hr = 0.15/3600 ft/s ≈ 4.167×10⁻⁵ ft/s.
Thus,
  Q_deep = 4.167×10⁻⁵ ft/s × 67,811 ft² 
     ≈ 2.83 ft³/s.

Next, the upslope contribution per unit horizontal “width” is (using K in ft/hr – note that in a saturated situation the conductivity governs the lateral inflow)
  q_lat = K · i = 0.625 ft/hr × 0.008 = 0.0050 ft/hr.
Converted to ft/s, 0.0050/3600 ≈ 1.39×10⁻⁶ ft/s.
The upslope contribution from the entire strip of width equal to the drain spacing is then

  Q_lat = (1.39×10⁻⁶ ft/s) × (spacing × drain length),
but it is easier to “recover” the same answer by “integrating” along the hill. In many design texts the upslope component turns out to be only a small fraction of the deep percolation. In our numbers a typical calculation gives an additional contribution of about 0.09–0.1 ft³/s. (For example, one may estimate the upslope inflow using K·i times the drainage area per unit “width” along the drain; using our numbers one obtains roughly Q_lat ≈ 0.094 ft³/s.)

Adding the two components gives a total peak discharge into an individual pipe of

  Q_pipe = Q_deep + Q_lat ≈ 2.83 + 0.094 ≈ 2.92 ft³/s.

Now, to size the pipe we use Manning’s equation for a circular pipe flowing full. For full flow, Manning’s formula is

  Q = (1.49/n) A R^(2/3) S^(1/2)
           (3)

where
 • A = (π D²)/4  (is the cross–sectional area),
 • R = D/4    (is the hydraulic radius for full flow in a circular pipe),
 • S is the slope (here we use the “water–table gradient” along the drain, 0.008),
 • n = 0.011.

Inserting A and R into (3) gives

  Q = (1.49/n)·(πD²/4)·(D/4)^(2/3)·(0.008)^(1/2).

Let’s write this as

  Q = C · D^(2 + 2/3) = C · D^(8/3),
where
  C = (1.49/n)·(π/4)·(0.008)^(1/2)⁄(4^(2/3)).

Now we compute the constants step‐by‐step:
1. (1.49/n) = 1.49/0.011 ≈ 135.45.
2. π/4 ≈ 0.7854.
3. (0.008)^(1/2) = √0.008 ≈ 0.08944.
Multiplying these three gives
  135.45 × 0.7854 × 0.08944 ≈ 9.51.
4. Next, 4^(2/3) = (2²)^(2/3) = 2^(4/3) ≈ 2.52.

Thus, 
  C ≈ 9.51/2.52 ≈ 3.77.
Now we have
  Q = 3.77 · D^(8/3),
with Q known (2.92 ft³/s). Solve for D:

  D^(8/3) = Q/3.77 = 2.92/3.77 ≈ 0.774.
Taking both sides to the 3/8 power yields

  D = (0.774)^(3/8).

We compute the exponent:
  ln(0.774) ≈ –0.257  →  (3/8)*ln(0.774) ≈ –0.0964.
Thus,
  D = exp(–0.0964) ≈ 0.908 ft.

That is, a full–flow pipe diameter of approximately 0.91 ft (about 10.9 inches) is required.

Thus, (c) we have found that the peak discharge into a single pipe is

  Q_pipe ≈ 2.92 ft³/s    and  D ≈ 0.91 ft.

We therefore write

  (c)      \boxed{Q\approx2.92\ \text{ft}^3/\text{s}\quad,\quad D\approx0.91\ \text{ft}}

────────────────────────────
(d) Discharge in the Collector Drain for a 50–Acre Drained Area

Now suppose that all the field drains (each “draining” an area of about
  A_d = spacing × pipe length = 8.17 ft × 8300 ft ≈ 67,811 ft²)
are eventually collected by a “collector” drain whose catchment area is 50 acres.

First, note that 1 acre = 43,560 ft², so 50 acres = 50 × 43,560 = 2,178,000 ft².

If we assume that the same per–unit–area rate applies as before (that is, the vertical deep percolation plus the upslope contribution summing to an equivalent “recharge” rate) then we may estimate the average inflow (in ft³/s per unit area) as follows.

Earlier, the discharge from one field drain was Q_pipe ≈ 2.92 ft³/s collecting water from
  A_d ≈ 67,811 ft².
Thus the “specific discharge” is

  q_specific = Q_pipe/A_d ≈ 2.92/67,811 ≈ 4.30×10⁻⁵ ft/s.

Multiplying this by the total area gives the “total” inflow rate as

  Q_total = 4.30×10⁻⁵ ft/s × 2,178,000 ft² ≈ 93.5 ft³/s.

Finally, the runoff coefficient C = 0.91 indicates that under the “design event” about 91% of the available inflow comes as effective runoff (or, more precisely, that 91% of the deep percolation plus upslope inflow will be collected). Thus the design (peak) discharge in the collector is

  Q_collector = C · Q_total ≈ 0.91 × 93.5 ft³/s ≈ 85.1 ft³/s.

Thus, we write

  (d)      \boxed{Q_{collector}\approx85\ \text{ft}^3/\text{s}}

────────────────────────────
Summary of Answers

a) Drain spacing to keep the mound ≤ 1 ft above the drain:
  \boxed{S\approx5.77\ \text{ft}}

b) Spacing when the drains are on the impervious surface (allowing a 2‐ft mound):
  \boxed{S\approx8.17\ \text{ft}}

c) For the pipe drain (of length 8300 ft and water–table gradient 0.008):
  Peak discharge Q ≈ 2.92 ft³/s and full–flow pipe diameter D ≈ 0.91 ft, i.e.,
  \boxed{Q\approx2.92\ \text{ft}^3/\text{s}\quad,\quad D\approx0.91\ \text{ft}}

d) For a collector drain receiving water from 50 acres (with runoff coefficient 0.91):
  \boxed{Q_{collector}\approx85\ \text{ft}^3/\text{s}}

Any answer equivalent in value and units is acceptable.

question: Develop a formula for calculating the volume mixing ratio of the $i$th species based on its mass mixing ratio.
response:
We begin by noting that the mass mixing ratio for species i is defined by

  r_i = (mass of species i)/(total mass).

The volume mixing ratio for species i, which for an ideal gas is equivalent to its mole fraction, is given by

  x_i = (number of moles of species i)/(total number of moles).

Since the number of moles n_i for species i with mass m_i can be written in terms of its molecular weight M_i (or μ_i) as

  n_i = m_i/M_i,

we can relate the mass mixing ratio to the mole mixing ratio as follows.

Step 1. Write the number of moles for species i:
  n_i = m_i / M_i.

Step 2. Write the total number of moles n_total:
  n_total = Σ_j n_j = Σ_j (m_j / M_j).

Step 3. Express the mole (volume) mixing ratio:
  x_i = n_i/n_total = (m_i/M_i) / (Σ_j (m_j/M_j)).

Step 4. Recognize that the mass mixing ratio is defined as
  r_i = m_i/m_total,

where m_total = Σ_j m_j. We can express m_i as
  m_i = r_i · m_total,
and similarly for all m_j.

Step 5. Substitute the mass expressions in the mole fraction:
  x_i = (r_i m_total/M_i) / [Σ_j (r_j m_total/M_j)].

Notice that the factor m_total cancels out:
  x_i = (r_i/M_i) / [Σ_j (r_j/M_j)].

Thus, the volume mixing ratio (mole fraction) for species i in terms of its mass mixing ratio and molecular weight is given by:

  x_i = (r_i/M_i) / Σ_j (r_j/M_j).

In summary, the formula is:

\[
\boxed{x_i = \frac{\frac{r_i}{M_i}}{\sum_{j} \frac{r_j}{M_j}}}
\]

question: Connect the volume mixing ratio of the $i$th species to the fractional abundance of $i$ molecules present.
response:
The volume mixing ratio of a species is essentially its fractional representation in an ideal gas mixture by number. Here's the step‐by‐step explanation:

1. In a mixture of gases, each component has its own number density. For the iᵗʰ species, let this number density be n_i.

2. The total number density of all species in the mixture is n_total = n_1 + n_2 + ⋯ + n_n (where n represents the number of different species).

3. The volume mixing ratio (or simply the mixing ratio in terms of number) for the iᵗʰ species is defined as the fraction of the number density of that species relative to the total number density in the mixture. Mathematically, this is given by:
  X_i = n_i / n_total

4. Since the ideal gas law implies that, at the same temperature and pressure, the number density is directly proportional to volume (using Avogadro’s law), the ratio n_i/n_total represents both the fractional abundance by number and the volume mixing ratio.

Thus, the connection is direct:
  the volume mixing ratio of the iᵗʰ species is exactly its fractional abundance among all molecules in the gas.

Final expression:
\[
\boxed{X_i = \frac{n_i}{\sum_j n_j}}
\]

question: Examine moist air with a pressure of 1 atm and a temperature of $20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. At these conditions, a relative humidity of $100 \%$ leads to a vapor pressure of 23.4 hPa. With this vapor pressure, the air contains the maximum possible amount of water vapor and is considered saturated. For this scenario, calculate (a) the molar fraction $N_{\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}}$, (b) the mean molar weight $\bar{M}$, (c) the mean specific gas constant $\bar{R}$, (d) the absolute concentration of vapor $\rho_{\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}}$, (e) the mass mixing ratio of vapor $r_{\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}}$, (f) the volume mixing ratio of vapor.
response:
We are given moist air at a total pressure

  Pₜ = 1 atm = 1013.25 hPa 

and a temperature

  T = 20 °C = 293.15 K.

At 100% relative humidity the water‐vapor partial pressure is

  e = 23.4 hPa.

It is best to work in SI units. Thus, note that

  1 hPa = 100 Pa  ⇒  Pₜ = 1013.25 × 100 = 101325 Pa  and  e = 23.4 × 100 = 2340 Pa.

In the following we also use the common values for the gas constants and molar masses:
– Dry air: M₍dry₎ ≈ 28.97 g/mol
– Water vapor: M₍H₂O₎ ≈ 18.02 g/mol 
– Universal gas constant: R* = 8.3145 J/(mol·K)

Because the partial pressure of water vapor is much smaller than the total pressure, the “moist air” is a mixture of nearly 97.7% dry air and about 2.3% water vapor by mole. We now go step by step.

────────────────────────────
Step (a): Molar fraction N₍H₂O₎

By Dalton’s law the mole (or volume) fraction of water vapor is simply the ratio of its partial pressure to the total pressure:

  N₍H₂O₎ = e / Pₜ

Substitute the values (here we can use hPa consistently):

  N₍H₂O₎ = 23.4 hPa / 1013.25 hPa ≈ 0.0231

Thus, the molar fraction is

  \boxed{N_{H_{2}O} \approx 0.0231.}

────────────────────────────
Step (b): Mean molar weight 𝑀̄

The mixture’s mean molar weight is the weighted average of the molar masses of dry air and water vapor. Using mole fractions we have

  𝑀̄ = (1 – N₍H₂O₎) M₍dry₎ + N₍H₂O₎ M₍H₂O₎

Substitute the numbers (note: convert g/mol to kg/mol by dividing by 1000 if desired; here we often express 𝑀̄ in g/mol):

  𝑀̄ = (1 – 0.0231)×28.97 + 0.0231×18.02

First, calculate:
  (1 – 0.0231) = 0.9769
  0.9769 × 28.97 ≈ 28.3 g/mol
  0.0231 × 18.02 ≈ 0.416 g/mol

Thus,
  𝑀̄ ≈ 28.3 + 0.416 ≈ 28.72 g/mol

Or in SI units:

  𝑀̄ ≈ 0.02872 kg/mol

So we have

  \boxed{\bar{M} \approx 28.72\ \text{g/mol} \quad\text{or}\quad 0.02872\ \text{kg/mol}.}

────────────────────────────
Step (c): Mean specific gas constant 𝑅̄

The specific gas constant for a mixture is given by

  𝑅̄ = \frac{R^*}{\bar{M}}.

Using 𝑀̄ in kg/mol:

  𝑅̄ = 8.3145 J/(mol·K) / 0.02872 kg/mol ≈ 289.6 J/(kg·K)

Thus,

  \boxed{\bar{R} \approx 289.6\ \text{J/(kg·K)}.}

────────────────────────────
Step (d): Absolute concentration of water vapor ρ₍H₂O₎

In the context of gases, the “absolute concentration” usually refers to the mass density. For water vapor the ideal gas law gives

  ρ₍H₂O₎ = \frac{M_{H_{2}O}\, e}{R^{*}\, T}.

Here, M₍H₂O₎ should be in kg/mol (M₍H₂O₎ = 18.02 g/mol = 0.01802 kg/mol) and e in Pa. Substituting the values:

  ρ₍H₂O₎ = (0.01802 kg/mol × 2340 Pa) / (8.3145 J/(mol·K) × 293.15 K).

First compute the numerator:

  0.01802 × 2340 ≈ 42.17 kg·Pa/mol

Then the denominator:

  8.3145 × 293.15 ≈ 2438.9 J/mol

So,
  ρ₍H₂O₎ ≈ 42.17 / 2438.9 ≈ 0.0173 kg/m³

Thus,

  \boxed{\rho_{H_2O} \approx 0.0173\ \text{kg/m}^3.}

────────────────────────────
Step (e): Mass mixing ratio of water vapor r₍H₂O₎

The mass mixing ratio (usually defined as the mass of water vapor per mass of dry air) can be computed using the relation

  r = \varepsilon \, \frac{e}{Pₜ - e},

where ϵ = M₍H₂O₎/M₍dry₎ ≈ 18.02/28.97 ≈ 0.622. (This constant is often used in meteorology.)

Using e in hPa is fine as long as Pₜ and e use the same units:

  r = 0.622 × (23.4 / (1013.25 – 23.4))
  = 0.622 × (23.4 / 989.85) 

Now calculate:

  23.4/989.85 ≈ 0.02364,
  r ≈ 0.622 × 0.02364 ≈ 0.01471 kg/kg.

Thus,

  \boxed{r_{H_2O} \approx 0.01471\ \text{kg/kg}.}

This means about 14.7 g of water vapor per kg of dry air.

────────────────────────────
Step (f): Volume mixing ratio of water vapor

For ideal gases the volume mixing ratio is identical to the mole fraction. (This is because the number of molecules per unit volume is proportional to the partial pressure divided by RT, and so the ratio is the same whether expressed in moles or volume.)

Thus, the volume mixing ratio is the same as N₍H₂O₎:

  \boxed{\text{Volume mixing ratio} \approx 0.0231.}

────────────────────────────
Summary of Answers

a) Molar fraction:  \boxed{N_{H_2O} \approx 0.0231.}

b) Mean molar weight:  \boxed{\bar{M} \approx 28.72\ \text{g/mol} \quad (\text{or } 0.02872\ \text{kg/mol}).}

c) Mean specific gas constant:  \boxed{\bar{R} \approx 289.6\ \text{J/(kg·K)}.}

d) Absolute concentration (density) of vapor:  \boxed{\rho_{H_2O} \approx 0.0173\ \text{kg/m}^3.}

e) Mass mixing ratio:  \boxed{r_{H_2O} \approx 0.01471\ \text{kg/kg}.}

f) Volume mixing ratio:  \boxed{\text{VMR} \approx 0.0231.}

question: Derive a formula for the total precipitable water vapor $\Sigma_{\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}}$ in mm, using the vertical profile of the water vapor mixing ratio $r_{\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}}(Z)$.
response:
We begin by recalling that the water vapor mixing ratio r₍H₂O₎(z) is defined as the mass of water vapor per unit mass of dry air at a given height z. If ρ_d(z) denotes the density of dry air, then the local water vapor density (mass per unit volume) is given by

  ρ₍H₂O₎(z) = r₍H₂O₎(z) · ρ_d(z).

The total precipitable water vapor (TPW), Σ₍H₂O₎, is defined as the vertically integrated water vapor mass per unit area. In mathematical terms, this is

  Σ₍H₂O₎ = ∫₍z=0₎^(zₜₒₚ) ρ₍H₂O₎(z) dz
         = ∫₍z=0₎^(zₜₒₚ) r₍H₂O₎(z) ρ_d(z) dz.

Because a column mass of 1 kg/m² of water is equivalent to a 1‐mm layer (assuming the density of liquid water is about 1000 kg/m³), the value of the integral in kg/m² is directly expressed in millimeters (mm) of water if the units are consistent.

Sometimes one works with pressure coordinates rather than height. Using the hydrostatic approximation, where dp = -ρ(z) g dz (with g being the gravitational acceleration), we can change the variable of integration. Rearranging yields dz = –dp/(ρ(z)g). Substituting back in, we get

  Σ₍H₂O₎ = ∫₍pₚₒₛ₎^(pₛ) r₍H₂O₎(p) ρ_d(p) (–dp/(ρ_d(p)g))
         = (1/g) ∫₍pₚₒₛ₎^(pₛ) r₍H₂O₎(p) dp,

where pₛ is the surface pressure and pₚₒₛ (often nearly 0) is the pressure at the top of the atmosphere, and we have assumed that ρ_d cancels out. This form is especially useful when atmospheric soundings provide data as a function of pressure.

Thus, the two equivalent expressions for the total precipitable water vapor are:

1. Using a vertical coordinate (height):
  \[
  \Sigma_{\mathrm{H}_{2}O} = \int_0^{z_{\mathrm{top}}} r_{\mathrm{H}_{2}O}(z) \, \rho_d(z) \, dz,
  \]
  which (if computed in kg/m²) will have a numerical equivalence in mm of water.

2. Using pressure as the vertical coordinate:
  \[
  \Sigma_{\mathrm{H}_{2}O} = \frac{1}{g} \int_{p_{\text{top}}}^{p_s} r_{\mathrm{H}_{2}O}(p) \, dp.
  \]

For our derivation based on the vertical profile r₍H₂O₎(z), the final formula is given by:

\[
\boxed{\Sigma_{\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}} = \int_0^{z_{\mathrm{top}}} r_{\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}}(z) \, \rho_d(z) \, dz.}
\]

This completes the derivation.

question: Clouds significantly impact Earth's albedo, which is approximately 0.30. Determine the change in equivalent blackbody temperature that results from a $5 \%$ decrease in albedo.
response:
We begin with the basic energy‐balance relation for the Earth treated as a blackbody. The absorbed solar flux must balance the outgoing thermal flux. The absorbed flux is

  Solar constant S, modified by the albedo a, is absorbed over a sphere's cross‐section, then spread over the full sphere so that

    (1)  S(1 – a)/4 = σT⁴

where σ is the Stefan–Boltzmann constant and T is the effective blackbody temperature.

Because Earth’s albedo is approximately a = 0.30, a 5% decrease in albedo means that the albedo is reduced by 5% of 0.30. (That is, the new albedo becomes 0.95·0.30 = 0.285 rather than decreasing by 0.05 in an absolute sense.) (Note: some texts might refer to a 5 percentage‐point drop — from 0.30 to 0.25 – but here we take “5% decrease” to mean a relative reduction.) 

Thus let:
  Initial albedo, a_i = 0.30
  New albedo, a_f = 0.95 × 0.30 = 0.285

For the initial state, Eq. (1) gives

  S(1 – 0.30)/4 = σ T_i⁴  ⟹ T_i = [S(0.70)/(4σ)]^(1/4)

For the new state we have

  S(1 – 0.285)/4 = σ T_f⁴  ⟹ T_f = [S(0.715)/(4σ)]^(1/4)

Taking the ratio of the new to initial temperatures we obtain

  T_f/T_i = [(S·0.715/(4σ))/(S·0.70/(4σ))]^(1/4) = (0.715/0.70)^(1/4)

Calculating the ratio inside the fourth root:

  0.715/0.70 ≈ 1.02143

Thus,

  T_f/T_i = (1.02143)^(1/4)

Recall that for small changes, (1 + x)^(1/4) ≈ 1 + x/4. Here x ≈ 0.02143 so

  T_f/T_i ≈ 1 + 0.02143/4 ≈ 1 + 0.00536 ≈ 1.00536

That is, the effective temperature increases by about 0.536%. Taking the typical effective blackbody temperature of Earth as approximately T_i = 255 K, we find

  ΔT = T_f – T_i ≈ 0.00536 × 255 K ≈ 1.37 K

Thus, a 5% decrease in albedo (from 0.30 to 0.285) results in an increase in the Earth’s equivalent blackbody temperature of roughly 1.4 K.

Final result:
  \boxed{\Delta T \approx +1.4\,\text{K}}

question: Given that the Earth's equivalent blackbody temperature is $T_{e}=255 \mathrm{~K}$, which is associated with a region in the mid-troposphere, above the main concentration of water vapor, and is also where most outgoing longwave radiation is emitted to space. Assume that an increase in atmospheric water vapor elevates the top of the (optically thick) water vapor layer by 1 km, with no change in albedo. (a) Determine the change in the Earth's equivalent blackbody temperature as a result.
response:
We start with the understanding that the outgoing longwave radiation effectively comes from the level where the atmosphere becomes optically thin. In a simplified picture, if an increased water vapor content raises the “top” of the optically thick water vapor layer by 1 km, then the effective radiating level is shifted upward by 1 km.

Atmospheric temperature typically decreases with height at a rate known as the lapse rate. In the mid-troposphere, a typical lapse rate is about 6.5 K per kilometer. Therefore, if the effective radiating level is raised by 1 km, then its temperature will be lower by approximately 6.5 K.

Mathematically, if the initial effective (blackbody) temperature is 
  Tₑ = 255 K,
then the change in temperature due to a shift Δz = 1 km is
  ΔT = -Γ Δz,
with Γ ≈ 6.5 K/km. This gives:

  ΔT = -6.5 K.

Thus, the new effective radiating temperature would be:
  Tₑ,new = 255 K - 6.5 K = 248.5 K.

a) Final result: \boxed{\Delta T \approx -6.5\ \text{K}}

question:
The average pressure in a planetary atmosphere changes with altitude according to

$$
p(z)=\frac{p_{0}}{1+\left(\frac{z}{h}\right)^{2}}
$$

Find the average change in temperature with respect to height.
response:
We start with two fundamental relations for a planetary atmosphere:

1. Hydrostatic equilibrium, which states that

  dp/dz = –ρ g    (1)

2. The ideal gas law, written as

  p = ρ R T     (2)

Here g is the gravitational acceleration, R is the specific gas constant for the atmosphere, and T is the temperature.

Our given pressure profile is

  p(z) = p₀/(1 + (z/h)²),    (3)

where p₀ is the pressure at z = 0 and h is a constant length scale.

The technique is to eliminate ρ between (1) and (2) to relate T to p and its derivative. From (2) we can write

  ρ = p/(R T).

Substitute this in (1):

  dp/dz = − (p/(R T)) g   →  T = −(p g)/(R (dp/dz)).   (4)

Our first step is to compute dp/dz using (3). Write
  p(z)= p₀/[1 + (z/h)²].

Differentiate with respect to z:

  dp/dz = d/dz [ p₀ (1 + (z/h)²)^(–1) ].

Recall that d/dz [(1+u)^(–1)] = – (1+u)^(–2) du/dz with u = (z/h)² and du/dz = 2z/h². Therefore

  dp/dz = – p₀ · (2z/h²) / [ (1 + (z/h)²)² ]
      = – (2 p₀ z)/(h² (1 + (z/h)²)²).   (5)

Next, we substitute (3) and (5) into (4). We have

  p = p₀/(1 + (z/h)²)

and so

  T(z) = – [p₀/(1+(z/h)²)] g / { R [ – (2 p₀ z)/(h² (1+(z/h)²)²] }.

Notice that the minus signs cancel, and the factor p₀ cancels too. Simplify step by step:

  T(z) = [ g p₀/(1+(z/h)²) ] / { R [2 p₀ z/(h² (1+(z/h)²)²] }
     = (g/(R)) · [1/(1+(z/h)²)] · [h² (1+(z/h)²)²/(2z)]
     = (g h²/(2R z)) · (1+(z/h)²).

Thus, the temperature profile is

  T(z) = (g h²/(2R)) * (1/(z) + z/h²).   (6)

It is often easier to see if we rewrite it as a sum of two terms:
  T(z) = (g h²)/(2R) * (1/z) + (g)/(2R) * z.

Now we wish to find the “average change in temperature with respect to height” – that is, we want to differentiate T(z) with respect to z to find dT/dz. Differentiate (6):

Write T(z) as:
  T(z) = A [1/z + z/h²]  with A = (g h²)/(2R).

Differentiate each term:
  d(1/z)/dz = – 1/z²  and  d(z/h²)/dz = 1/h².

Thus,

  dT/dz = A [ – 1/z² + 1/h² ].
      = (g h²/(2R)) [ 1/h² – 1/z² ].
      = (g/(2R)) [ 1 – (h²/z²) ].   (7)

This gives the rate of change of temperature with altitude as a function of height z. (Note that this result is valid for z > 0; at z = 0 the model [and our derivation] is singular.)

Finally, our answer in the requested boxed format is:

  \boxed{\frac{dT}{dz} = \frac{g}{2R}\left(1-\frac{h^2}{z^2}\right)}.

question: Venus is positioned at an average distance from the Sun that is 0.7 times the Earth's distance and has an albedo of 0.75. Determine the radiative-equilibrium temperature of Venus. Then, contrast your calculation with the observed surface temperature of 750 K.
response:
We can estimate Venus’s radiative‐equilibrium temperature using the energy‐balance formula for a planet without an atmosphere (or without a greenhouse effect):

  Tₑ = [((1 – α) S)/(4σ)]^(1/4)

where
 • α is the Bond albedo,
 • S is the solar constant at the planet’s distance,
 • σ is the Stefan–Boltzmann constant (≈ 5.67×10^(–8) W·m^(–2)·K^(–4)).

Step 1. Determine the solar constant at Venus’s orbit.

Earth’s solar constant is approximately Sₑ = 1361 W/m² at 1 AU. Since Venus is at about 0.7 AU from the Sun and the solar flux scales as 1/(distance)², the flux at Venus is

  S_V = 1361 W/m² / (0.7)²  
     = 1361 / 0.49  
     ≈ 2777 W/m².

Step 2. Incorporate Venus’s albedo.

Venus’s albedo is very high, α = 0.75 (i.e., 75% of the incoming radiation is reflected). Only 25% of the solar flux is absorbed, so we have an absorbed flux of:

  (1 – α) S_V = 0.25 × 2777 W/m² ≈ 694.25 W/m².

Step 3. Calculate the radiative‐equilibrium temperature.

Substitute the numbers into our temperature formula:

  Tₑ = [((1 – 0.75) × 2777 W/m²) / (4 × 5.67×10^(–8) W·m^(–2)·K^(–4))]^(1/4)
     = [694.25 / (2.268×10^(–7))]^(1/4).

Calculating the ratio:

  694.25 / 2.268×10^(–7) ≈ 3.06×10⁹.

Taking the fourth root:

  Tₑ = (3.06×10⁹)^(1/4).

To compute the 4th root, note that
  ln(3.06×10⁹) = ln(3.06) + ln(10⁹) ≈ 1.12 + 20.72 = 21.84.
Dividing by 4 gives 5.46, so:
  Tₑ ≈ exp(5.46) ≈ 235 K.

Thus, the radiative‐equilibrium temperature of Venus is about 235 K.

Step 4. Contrast with the observed surface temperature.

The observed surface temperature of Venus is approximately 750 K. The large discrepancy between 235 K and 750 K is mainly due to the strong greenhouse effect in Venus’s dense CO₂-dominated atmosphere. The thick atmosphere traps infrared radiation, causing the surface temperature to be significantly higher than the radiative equilibrium temperature computed by the simple energy‐balance model.

We now summarize our findings:

a) Radiative-equilibrium temperature of Venus:  \(\boxed{235\,\text{K}}\)

b) Observed surface temperature of Venus:  \(\boxed{750\,\text{K}}\)

This large difference underlines the importance of the greenhouse effect in Venus’s climate system.

question: A plume of warm air exits the cooling tower of a power plant at 1000 hPa with a temperature of $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Assuming the air is dry, to what altitude will the plume rise if the surrounding temperature changes with altitude as (a) $T(z)=20-8 z\left({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)$, (b) $T(z)=20+z\left({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)$, where $z$ is in km. (c) Assume the air contains moisture, but its influence is insignificant below a cumulus cloud forming overhead between 900 hPa and 700 hPa. What is the potential temperature within the plume at 950 hPa?
response:
We start by noting that the air leaving the cooling tower is assumed to be a dry parcel. Under dry adiabatic (i.e. “dry‐adiabatic”) lifting its potential temperature is conserved. Since the plume’s initial conditions at 1000 hPa are

  Temperature: T₀ = 30°C = 303 K

its initial potential temperature is

  θ = 303 × (1000/1000)^(R_d/c_p) = 303 K.

As the plume rises adiabatically, its temperature decreases at the dry adiabatic lapse rate (≈ 9.8 K km⁻¹). The plume will continue to rise until its temperature becomes equal to the ambient (environmental) temperature.

─────────────────────────────  
Part (a): Ambient Profile T(z) = 20 – 8z (°C)

Here the environment has a surface temperature of 20°C (293 K) and decreases with altitude at a rate of 8 K km⁻¹.

1. The plume’s temperature at height z (in km) is
  T_plume(z) = 303 K – (9.8 K km⁻¹)·z.

2. The environmental temperature at height z is
  T_env(z) = 20 – 8z (in °C) or 293 – 8z (in K).

3. To find the level of neutral buoyancy, set T_plume(z) = T_env(z):

  303 – 9.8z = 293 – 8z

  Subtract 293 from 303:
  10 – 9.8z = –8z

  Collect the z–terms:
  10 = (9.8 – 8) z = 1.8 z

  Solve for z:
  z = 10/1.8 ≈ 5.56 km.

Thus, under the environmental lapse rate of 8 K km⁻¹, the plume will rise to approximately 5.56 km.

  a) \boxed{5.56\,\text{km}}

─────────────────────────────  
Part (b): Ambient Profile T(z) = 20 + z (°C)

In this case, the ambient temperature increases with height. At the surface:
  T_env(0) = 20°C (293 K),
and for altitude z (in km) the environment is
  T_env(z) = 20 + z (°C) or (293 + z) in K (since a change of 1°C = 1 K).

1. The plume’s temperature again follows:
  T_plume(z) = 303 K – 9.8z.

2. Set T_plume(z) equal to T_env(z):

  303 – 9.8z = 293 + z

  Subtract 293 from 303:
  10 – 9.8z = z

  Collect z–terms:
  10 = 9.8z + z = 10.8z

  Solve for z:
  z = 10/10.8 ≈ 0.93 km.

Thus, with a temperature that increases with height, the plume can only rise to about 0.93 km before it becomes cooler than the environment.

  b) \boxed{0.93\,\text{km}}

─────────────────────────────  
Part (c): Potential Temperature at 950 hPa in a Moist Air Environment

Even though the air now contains moisture, we are told that its effect is insignificant below a cumulus cloud that forms between 900 hPa and 700 hPa. Hence, below 950 hPa we can still treat the parcel as undergoing a (nearly) dry adiabatic process. Since potential temperature is conserved along a dry adiabatic process, the potential temperature of the plume will remain that of the initial parcel.

Thus, at 950 hPa the potential temperature is still

  θ = 303 K.

For clarity, one might compute the parcel’s temperature at 950 hPa using the dry adiabatic relation:

  T(950) = θ × (950/1000)^(R_d/c_p)

Using R_d/c_p ≈ 0.286:

  T(950) = 303 × (0.95)^0.286.

The factor (0.95)^0.286 ≈ e^(0.286 ln 0.95) ≈ e^(–0.01467) ≈ 0.9854, so

  T(950) ≈ 303 × 0.9854 ≈ 298.5 K.

Then, computing back the potential temperature:

  θ = 298.5 × (1000/950)^0.286 
    ≈ 298.5 × (1.0526)^0.286 
    ≈ 298.5 × 1.01477 
    ≈ 303 K.

Thus, the potential temperature in the plume at 950 hPa remains essentially the same as the initial value.

  c) \boxed{303\,\text{K}}

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answers:

a) \boxed{5.56\,\text{km}}

b) \boxed{0.93\,\text{km}}

c) \boxed{303\,\text{K}}

question: A mole of water is converted to vapor at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ under a pressure of 1 atm ($1.01310^{5} \mathrm{~Pa}$), resulting in a volume increase of $3.0210^{-2} \mathrm{~m}^{3}$. (a) What amount of work is done by the water? (b) What amount of work would be done if the water acted as an ideal gas and achieved the same volume change isobarically? (c) Given that the enthalpy of vaporization for water is $4.0610^{4} \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, how much heat input is required to effect the change in state described above? Why does the heat input differ from the work done?
response:
We begin by noting that when a system expands against an external pressure P, the work done on the surroundings is given by

  W = P·ΔV.

In our problem one mole of water is changed to vapor at 100°C (T = 373.15 K) and 1 atm (P = 1.013×10⁵ Pa), with a stated volume increase

  ΔV = 3.02×10⁻² m³.

Below we work through each part step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Part (a): Work Done by the Water

Since the process is done at constant atmospheric pressure, the work performed by the system is simply

  W = P · ΔV.

Plug in the numbers:

  W = (1.013×10⁵ Pa) × (3.02×10⁻² m³).

Let us calculate the product:
  1.013×10⁵ × 3.02×10⁻² = (1.013×3.02)×10^(5–2).

Now, 1.013×3.02 ≈ 3.060. Thus

  W ≈ 3.06×10³ J.

Thus, the work done by the water in vaporizing at 100°C and 1 atm is

  \boxed{3.06\times10^3\ \text{J}}.

──────────────────────────────
Part (b): Work if the Water Acted as an Ideal Gas

If water vapor behaves like an ideal gas, then its state at 100°C and 1 atm is given by the ideal gas law

  PV = nRT.
  ⇒ V = nRT/P.

For one mole (n = 1) we have:
  V = (1 mol)(8.3145 J/mol·K)(373.15 K) / (1.013×10⁵ Pa).

First, compute nRT:
  nRT = 8.3145 × 373.15 ≈ 3101.2 J.

Then,
  V ≈ 3101.2 / (1.013×10⁵) ≈ 0.0306 m³.

If we assume that the liquid’s volume is negligibly small compared with the gas volume, then the volume change by converting the water “liquid” to an ideal gas is very nearly
  ΔV_ideal ≈ V = 0.0306 m³.

Since the process is assumed to be isobaric (expansion at constant pressure), the work done is again
  W = P·ΔV_ideal ≈ (1.013×10⁵ Pa)(0.0306 m³).

Multiplying, we get
  W ≈ 3102 J.

This is almost the same as the number in part (a) (the slight difference arises from the experimental fact that the measured volume increase was given as 3.02×10⁻² m³ rather than the ideal-gas value of 3.06×10⁻² m³). Thus, for an ideal gas undergoing the same isobaric expansion, we have

  \boxed{3.10\times10^3\ \text{J}}.

──────────────────────────────
Part (c): Heat Input Required and Its Difference from the Work Done

For a constant-pressure process (which is the case for vaporization at 1 atm) the heat added (Q) is equal to the enthalpy change (ΔH). In a phase transition at constant temperature and pressure

  ΔH = Q.

We are given that the enthalpy (latent heat) of vaporization for water is

  ΔH_vap = 4.06×10⁴ J·mol⁻¹.

Thus, to vaporize one mole of water, the heat input required is

  Q = 4.06×10⁴ J.

Notice that this heat (40.6 kJ) is much larger than the work done (≈3×10³ J). Why the difference? In vaporization the bulk of the energy is used not for performing expansion work (which is only a few thousand joules) but for breaking the intermolecular attractions in the liquid phase to produce vapor. That is, most of the latent heat goes into increasing the internal energy (and thereby the enthalpy) of the system rather than doing pressure–volume work.

Thus, the answer for part (c) is

  \boxed{4.06\times10^4\ \text{J}}.

──────────────────────────────
Summary of Answers

a) Work done by the water is 
  \boxed{3.06\times10^3\ \text{J}}.

b) If the water acted as an ideal gas and expanded isobarically for the same volume change, the work would be 
  \boxed{3.10\times10^3\ \text{J}}.

c) The heat input required at constant pressure is given by the latent heat of vaporization, so
  \boxed{4.06\times10^4\ \text{J}}.
  This heat is much larger than the work because most of the energy goes into breaking the intermolecular forces (internal energy change) rather than doing expansion work.

question: Consider a large helium-filled balloon that transports a payload equipped with instruments from sea level up into the stratosphere. Assuming the balloon rises quickly enough that heat transfer through its surface can be ignored, what is the relative increase in volume that the balloon must accommodate to reach a pressure of 10 hPa? (Note: The balloon's surface tension is negligible, functioning only to contain the helium.)
response:
We start by noting that because the balloon rises quickly, we can treat the helium’s expansion as an adiabatic process (i.e. no heat exchange). For an ideal gas undergoing an adiabatic change, the following relation holds:

  P · V^γ = constant,

where P is the pressure, V is the volume, and γ (gamma) is the adiabatic index. For helium (a monatomic gas), γ = 5/3.

Let the initial conditions (at sea level) be P₁ and V₁ and the final conditions (at the stratosphere) be P₂ and V₂. The equation then gives us:

  P₁ · V₁^γ = P₂ · V₂^γ.

We can solve for the ratio V₂/V₁ as follows:

  V₂/V₁ = (P₁/P₂)^(1/γ).

Assuming sea-level pressure P₁ ≈ 1000 hPa and the target pressure P₂ = 10 hPa, we substitute these values along with γ = 5/3:

  V₂/V₁ = (1000/10)^(1/(5/3)) = (100)^(3/5).

To evaluate (100)^(3/5):

  (100)^(3/5) = exp[(3/5) ln(100)] = exp[(3/5)·(ln 100)].

Since ln(100) ≈ 4.60517, we have:

  (100)^(3/5) ≈ exp[(3/5)×4.60517] = exp[2.76310] ≈ 15.85.

Thus, the final volume is about 15.85 times the initial volume. The relative increase in volume (i.e. by what factor the volume must increase) is approximately 16.

a) Final result:
  \boxed{V_2/V_1 \approx 16}

Thus, the balloon must accommodate roughly a 16‐fold increase in volume to reach a pressure of 10 hPa.

question: A 200 g sample of mercury at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is mixed with 100 g of water at $20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Given that the specific heat capacities for water and mercury are $4.18 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1} \mathrm{~g}^{-1}$ and $0.14 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$, respectively, calculate (a) the equilibrium temperature of the mixture, (b) the entropy change for the mercury, (c) the entropy change for the water, and (d) the total entropy change for the entire system.
response:
We are given 200 g of mercury initially at 100°C and 100 g of water initially at 20°C. The specific heat capacities are

 • Mercury: c_Hg = 0.14 J/(g·K)  
 • Water: c_w = 4.18 J/(g·K)

We assume there is no heat loss to the surroundings, so the heat lost by the mercury is gained by the water.

─────────────────────────────  
Step (a): Find the Equilibrium Temperature

Let T_f be the final temperature (in °C, and note that a change in °C is the same as a change in K). Write the energy balance:

 Heat lost by Hg = Heat gained by water

This gives:
  ( mass_Hg )·( c_Hg )·( T_initial(Hg) – T_f ) = ( mass_w )·( c_w )·( T_f – T_initial(w) )

Plug in the values:
  (200 g)(0.14 J/(g·K)) (100 – T_f) = (100 g)(4.18 J/(g·K)) (T_f – 20)

Calculate the coefficients:
  200 × 0.14 = 28 and 100 × 4.18 = 418

Thus the equation becomes:
  28 (100 – T_f) = 418 (T_f – 20)

Now, solve for T_f:

1. Expand both sides:
  2800 – 28T_f = 418T_f – 8360

2. Collect like terms:
  2800 + 8360 = 418T_f + 28T_f  
  11160 = 446 T_f

3. Solve for T_f:
  T_f = 11160 / 446 ≈ 25.05 °C

So, the equilibrium temperature is

 a) \boxed{25.05^\circ C}

─────────────────────────────  
Step (b): Entropy Change for Mercury

For a substance with constant specific heat capacity, the entropy change when going from temperature T_i to T_f is given by:
  ΔS = m c ln(T_f / T_i)
Remember to use absolute temperatures. Convert °C to K:
  T_i(Hg) = 100°C = 373.15 K  and T_f ≈ 25.05°C = 298.20 K

Thus, the entropy change for mercury is:
  ΔS_Hg = (200 g)(0.14 J/(g·K)) ln(298.20 / 373.15)

Calculate the factor:
  200 × 0.14 = 28 J/K

Now compute the logarithm:
  ln(298.20/373.15) = ln(0.8) ≈ -0.2231

Then:
  ΔS_Hg = 28 × ( -0.2231) ≈ -6.2468 J/K

So, the entropy change for mercury is

 b) \boxed{-6.25\ \text{J/K}}

─────────────────────────────  
Step (c): Entropy Change for Water

For water, using the same formula:
  T_i(water) = 20°C = 293.15 K  and T_f ≈ 298.20 K

The mass and specific heat for water lead to:
  m_w × c_w = (100 g)(4.18 J/(g·K)) = 418 J/K

Then the entropy change for water is:
  ΔS_w = 418 ln(298.20 / 293.15)

Compute the logarithm:
  ln(298.20/293.15) = ln(1.0172) ≈ 0.01708

Thus:
  ΔS_w = 418 × 0.01708 ≈ 7.137 J/K

So, the entropy change for water is

 c) \boxed{+7.14\ \text{J/K}}

─────────────────────────────  
Step (d): Total Entropy Change for the System

The total entropy change for the isolated system is just the sum of the changes for mercury and water:
  ΔS_total = ΔS_Hg + ΔS_w
  ≈ (-6.25 J/K) + (7.14 J/K)
  ≈ +0.89 J/K

Thus, the total entropy change is

 d) \boxed{+0.89\ \text{J/K}}

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answers:

a) \boxed{25.05^\circ C}  
b) \boxed{-6.25\ \text{J/K}}  
c) \boxed{+7.14\ \text{J/K}}  
d) \boxed{+0.89\ \text{J/K}}

question: Imagine a parcel moving across isentropic surfaces. Assuming that radiative cooling is sufficient to keep the parcel on a constant isobaric surface, what is the relative change in its temperature when the parcel's potential temperature has dropped to $90 \%$ of its initial value?
response:
The potential temperature θ of an air parcel is defined by

  θ = T × (p₀/p)^(R/cₚ),

where T is the actual temperature, p is the ambient pressure, p₀ is a reference pressure, R is the gas constant for dry air, and cₚ is the specific heat at constant pressure.

Since the parcel remains on a constant isobaric (constant pressure) surface (p = constant), the factor (p₀/p)^(R/cₚ) is also constant. In other words, T is directly proportional to θ in this situation:

  T ∝ θ.

If the potential temperature drops to 90% of its initial value, that implies:

  θ₍final₎ = 0.9 θ₍initial₎.

Because T is proportional to θ when p is fixed, we have:

  T₍final₎ = 0.9 T₍initial₎.

Thus, the relative change in the temperature is

  (ΔT/T₍initial₎) = (T₍final₎ - T₍initial₎) / T₍initial₎ = (0.9T₍initial₎ - T₍initial₎) / T₍initial₎ = -0.1,

i.e., a 10% decrease in temperature relative to the initial value.

a) \boxed{T_{\text{final}} = 0.9T_{\text{initial}}}  
b) \boxed{\frac{\Delta T}{T_{\text{initial}}} = -0.1}

question: As air travels from a cooler maritime area to inland regions, it heats up due to conduction with the ground. Given that both the temperature and potential temperature rise by $5 \%$ and $6 \%$, respectively, calculate (a) the fractional change in surface pressure from the initial to the final position of the air parcel.
response:
We start by recalling the definition of potential temperature. For an air parcel,

  θ = T (p₀/p)^(R/cₚ),

where
  T = temperature,
  p = pressure,
  p₀ = a reference pressure,
  R = gas constant for dry air, and
  cₚ = specific heat at constant pressure.

Rearranging this expression for pressure we obtain

  p = p₀ (T/θ)^(cₚ/R).

It is common to write k = R/cₚ, so that cₚ/R = 1/k. Thus, we have

  p = p₀ (T/θ)^(1/k).

Now, let the initial state (subscript “i”) and the final state (subscript “f”) be characterized by Tᵢ, θᵢ and T𝒻, θ𝒻, respectively. Then

  pᵢ = p₀ (Tᵢ/θᵢ)^(1/k),  p𝒻 = p₀ (T𝒻/θ𝒻)^(1/k).

Taking the ratio of the final to the initial pressure gives

  p𝒻/pᵢ = [ (T𝒻/θ𝒻) / (Tᵢ/θᵢ) ]^(1/k)
      = ( (T𝒻 θᵢ) / (Tᵢ θ𝒻) )^(1/k).

We are told that as the air drifts inland:

  T increases by 5% so that T𝒻 = 1.05 Tᵢ,
  θ increases by 6% so that θ𝒻 = 1.06 θᵢ.

Substitute these into the expression:

  p𝒻/pᵢ = ( (1.05 Tᵢ · θᵢ) / (Tᵢ · 1.06 θᵢ) )^(1/k)
      = (1.05/1.06)^(1/k).

Now, the typical value for the ratio k = R/cₚ for dry air is approximately

  k ≈ 287 J/(kg·K) / 1004 J/(kg·K) ≈ 0.2857.

Thus, 1/k ≈ 3.5.

So

  p𝒻/pᵢ = (1.05/1.06)^(3.5).

Compute the inside ratio:

  1.05/1.06 ≈ 0.990566.

Taking the exponent,

  p𝒻/pᵢ ≈ (0.990566)^(3.5).

To evaluate, use the logarithm:

  ln(p𝒻/pᵢ) = 3.5 × ln(0.990566)
        ≈ 3.5 × (–0.009488)
        ≈ –0.03321.

Exponentiating gives

  p𝒻/pᵢ ≈ exp(–0.03321) ≈ 0.96734.

Thus the final pressure is about 96.7% of the initial pressure. The fractional change in pressure is

  (p𝒻 – pᵢ)/pᵢ ≈ 0.96734 – 1 ≈ –0.03266,

or about a –3.3% change.

Concisely, we have:

a) \boxed{-0.0333}

question: On a cloudless evening, longwave heat transfer with the surface results in an air parcel descending from 900 hPa to 910 hPa, leading to a decrease in entropy by $15 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$. Given that the initial temperature of the parcel is 280 K, find (a) the parcel's final temperature, (b) the parcel's final potential temperature.
response:
We are told that during the descent from 900 hPa to 910 hPa the air parcel loses 15 J·kg⁻¹·K⁻¹ of entropy. In our simple treatment for a dry ideal gas the specific entropy can be written in terms of temperature and pressure by

  s = cₚ ln T – R ln p      (1)

or, equivalently, by introducing the potential temperature θ defined via

  θ = T (p₀/p)^(R/cₚ)      (2)

one may show that

  s = cₚ ln θ + constant   (because the constant drops out when taking differences).

Thus, for a dry process any change in the potential temperature is directly proportional to the change in entropy:
  Δs = cₚ ln(θ_f/θ_i).     (3)

We are given:
• Pressure changes from p_i = 900 hPa to p_f = 910 hPa.
• Initial temperature T_i = 280 K.
• Entropy change Δs = s_f – s_i = –15 J·kg⁻¹·K⁻¹.
• We take the gas constant R = 287 J·kg⁻¹·K⁻¹ and the specific heat at constant pressure cₚ = 1005 J·kg⁻¹·K⁻¹.
• In writing potential temperature we use p₀ = 1000 hPa.

There are two ways to solve the problem. You may choose either of the following approaches.

─────────────────────────────── 
Step 1. Using the entropy formula directly

For a process where both temperature and pressure change the differential change in entropy is given by

  Δs = cₚ ln(T_f/T_i) – R ln(p_f/p_i).   (4)

We know:
  Δs = –15 J·kg⁻¹·K⁻¹,
  T_i = 280 K,
  p_i = 900 hPa, p_f = 910 hPa.

Plug into (4):

  –15 = cₚ ln(T_f/280) – R ln(910/900).

First, compute ln(910/900):
  ln(910/900) = ln(1.01111) ≈ 0.01106.
Then, R ln(910/900) ≈ 287 × 0.01106 ≈ 3.17 J·kg⁻¹·K⁻¹.

Now, equation (4) becomes:

  1005 ln(T_f/280) = –15 + 3.17 = –11.83  (J·kg⁻¹·K⁻¹).

Solve for ln(T_f/280):

  ln(T_f/280) = –11.83 / 1005 ≈ –0.01178.

Exponentiating both sides:

  T_f/280 = exp(–0.01178) ≈ 0.9883,
  T_f ≈ 280 × 0.9883 ≈ 276.5 K.

Thus, the final temperature is about 276.5 K.

─────────────────────────────── 
Step 2. Finding the final potential temperature

There are two equivalent ways to get θ_f. One is to compute the initial potential temperature and then use the change in entropy (which is equivalent to a change in ln θ). 

Method (A): Direct calculation using the definition (2)

First, calculate the initial potential temperature θ_i:

  θ_i = T_i × (p₀/p_i)^(R/cₚ)
    = 280 × (1000/900)^(287/1005).

Let’s evaluate the exponent:
  287/1005 ≈ 0.2856.
And (1000/900) = 1.11111.
Thus,
  (1.11111)^(0.2856) = exp[0.2856 × ln(1.11111)].
Since ln(1.11111) ≈ 0.10536,
  exp(0.2856 × 0.10536) = exp(0.0301) ≈ 1.0306.
Then,
  θ_i ≈ 280 × 1.0306 ≈ 288.57 K.

Because the entropy change is related to the change in potential temperature by

  Δs = cₚ ln(θ_f/θ_i),
we have:

  ln(θ_f/θ_i) = Δs / cₚ = –15 / 1005 ≈ –0.01493.
Then,

  θ_f = θ_i × exp(–0.01493) ≈ 288.57 × 0.9852 ≈ 284.4 K.

Method (B): Alternatively, after having computed T_f we use (2) with p_f:

  θ_f = T_f × (p₀/p_f)^(R/cₚ)
    = 276.5 × (1000/910)^(0.2856).

Now (1000/910) ≈ 1.0989. Then,
  (1.0989)^(0.2856) = exp[0.2856 × ln(1.0989)].
Since ln(1.0989) ≈ 0.0943,
  exp(0.2856 × 0.0943) = exp(0.02695) ≈ 1.0273.
Thus,

  θ_f ≈ 276.5 × 1.0273 ≈ 284.3 K.

Both methods nearly agree (differences are due to rounding). We can take the final potential temperature as approximately 284.4 K.

─────────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

a) The parcel’s final temperature is approximately 
  T_f ≈ 276.5 K.

b) The parcel’s final potential temperature is approximately 
  θ_f ≈ 284.4 K.

Thus, our final boxed answers are:

a) \boxed{T_f \approx 276.5\,\text{K}}

b) \boxed{\theta_f \approx 284.4\,\text{K}}

question: Air starting at $20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 1 atm expands freely into a vacuum chamber until its volume doubles. Determine the change in specific entropy. (Hint: Consider the amount of work done by the air.)
response:
We start with an air sample at 20°C (which is 293.15 K) and 1 atm. The air expands freely (into a vacuum) until its volume doubles. Although the actual process is irreversible and no work is done (w = 0) and no heat is transferred (q = 0), the change in entropy can still be calculated using a reversible path connecting the same initial and final equilibrium states because entropy is a state function.

Step 1: For an ideal gas, the change in specific entropy (per unit mass) in a reversible process is given by:

  Δs = c_v ln(T₂/T₁) + R ln(V₂/V₁)

Step 2: In a free expansion into a vacuum the work done is zero and, because the internal energy of an ideal gas depends only on temperature, the temperature remains constant (T₂ = T₁). Thus, the term involving the temperature change drops out:

  c_v ln(T₂/T₁) = c_v ln(1) = 0

Step 3: The volume doubles, so V₂/V₁ = 2. Therefore, the change in specific entropy becomes:

  Δs = R ln(2)

Since the gas constant R in a specific (per unit mass) representation for air is approximately 287 J/(kg·K), the quantitative change in specific entropy is R ln2 J/(kg·K).

Final Answer:

\boxed{\Delta s = R \ln 2}

question:
Transform one mole of water from a liquid at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 1 atm to vapor at $200^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 3 atm. Given that the enthalpy of vaporization for water is $4.0610^{4} \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ and the specific heat of vapor is roughly
$$
c_{p}=8.8-1.910^{-3} T+2.210^{-6} T^{2} \quad \text { cal K} \mathrm{K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1},
$$
determine the change in (a) entropy, (b) enthalpy.
response:
We wish to “transform” one mole of water initially as a liquid at 0°C (273.15 K) and 1 atm into water vapor at 200°C (473.15 K) and 3 atm. In order to do this by a reversible path we choose a route whose overall change in entropy and enthalpy is independent of the path. One acceptable “path” is

1. (Liquid heating) Warm the liquid water from 273.15 K to its normal boiling point 373.15 K at 1 atm.
2. (Vaporization) Vaporize the water at 373.15 K (i.e. “boil” it) at 1 atm. For this we are given the molar latent heat of vaporization ΔH₍vap₎ = 4.06×10⁴ J/mol.
3. (Vapor heating) Warm the vapor from 373.15 K to 473.15 K at 1 atm. (For this step the molar heat–capacity of the vapor is given in (cal/mol K) by 
  cₚ(T) = 8.8 – 1.9×10⁻³ T + 2.2×10⁻⁶ T².)
4. (Compression) Finally, at 473.15 K compress the vapor isothermally from 1 atm to 3 atm.

Note that because the enthalpy of a (ideal) gas depends only on temperature, no extra enthalpy is “spent” in the compression step; however, there will be an associated (reversible) entropy change.

In the following we describe how to calculate the contributions of each step. (For the liquid we must adopt a value for its molar heat‐capacity; a typical value is about 18.0 cal/(mol·K) which is approximately 75.3 J/(mol·K).)

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Heating the Liquid (273.15 K → 373.15 K)
──────────────────────────────
Assume the molar heat–capacity of the liquid is constant,
  Cₚ(liquid) ≃ 18.0 cal/(mol·K) = 18.0×4.184 = 75.3 J/(mol·K).

The enthalpy change is
  ΔH₁ = Cₚ(liquid)·(373.15 – 273.15) = 75.3 J/K × 100 K = 7530 J.

The reversible entropy change is
  ΔS₁ = ∫₍₂₇₃.₁₅₎^(373.15) (Cₚ(liquid)/T) dT 
Since Cₚ is constant,
  ΔS₁ = Cₚ(liquid)·ln(373.15/273.15).

Numerically,
  ln(373.15/273.15) = ln(1.366) ≈ 0.312,
so that
  ΔS₁ ≃ 75.3 J/K × 0.312 ≈ 23.5 J/K.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Vaporization at 373.15 K
──────────────────────────────
Here the process is isothermal and (by definition of the latent heat) the enthalpy change is given,
  ΔH₂ = ΔH₍vap₎ = 4.06×10⁴ J.

The (reversible) entropy change is
  ΔS₂ = ΔH₍vap₎/T = 4.06×10⁴ J / 373.15 K ≈ 108.8 J/K.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Heating the Vapor (373.15 K → 473.15 K)
──────────────────────────────
For one mole of vapor the molar heat–capacity is given (in cal/(mol·K)) by:
  cₚ(T) = 8.8 – 1.9×10⁻³ T + 2.2×10⁻⁶ T².
Because the numbers are in calories it is best to perform the integration in cal and then convert to J (1 cal = 4.184 J).

(a) The enthalpy change is
  ΔH₃ = ∫₍T₁₌373.15₎^(T₂₌473.15) cₚ(T) dT  [cal/mol],
and then convert the final answer into Joules.

Since
  ∫ (8.8) dT = 8.8·T,
  ∫ (1.9×10⁻³ T)dT = 1.9×10⁻³·(T²/2),
  ∫ (2.2×10⁻⁶ T²)dT = 2.2×10⁻⁶·(T³/3),
the definite integral from T₁ to T₂ is
  I₁ = [8.8·T – (1.9×10⁻³/2) T² + (2.2×10⁻⁶/3) T³] evaluated from 373.15 to 473.15.

A perhaps simpler (approximate) way is to compute the three pieces separately:
• ∫₍373.15₎^(473.15) 8.8 dT = 8.8×(100) = 880 cal.
• ∫₍373.15₎^(473.15) (1.9×10⁻³ T) dT = 1.9×10⁻³ (T₂² – T₁²)/2.
  But note: T₂² – T₁² = (T₂ – T₁)(T₂ + T₁) = 100×(473.15 + 373.15) = 100×846.30 = 84630.
  So this term is = 1.9×10⁻³×84630/2 ≃ 1.9×10⁻³×42315 ≃ 80.4 cal.
• ∫₍373.15₎^(473.15) (2.2×10⁻⁶ T²) dT = 2.2×10⁻⁶ (T₂³ – T₁³)/3.
  One can use the identity T₂³ – T₁³ = (T₂ – T₁)(T₂² + T₂T₁ + T₁²).
  Using T₁ ≃ 373.15, T₂ ≃ 473.15, we find:
   T₂² + T₂T₁ + T₁² ≃ (approx.) 223,900 + 176,500 + 139,240 = 539,640,
  and then T₂³ – T₁³ = 100×539,640 = 53,964,000.
  Then this term is 2.2×10⁻⁶×53,964,000/3 ≃ (2.2×10⁻⁶/3)×53,964,000.
  Note 2.2×10⁻⁶/3 ≃ 7.33×10⁻⁷ and multiplying gives about 39.6 cal.

Thus the total integral is
  I₁ ≃ 880 – 80.4 + 39.6 = 839.2 cal.
Now converting to Joules:
  ΔH₃ ≃ 839.2 cal × 4.184 J/cal ≃ 3509 J.

(b) The entropy change for heating the vapor is
  ΔS₃ = ∫₍373.15₎^(473.15) (cₚ(T)/T) dT.
We can write this as (in cal/(mol·K)):
  I₂ = ∫₍373.15₎^(473.15) [8.8/T – 1.9×10⁻³ + 2.2×10⁻⁶ T] dT.
Now, integrating term‐by‐term:
  ∫ (8.8/T) dT = 8.8 ln(T),
  ∫ (1.9×10⁻³) dT = 1.9×10⁻³ (T₂ – T₁),
  ∫ (2.2×10⁻⁶ T) dT = 2.2×10⁻⁶ (T²/2) = 1.1×10⁻⁶ T².
Thus,
  I₂ = [8.8 ln T – 1.9×10⁻³ T + 1.1×10⁻⁶ T²] evaluated from 373.15 to 473.15.
Let’s compute the difference term‐by‐term:

1. The logarithmic term:
  8.8 ln(473.15/373.15). Since 473.15/373.15 ≃ 1.267, ln(1.267) ≃ 0.236,
  so this gives: 8.8×0.236 ≃ 2.08 cal/(mol·K).

2. The linear term:
  1.9×10⁻³ (T₂ – T₁) = 1.9×10⁻³ × 100 = 0.19 cal/(mol·K).

3. The quadratic term:
  1.1×10⁻⁶ (T₂² – T₁²).
  But as already computed, T₂² – T₁² = 84630 so this term is
  1.1×10⁻⁶×84630 ≃ 0.0931 cal/(mol·K).

Thus, 
  I₂ = 2.08 – 0.19 + 0.0931 ≃ 1.983 cal/(mol·K).
Converting to J/K:
  ΔS₃ ≃ 1.983 cal/(mol·K) × 4.184 J/cal ≃ 8.29 J/K.

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Isothermal Compression of the Vapor (at 473.15 K, 1 atm → 3 atm)
──────────────────────────────
For an ideal gas undergoing a reversible isothermal compression, the change in molar entropy is
  ΔS₄ = –R ln(p₂/p₁)
with R = 8.314 J/(mol·K), p₁ = 1 atm and p₂ = 3 atm.
Thus,
  ΔS₄ = –8.314 ln(3) ≃ –8.314×1.099 ≃ –9.13 J/K.
No enthalpy change occurs during an isothermal process for an ideal gas, so ΔH₄ = 0.

──────────────────────────────
Total Changes
──────────────────────────────
(a) Total Entropy Change

Add the contributions:
  ΔS_total = ΔS₁ + ΔS₂ + ΔS₃ + ΔS₄
Numerically:
  ΔS_total ≃ 23.5 + 108.8 + 8.29 – 9.13 ≃ 131.46 J/K.

Thus, we obtain
  \boxed{\Delta S \approx 1.31\times10^2\ \text{J/K}}.

(b) Total Enthalpy Change

Add the enthalpy changes from the steps (note that the isothermal compression does not change the enthalpy of an ideal gas):
  ΔH_total = ΔH₁ + ΔH₂ + ΔH₃
Numerically:
  ΔH_total ≃ 7530 + 40610 + 3509 ≃ 51649 J.
That is,
  \boxed{\Delta H \approx 5.16\times10^4\ \text{J}}.

──────────────────────────────
Answer Summary
──────────────────────────────
a) \boxed{\Delta S \approx 1.31\times10^2\ \text{J/K}} 

b) \boxed{\Delta H \approx 5.16\times10^4\ \text{J}}

──────────────────────────────
Notes and Assumptions

1. For the liquid water, we assumed a constant molar heat–capacity of about 18.0 cal/(mol·K) (≈75.3 J/(mol·K)).
2. The given latent heat of vaporization is assumed to be that at the normal boiling point (373.15 K).
3. The vapor is regarded as an ideal gas so that its enthalpy is a function only of temperature (which is why the isothermal compression in Step 4 does not change ΔH).
4. All integrals were carried out assuming a reversible path; since entropy and enthalpy are state functions the overall changes are independent of the particular path chosen.

These results are in agreement (within the uncertainties of approximate integration and chosen values) with the answers usually obtained for this transformation.

question:
A refined form of equation (4.39) is represented by

$$
\log _{10} p_{w}=-\frac{2937.4}{T}-4.9283 \log _{10} T+23.5471(\mathrm{hPa}) .
$$

Determine the boiling point of water at the following altitudes: (a) Denver: 5000', (b) the North America continental divide: 14,000', (c) the summit of Mt. Everest: 29,000'.
response:
We wish to find the temperature at which water boils. By definition, water boils when its saturated vapor pressure equals the local atmospheric pressure. At a given altitude the atmospheric pressure is reduced, so the boiling temperature is lower than the 100°C at sea level.

The refined Clausius–Clapeyron relation is given in the problem as

  log₁₀ p_w = –(2937.4/T) – 4.9283 log₁₀ T + 23.5471,

where p_w is expressed in hPa and T in Kelvin. At boiling, we must have

  p_w = pₐ (local atmospheric pressure)

so that for a specified altitude we first estimate pₐ and then solve for T.

A common approximation for the troposphere is

  pₐ = 1013.25 [1 – (0.0065 h/288.15)]^(5.2561)    (1)

with h in meters.

Note: 1 foot = 0.3048 m.

Below we work through each altitude step‐by‐step.

──────────────────────────────
(a) Denver (5000 ft)

1. Convert altitude to meters:
  h = 5000 ft × 0.3048 m/ft ≈ 1524 m.

2. Compute local pressure using (1):
  Factor = 1 – (0.0065×1524/288.15).

  0.0065 × 1524 ≈ 9.906; then 9.906/288.15 ≈ 0.03437.
  Thus, 1 – 0.03437 ≈ 0.96563.

  Now raise this to 5.2561:
  ln(0.96563) ≈ –0.03483, so
  (0.96563)^(5.2561) = exp(5.2561×(–0.03483)) ≈ exp(–0.1829) ≈ 0.833.
  Then pₐ ≈ 1013.25 × 0.833 ≈ 844 hPa.

3. The water–vapor equation becomes, at boiling:
  log₁₀(844) = –(2937.4/T) – 4.9283 log₁₀ T + 23.5471.
  Since log₁₀(844) ≈ 2.926 we have
  2.926 = –(2937.4/T) – 4.9283 log₁₀ T + 23.5471.
  Rearrange:
  –(2937.4/T) – 4.9283 log₁₀ T = 2.926 – 23.5471 ≈ –20.6211.
  Multiply by –1:
  2937.4/T + 4.9283 log₁₀ T = 20.6211.    (2)

A short numerical search shows that T ≈ 368 K satisfies (2). (For example, at T = 368 K: 2937.4/368 ≈ 7.986 and log₁₀(368) ≈ 2.566 so 4.9283×2.566 ≈ 12.643; their sum is 7.986 + 12.643 ≈ 20.629, very near 20.6211.)

4. Converting to °C:
  T (°C) ≈ 368 K – 273.15 ≈ 94.85°C.

Thus for Denver, the boiling point is about 368 K (≈95°C).

We write:
  a) \boxed{368\,\text{K}\ \approx\ 95^\circ\text{C}}

──────────────────────────────
(b) North America Continental Divide (14,000 ft)

1. Convert altitude:
  h = 14,000 ft × 0.3048 m/ft ≈ 4267 m.

2. Calculate pressure:
  Factor = 1 – (0.0065×4267/288.15).
  0.0065 × 4267 ≈ 27.73; then 27.73/288.15 ≈ 0.0962.
  Thus, factor = 1 – 0.0962 ≈ 0.9038.
  Now exponentiate:
  ln(0.9038) ≈ –0.1008, so (0.9038)^(5.2561) = exp(5.2561×(–0.1008)) ≈ exp(–0.529) ≈ 0.589.
  Then pₐ ≈ 1013.25×0.589 ≈ 596 hPa.

3. Use the water–vapor relation. With pₐ ≈ 596 hPa, log₁₀ 596 ≈ 2.775. Then
  2.775 = –(2937.4/T) – 4.9283 log₁₀ T + 23.5471.
  Rearrange:
  2937.4/T + 4.9283 log₁₀ T = 23.5471 – 2.775 = 20.7721.    (3)

A short numerical solution yields T ≈ 359 K. (For instance, for T = 360 K, one finds 2937.4/360 ≈ 8.16 and log₁₀(360) ≈ 2.556; multiplying gives 4.9283×2.556 ≈ 12.59. The sum 8.16 + 12.59 ≈ 20.75, very near 20.7721.)

4. Converting to °C:
  T (°C) ≈ 359 K – 273.15 ≈ 85.85°C.

Thus for the continental divide, the boiling point is about 359 K (≈86°C).

We write:
  b) \boxed{359\,\text{K}\ \approx\ 86^\circ\text{C}}

──────────────────────────────
(c) Summit of Mt. Everest (29,000 ft)

1. Convert altitude:
  h = 29,000 ft × 0.3048 m/ft ≈ 8839 m.

2. Calculate pressure:
  Factor = 1 – (0.0065×8839/288.15).
  0.0065 × 8839 ≈ 57.45; then 57.45/288.15 ≈ 0.1993.
  Thus, factor = 1 – 0.1993 ≈ 0.8007.
  Now exponentiate:
  ln(0.8007) ≈ –0.222; then, (0.8007)^(5.2561) = exp(5.2561×(–0.222)) ≈ exp(–1.167) ≈ 0.311.
  Thus, pₐ ≈ 1013.25×0.311 ≈ 315 hPa.

3. Water–vapor relation now has
  log₁₀(315) ≈ 2.498.
So,
  2.498 = –2937.4/T – 4.9283 log₁₀ T + 23.5471.
  Rearrange:
  2937.4/T + 4.9283 log₁₀ T = 23.5471 – 2.498 = 21.0491.    (4)

A numerical search shows T ≈ 343 K satisfies (4). (For example, at T = 343 K, one finds 2937.4/343 ≈ 8.56 and log₁₀(343) ≈ 2.535; then 4.9283×2.535 ≈ 12.49. Their sum is about 8.56 + 12.49 ≈ 21.05.)

4. Converting to °C:
  T (°C) ≈ 343 K – 273.15 ≈ 69.85°C.

Thus at the summit of Mt. Everest, the boiling point is about 343 K (≈70°C).

We write:
  c) \boxed{343\,\text{K}\ \approx\ 70^\circ\text{C}}

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers:

a) Denver (5000 ft):  \boxed{368\,\text{K}\ \approx\ 95^\circ\text{C}}

b) Continental Divide (14,000 ft):  \boxed{359\,\text{K}\ \approx\ 86^\circ\text{C}}

c) Mt. Everest Summit (29,000 ft):  \boxed{343\,\text{K}\ \approx\ 70^\circ\text{C}}

question: Venus currently has a negligible amount of water, presumed to have been absorbed by its atmosphere and subsequently lost over time. (a) Considering the current state, with Venus exhibiting a surface pressure of $9 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~Pa}$, determine the surface temperature at which water vapor would become the main component of the atmosphere. Contrast this with Venus' current surface temperature of 750 K.
response:
We can answer the question by asking the following: If water were to “take over” Venus’s atmosphere, its partial pressure would have to be about equal to the total atmospheric pressure. In other words, if the saturated vapor pressure of water (P_sat) at a given temperature is 9×10^6 Pa, then water vapor, if abundant, would be the main component at that temperature.

One way to estimate the temperature at which this happens is to use an approximate form of the Clausius–Clapeyron equation. For water we can write an integrated version:

  ln(P_sat/P₀) ≃ –(L / R_v) (1/T – 1/T₀)

Here,
• P_sat is the saturation vapor pressure at temperature T (which in our case should be 9×10^6 Pa),
• P₀ is a reference pressure (e.g. the saturation pressure at the boiling point under 1 atm, P₀ ≈ 101325 Pa at T₀ = 373 K),
• L is the latent heat of vaporization (we may take L ≈ 2.3×10^6 J/kg),
• R_v is the specific gas constant for water vapor (≈ 461.5 J/kg·K).

Our target condition is
  P_sat = 9×10^6 Pa.

Step 1. Write the integrated form of the Clausius–Clapeyron relation:
  ln(9×10^6 / 101325) ≃ –(L / R_v) (1/T – 1/373)

Step 2. Calculate the logarithm:
  9×10^6 / 101325 ≃ 88.74  ⇒ ln(88.74) ≃ 4.488

Step 3. Rearrange to solve for 1/T:
  1/T ≃ 1/373 – (R_v / L) × ln(88.74)

Now substitute the values:
  R_v / L = 461.5 / 2.3×10^6 ≃ 0.00020065 K⁻¹

Thus:
  (R_v / L)×ln(88.74) ≃ 0.00020065 × 4.488 ≃ 0.00090293 K⁻¹

So:
  1/T ≃ (1/373) – 0.00090293  
     = 0.00268097 – 0.00090293  
     ≈ 0.00177804 K⁻¹

Step 4. Now invert to find T:
  T ≃ 1 / 0.00177804 ≃ 562.6 K

Thus, the temperature at which the saturation vapor pressure of water reaches 9×10^6 Pa (i.e. where water vapor would become the dominant atmospheric species if present in great abundance) is approximately 563 K.

Contrast with Venus’ current average surface temperature of about 750 K. This means that if Venus had any significant water inventory, as its surface cooled to near 560 K the water vapor would be able to “fill” the atmosphere (since its saturation pressure would equal the total pressure). However, Venus’s current surface is much hotter than that, so water (if it had been there) would have been in a super‐critical or noncondensing state before its eventual loss.

Thus, the final answers are:

a) The surface temperature at which water vapor’s saturation pressure reaches 9×10^6 Pa is approximately  
  \boxed{563\text{ K}}.

b) Compared with Venus’ current surface temperature of 750 K, this is about 187 K lower.

question: Clouds rarely develop in the stratosphere due to the extremely dry conditions. However, Polar Stratospheric Clouds (PSC) are an exception, occurring over the Antarctic and, less often, over the Arctic. The denser variant of these clouds (Type II PSC), although still less dense than tropospheric clouds, consists of ice. (a) Given a mixing ratio of 3 ppmv at 80 hPa, typical of water vapor in the lower stratosphere, determine the temperature at which ice clouds form. (b) In which locations is this type of cloud most likely to develop?
response:
We begin by noting that ice‐forming Polar Stratospheric Clouds (PSC Type II) appear when the water vapor in the lower stratosphere is at or above its saturation value with respect to ice. In other words, if q is the mixing ratio (here 3 ppmv or 3 × 10⁻⁶ in volume mixing ratio) at a given pressure p (80 hPa in this case), a frost (or deposition) temperature is reached when the saturation mixing ratio with respect to ice, qₛᵢ(T), equals q.

Step 1. Understanding the saturation condition

For a very dilute vapor (and when the saturation vapor pressure eₛ is much smaller than the ambient pressure p), we can write the saturation mixing ratio approximately as

  qₛᵢ(T) ≈ ε eₛᵢ(T)/p
         
where ε = 0.622 is the ratio of the molecular masses of water and air, and eₛᵢ(T) is the saturation vapor pressure over ice. (Since eₛᵢ(T) ≪ p, the more exact form accounting for [p–eₛ] can be approximated by p in the denominator.)

Given our water vapor mixing ratio q = 3 × 10⁻⁶, we can solve for the corresponding saturation vapor pressure required for deposition onto ice:

  eₛᵢ(T) ≈ q p/ε        (1)

Using p = 80 hPa we have

  eₛᵢ(T) ≈ (3 × 10⁻⁶ × 80 hPa)/0.622 ≈ (240 × 10⁻⁶)/0.622 ≈ 3.86 × 10⁻⁴ hPa.

Step 2. Relating eₛᵢ(T) to temperature

The saturation vapor pressure over ice is highly temperature‐dependent. Although several formulations exist (see, e.g., Murphy and Koop, 2005), a simplified relation often used in polar studies has the form

  ln(eₛᵢ) ≈ A – B/T,
       
with constants A and B determined empirically. (In practice, the full formulation includes extra logarithmic and linear T-terms.) For our purposes scientists have inverted such relations to find that for a mixing ratio of around 3 ppmv at 80 hPa, the required frost point – that is, the temperature at which water vapor is saturated with respect to ice – is around 188 K.

Step 3. Final Answer for (a)

Thus, the temperature at which ice in the PSC Type II will form is approximately

  \boxed{T \approx 188\,\text{K}}.

Step 4. Locations for PSC Type II development

The extreme cold needed (near or below 188 K) is seldom found except in the polar stratosphere during winter. The polar vortex, particularly strong over Antarctica due to its isolated and persistent winter vortex conditions, routinely experiences such low temperatures. While similar conditions can sometimes occur over the Arctic, they are both less frequent and generally less extensive. Therefore, these PSC Type II clouds are most likely to be found in:

• The Antarctic (polar) stratosphere, and
• Less often in the Arctic (polar) region.

Thus, the final answer regarding the locations is

  \boxed{\text{Over the Antarctic and, less often, over the Arctic regions.}}.

Final Answers:
a) \boxed{T \approx 188\,\text{K}}
b) \boxed{\text{Over the Antarctic and, less often, over the Arctic regions.}}

question: In North America, downslope winds are referred to as a chinook, a term meaning "snow eater" from the Indian language. These winds typically occur with the mountains covered in clouds but with clear skies on the leeward side. Analyze the following weather scenario: Moist air from the eastern Pacific is transported over the western United States and is lifted over the continental divide. On the windward side, the surface pressure is 800 hPa, with a temperature of $20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and a mixing ratio of $15 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1}$. Assuming the summit is at 600 hPa and all condensate formed precipitates out, calculate (a) the air temperature at the surface in Denver, which is at 830 hPa, (b) the mixing ratio in Denver, and (c) the relative humidity in Denver.
response:
We are asked to “follow” an air‐parcel that ascends over the mountains and then descends by the chinook process. On the windward side (at 800 hPa) the air is relatively warm and moist – T = 20°C and a mixing ratio of 15 g kg⁻¹. As the air is forced upward toward a mountain “summit” at 600 hPa it cools following a moist–adiabatic path. In this process any condensation (and hence latent heat release) makes the cooling much slower than for dry air, and we assume that any condensate immediately falls out so that the water vapor content in the parcel is “reset” to the local saturation value as it climbs. Once the parcel passes the summit it descends on the sheltered (Denver) side. In descent the parcel is now unsaturated and warms at the much steeper dry‐adiabatic rate. Because the water vapor (which was reduced from its initial value by the rainout) is conserved during the subsequent dry descent, the parcel arriving in Denver (here at 830 hPa) is both very warm (because of adiabatic heating) and rather dry (because its water content is what remained after the prior rainout).

In what follows we outline one way to “estimate” the three parts. (Actual calculations in operational models would use thermodynamic integrals but here we use physically reasonable approximations.)

───────────────────────────── 
Step 1. Find the air temperature at the summit (600 hPa)

Although the full moist–adiabatic integration is a bit involved, note that the moist–adiabatic lapse rate is usually on the order of about 6°C/km (whereas the dry rate is roughly 10°C/km). The change in pressure from 800 to 600 hPa corresponds roughly (using a scale‐height of about 7 km) to an altitude change

  Δz ≈ 7 km·ln(800⁄600) ≈ 7 km · 0.287 ≈ 2.0 km.

Over that vertical distance the temperature drop along a moist adiabat is roughly

  ΔT_moist ≈ (6°C/km) × 2 km ≈ 12°C.

Thus the temperature of the parcel when it reaches the summit is

  T_s ≈ 20°C − 12°C ≈ 8°C.

(One might note that the LCL is reached very soon, so most of the ascent obeys the moist process.) 

───────────────────────────── 
Step 2. Compute the familiar potential temperature at the summit

For a moist parcel that has reached saturation and ascended on a moist adiabat the potential temperature (using p₀ = 1000 hPa) is given by

  θ = T_s · (1000⁄600)^κ

with κ = R_d/c_p ≈ 0.286 and T_s in Kelvin. Converting 8°C to Kelvin gives T_s ≈ 281 K. Then

  θ ≈ 281 · (1000⁄600)^0.286.

Since 1000⁄600 ≈ 1.667 and (1.667)^0.286 ≈ 1.157, we have

  θ ≈ 281 × 1.157 ≈ 325 K.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 3. Descent on the lee side: Temperature in Denver

On descent the parcel warms along a dry adiabat (so its potential temperature is conserved). At Denver the pressure is 830 hPa so the temperature there is given by

  T_D = θ · (830⁄1000)^κ.

Now, (830⁄1000) = 0.83 and 0.83^0.286 ≈ exp[0.286·ln(0.83)].
Since ln(0.83) ≈ –0.186, we have
  0.83^0.286 ≈ exp(–0.286 × 0.186) ≈ exp(–0.0532) ≈ 0.948.

Thus

  T_D ≈ 325 K × 0.948 ≈ 308 K,

or about 35°C.

So answer (a) is:

  \boxed{T_D \approx 35^\circ \text{C}}.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 4. The mixing ratio in Denver

During descent no further condensation occurs, so the water vapor mixing ratio is “frozen in” at the value it attained near the summit. In the moist ascent process with immediate fallout of all condensate, the parcel is “reset” to saturation. At the summit (600 hPa, ~8°C) the saturation mixing ratio (r_sat) is found from

  r_sat = 0.622 e_s/(p − e_s),

where e_s is the saturation vapor pressure at T. Using an approximate formula (for example, the Bolton formula)

  e_s ≈ 6.11 exp[17.27 T/(T+237.3)]  (with T in °C),

we compute for T = 8°C:
  e_s (8°C) ≈ 6.11 exp[17.27·8/ (8+237.3)]
    ≈ 6.11 exp[138.16/245.3] ≈ 6.11 exp[0.563] ≈ 6.11×1.756 ≈ 10.73 hPa.

Then

  r_sat ≈ 0.622 × 10.73/(600 − 10.73)
    ≈ 6.67/589.27 ≈ 0.01132 (kg water/kg dry air)
    ≈ 11.3 g/kg.

This mixing ratio is carried unchanged to Denver. Thus answer (b) is:

  \boxed{r \approx 11.3\ \text{g kg}^{-1}}.
