───────────────────────────── 
Step 5. The relative humidity in Denver

At Denver the parcel now has a mixing ratio of about 11.3 g kg⁻¹ and a temperature of about 35°C. To find the relative humidity we need to compare this to the saturation mixing ratio at Denver’s conditions (830 hPa, 35°C). First, calculate e_s (35°C) using the same formula:

  e_s (35°C) ≈ 6.11 exp[17.27·35/(35+237.3)].
Now, 17.27·35 ≈ 604.45 and 35+237.3 ≈ 272.3, so
  e_s ≈ 6.11 exp(604.45/272.3 ≈ 2.219) ≈ 6.11 exp(2.219).
Since exp(2.219) ≈ 9.20, we have
  e_s ≈ 6.11 × 9.20 ≈ 56.3 hPa.

Now the saturation mixing ratio at Denver is

  r_sat,D = 0.622 e_s/(p − e_s) = 0.622×56.3/(830 − 56.3).

The denominator: 830 − 56.3 ≈ 773.7 hPa, so

  r_sat,D ≈ (35.0)/773.7 ≈ 0.0452 (kg/kg) ≈ 45.2 g/kg.

Thus the relative humidity is

  RH = (actual mixing ratio / saturation mixing ratio) × 100%
    ≈ (11.3/45.2) × 100% ≈ 25%.

So answer (c) is:

  \boxed{\text{RH} \approx 25\%}.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers:

a) Denver’s temperature is about  \boxed{35^\circ \text{C}}.

b) The mixing ratio is about  \boxed{11.3\ \text{g kg}^{-1}}.

c) The relative humidity is about  \boxed{25\%}.

question: Moist warm air exits a series of cooling towers at a power plant located at 825 hPa. A cloud forms directly above. Assuming the ambient temperature profile is isothermal, with $T=5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, and that the initial temperature and mixing ratio of air leaving the towers are $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $25 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1}$, respectively, calculate: (a) the relative humidity just above the towers, (b) the dew point just above the towers, (c) the virtual potential temperature just above the towers; compare this with the potential temperature and relate it to typical differences between $\theta$ and $\theta_{v}$, (d) the pressure at the base of the cloud, (e) the equivalent potential temperature at 800 hPa, (f) the mixing ratio at 700 hPa, (g) the pressure at the top of the cloud.
response:
We will “follow the money” in the calculations. In our problem a power‐plant cooling tower is discharging very warm, moist air at 30°C with a water–vapor mixing ratio of 25 g kg⁻¹ into an environment that is held nearly isothermal at 5°C. The tower air exits at 825 hPa. (Remember: 25 g kg⁻¹ means 0.025 in nondimensional “kg of water per kg of dry air”.) We will assume that when the warm, moist air rises it does so adiabatically until it eventually becomes saturated (and a cloud forms), and that before saturation (or even just at the exit level) we may use the usual “parcel” formulas to compute various quantities. In what follows we sketch one acceptable method; note that many “reasonable approximations” are used in many texts.

────────────────────────────
Step (a). Relative Humidity just above the towers

At the tower exit the air is unsaturated. One may compute the RH by comparing the actual mixing ratio q (0.025 kg kg⁻¹) to the saturation mixing ratio at 30°C and 825 hPa. One may use the standard formula

  wₛ = 0.622·[eₛ/(p – eₛ)],

where eₛ is the saturation vapor pressure. At T = 30°C the Bolton formula gives

  eₛ(30°C) ≈ 6.112 exp[17.67·30/(30+243.5)] ≈ 42.6 hPa.

Thus,
  wₛ(30°C,825 hPa) ≈ 0.622 · 42.6/(825 – 42.6) 
              = (26.5)/(782.4) ≈ 0.0339 (in kg/kg) 
           which is about 33.9 g/kg.

Then the relative humidity is
  RH = (q / wₛ) × 100% = (25/33.9)×100% ≈ 73.8%.

It is acceptable to round this to about 74%.

Thus,
(a) \boxed{74\%}

────────────────────────────
Step (b). Dew Point just above the towers

The dew point Tₑ is that temperature at which, at the same pressure (825 hPa), a saturated air would have a mixing ratio equal to q = 0.025. In other words we solve for Tₑ so that

  q = 0.622·eₛ(Tₑ)/(825 – eₛ(Tₑ)).

A short (approximate) procedure is to “invert” the calculation. First, solve for the “required” saturation vapor pressure:
  0.025 = 0.622·eₛ_d/(825 – eₛ_d)  ⟹  eₛ_d = [0.025·825] / [0.622 + 0.025]
because writing
  eₛ_d = (q/0.622)[825 – eₛ_d]  ⟹  eₛ_d [1 + (q/0.622)] = (q×825)/0.622.
Using q = 0.025 we have q/0.622 ≈ 0.04019 so that
  1+0.04019 = 1.04019  and  (0.025×825)/0.622 ≈ (20.625)/0.622 ≈ 33.18 hPa.
Then,
  eₛ_d ≈ 33.18/1.04019 ≈ 31.9 hPa.

Now one “inverts” eₛ(T) (using, e.g., the Bolton formula in reverse) to get Tₑ. For example, using
  Tₑ = [243.5 ln(eₛ/e₀)]/[17.67 – ln(eₛ/e₀)]
with e₀ = 6.112 hPa, we have
  ln(31.9/6.112) = ln(5.22) ≈ 1.653.
Thus,
  Tₑ = (243.5×1.653)/(17.67 – 1.653) = 402.3/16.017 ≈ 25.1°C.
We then say the dew point is approximately 25°C.

Thus,
(b) \boxed{25^\circ C}

────────────────────────────
Step (c). Virtual Potential Temperature just above the towers

Recall that the potential temperature is defined as
  θ = T (p₀/p)^(R_d/c_p),
with p₀ usually 1000 hPa. (Use T in Kelvin; here T = 30°C = 303 K.) With R_d = 287 J/(kg·K) and c_p = 1004 J/(kg·K), the exponent is about 0.285. At p = 825 hPa we have
  θ = 303 × (1000/825)^(0.285).
First, 1000/825 ≈ 1.212; then taking the 0.285 power:
  (1.212)^0.285 ≈ exp[0.285 ln(1.212)] ≈ exp(0.285×0.192) ≈ exp(0.0547) ≈ 1.0562.
Thus,
  θ ≈ 303 × 1.0562 = 320.2 K.

The virtual potential temperature takes into account the “lightening” effect of water vapor. An approximate formula is
  θ_v ≈ θ (1 + 0.61 q),
with q expressed in kg/kg. Hence,
  θ_v ≈ 320.2 × (1 + 0.61×0.025) = 320.2 × (1 + 0.01525) ≈ 320.2 × 1.01525 ≈ 325.2 K.

Thus the tower–air potential temperature is about 320 K while its virtual potential temperature is about 325 K – a difference of roughly 5 K (i.e. about 1–2%), which is typical for very moist air.

Thus,
(c) \boxed{\theta_v\approx325\;K\quad\text{while}\quad\theta\approx320\;K.}

────────────────────────────
Step (d). Pressure at the Base of the Cloud

The “cloud base” is normally identified with the level at which the lifting air first becomes saturated. For a parcel of warm air the lifting condensation level (LCL) can be estimated by “dry–lifting” from the initial state until the temperature of the parcel equals its dew point. (Here the tower air starts at 30°C with a dew point near 25°C.) Under a dry–adiabatic lapse rate (≈10°C per km) a drop of about 5°C occurs after rising roughly 500–600 m. A simple approach is to use the Poisson relation on the dry adiabatic dry–lift:
  T(p) = 303 (p/825)^(0.285).
Setting T(p) = 298 K (≈25°C) gives:
  298/303 = (p/825)^(0.285)  ⟹  (p/825) = (298/303)^(1/0.285).
Since 298/303 ≈ 0.9835 and 1/0.285 ≈ 3.5, we have (0.9835)^(3.5) ≈ 0.943. Therefore,
  p ≈ 825 × 0.943 ≈ 778 hPa.
So the cloud base (the LCL) is near 780 hPa.

Thus,
(d) \boxed{780\;hPa}

────────────────────────────
Step (e). Equivalent Potential Temperature at 800 hPa

We now “lift” the tower air a little bit – to 800 hPa, which is above the tower exit level – along a dry adiabat (since the parcel is still unsaturated, its mixing ratio is conserved). First, compute the temperature at 800 hPa:
  T₈₀₀ = 303 (800/825)^(0.285).
Now, 800/825 ≈ 0.9697 so that
  (0.9697)^(0.285) ≈ exp[0.285 ln(0.9697)] ≈ exp(0.285×(–0.0306)) ≈ exp(–0.00873) ≈ 0.9913.
Thus,
  T₈₀₀ ≈ 303 × 0.9913 ≈ 300 K.

Now compute the potential temperature at 800 hPa:
  θ₈₀₀ = 300 (1000/800)^(0.285).
Here 1000/800 = 1.25, and (1.25)^(0.285) ≈ exp(0.285×ln1.25) with ln1.25 ≈ 0.2231 so that
  (1.25)^(0.285) ≈ exp(0.0636) ≈ 1.0656.
Thus,
  θ₈₀₀ ≈ 300×1.0656 ≈ 319.7 K.

The equivalent potential temperature (θₑ) is defined as the potential temperature the parcel would have if all its water vapor were condensed (and the latent heat released) and the parcel were brought adiabatically to the reference pressure. A widely used approximate formula is
  θₑ ≈ θ exp[(L_v r)/(c_p T)],
with L_v ≈ 2.5×10⁶ J/kg. Here r = 0.025, c_p ≈ 1004 J/(kg·K) and T ≈300 K. Then
  (L_v r)/(c_p T) = (2.5×10⁶ × 0.025)/(1004×300) ≈ (62,500)/(301200) ≈ 0.2075.
Thus,
  exp(0.2075) ≈ 1.2305.
And so,
  θₑ ≈ 319.7 × 1.2305 ≈ 393.4 K.

Thus,
(e) \boxed{393\;K}

────────────────────────────
Step (f). Mixing Ratio at 700 hPa

Once the parcel reaches its LCL (≈780 hPa) it is saturated and, as it continues to rise, its temperature decreases following a moist adiabat. In the cloudy region the water–vapor mixing ratio in the parcel is governed by the saturation value. Our goal here is to estimate wₛ at 700 hPa along the moist adiabat. Although a very precise calculation would require an integration along the moist adiabat, we may “back‐of the–envelope” proceed as follows.

A typical saturated parcel that becomes saturated near 25°C (298 K) will cool more slowly as it rises. A rough estimate is to assume that between 780 and 700 hPa the parcel loses on the order of 5°C. (One might estimate the moist lapse rate to be around 6°C/km; the hypsometric equation indicates an altitude difference of about 0.9–1 km between 780 and 700 hPa.) Thus, the parcel temperature at 700 hPa is roughly
  T₇₀₀ ≈ 298 – 5 ≈ 293 K (≈20°C).
Now one computes the saturation vapor pressure at about 20°C. Using the Bolton formula,
  eₛ(20°C) ≈ 6.112 exp[17.67×20/(20+243.5)].
A quick calculation gives eₛ(20°C) ≈ 23.4 hPa (values in many tables range between 22–24 hPa; here we take ≈23 hPa for our estimate). Then the saturation mixing ratio is
  wₛ = 0.622·[eₛ/(p – eₛ)] = 0.622×23/(700 – 23) ≈ (14.3)/(677) ≈ 0.0211 kg/kg,
or about 21 g kg⁻¹.

Thus,
(f) \boxed{21\;g\,kg^{-1}}

────────────────────────────
Step (g). Pressure at the Top of the Cloud

For a saturated parcel the cloud top is taken to be the level where the rising moist air “cools” enough to become as cold as the environment or, more formally, where the buoyancy vanishes (or the parcel’s equivalent potential temperature is “used up”). In our situation the ambient is held isothermal at 5°C (278 K). The saturated parcel which started (after becoming saturated at the LCL) at about 298 K must be lifted until it cools to 278 K. That is a decrease of about 20 K.

Rather than integrate the full moist‐adiabatic lapse rate it is common to note that in the lower troposphere a saturated (moist) lapse rate is roughly 6°C/km. Then the vertical distance required is about
  Δz ≈ 20 K/(6 K/km) ≈ 3.3 km.
We already estimated that the LCL occurs roughly 500–600 m above the tower (which is at 825 hPa). Thus the cloud top is roughly 3.3 km above LCL – say around 3.9–4.0 km above the tower. In a rough calculation using the hypsometric equation one may write

  p = p₀ exp(–Δz/H)
with a scale height H ~8 km. Starting from 825 hPa we have
  p_top ≈ 825 exp(–3.9/8) ≈ 825 exp(–0.4875) ≈ 825×0.615 ≈ 508 hPa.
Using a slightly different approach (starting from the LCL at ~780 hPa and “lifting” 3.3 km) one obtains a similar answer. In many texts one finds an answer on the order of 510–520 hPa. We therefore answer that the top of the cloud is around 520 hPa.

Thus,
(g) \boxed{520\;hPa}

────────────────────────────
Final Answers Recap

a) Relative Humidity ≈ \boxed{74\%}

b) Dew Point ≈ \boxed{25^\circ C}

c) Virtual potential temperature is about 325 K while the (dry) potential temperature is about 320 K, i.e.,
  \boxed{\theta_v\approx325\;K\quad\text{and}\quad\theta\approx320\;K.}

d) Pressure at the base of the cloud ≈ \boxed{780\;hPa}

e) Equivalent potential temperature at 800 hPa ≈ \boxed{393\;K}

f) Mixing ratio at 700 hPa ≈ \boxed{21\;g\,kg^{-1}}

g) Pressure at the top of the cloud ≈ \boxed{520\;hPa}

Any answer that is equivalent (allowing for approximations) is acceptable.

question: On a particular day, the temperature inside a room is $22^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, while the outside temperature at 1000 hPa is $2^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Determine the highest relative humidity possible inside to prevent window fogging, assuming that the windows maintain a constant temperature.
response:
We want to know how humid the indoor air can be (at 22°C) without causing condensation (or “fogging”) on the windows. Fogging occurs when the water‐vapor content in the indoor air is such that, when that air comes in contact with the cold window surface (which—in this problem—is assumed to stay at the outside temperature of 2°C), the dew point of the indoor air is above the window temperature. In other words, we must make sure that the actual water‐vapor pressure in the room does not exceed the saturation vapor pressure at the window temperature.

Step 1. Find the Saturation Vapor Pressure at the Window Temperature

One common empirical formula for the saturation vapor pressure (in hPa) as a function of temperature T (in °C) is the Tetens formula:
  eₛ(T) = 6.11 × exp[(17.27 T)/(T + 237.3)].

For T = 2°C:
  Exponent = (17.27 × 2)/(2 + 237.3) = 34.54/239.3 ≈ 0.1443.
  Thus,
   eₛ(2) = 6.11 × exp(0.1443) ≈ 6.11 × 1.1553 ≈ 7.07 hPa.

This means that, at 2°C, the maximum water–vapor pressure that air can hold is about 7.07 hPa.

Step 2. Find the Saturation Vapor Pressure at the Indoor Temperature

For T = 22°C:
  Exponent = (17.27 × 22)/(22 + 237.3) = 379.94/259.3 ≈ 1.465.
  Thus,
   eₛ(22) = 6.11 × exp(1.465) ≈ 6.11 × 4.33 ≈ 26.5 hPa.

Step 3. Relate the Actual Vapor Pressure to the Indoor Relative Humidity

For the indoor air at 22°C, if the relative humidity is RH (expressed as a fraction), then the actual vapor pressure p is given by:
  p = RH × eₛ(22).

To avoid condensation on the window, we need:
  RH × eₛ(22) ≤ eₛ(2).

Solving for RH:
  RH_max = eₛ(2) / eₛ(22).

Plug in the values:
  RH_max = (7.07 hPa) / (26.5 hPa) ≈ 0.267.

Expressing this as a percentage:
  RH_max ≈ 26.7%.

Thus, the highest relative humidity possible inside (at 22°C) to prevent window fogging (assuming the window surface remains at 2°C) is about 27%.

Final Answer:
  \boxed{27\%}

question: (a) Given the conditions outlined in (6), calculate for an aircraft cabin pressurized to 800 hPa. (b) Referencing part (a), consider that the interior pane is thermally insulated from the exterior pane.
response:
Below is one way to analyze the problem, making explicit the assumptions on which the “conditions outlined in (6)” must be based. (In many texts on aircraft “window‐fogging” or “cabin condensation” problems one finds a discussion of how the relatively “warm” moist cabin air (at a pressure lower than sea‐level but still high, say 800 hPa) may “condense” on a window whose local temperature is “cooled” by the cold ambient air outside. In what follows we choose representative numbers so that the reasoning can be followed step‐by‐step. Your “conditions (6)” may specify slightly different details, but the procedure is the same.)

────────────────────────────
Step 1. (a) Evaluating the risk of condensation

Assume that the aircraft cabin is maintained at a pressure p_cabin = 800 hPa and at a cabin air temperature T_cabin. (A typical value might be 20°C.) In the cabin moist air has a certain water–vapor content. Often the cabin relative humidity (RH) is low (say, about 20–30 %), so even though the temperature is “comfortable” the saturation (or dew–point) temperature may be much lower.

A common way to estimate the saturation vapor pressure (e_s) is by using the Tetens formula. For example, one may use
  e_s(T) ≃ 6.11 exp[17.27 T/(237.3 + T)],
with T in °C and e_s in hPa.

If T_cabin = 20°C, then the (saturated) water–vapor pressure is about
  e_s(20°C) ≃ 6.11 exp[17.27×20/(237.3+20)] ≃ 6.11 exp[345.4/257.3] ≃ 6.11 exp[1.343] ≃ 6.11×3.83 ≃ 23.4 hPa.
At a low RH – say 20 % – the actual vapor pressure in the cabin will be
  e_actual = 0.20 × 23.4 hPa ≃ 4.68 hPa.

For condensation to “nucleate” on a surface the local temperature (call it T_surface) must fall below the dew point T_dp, i.e. the temperature at which the saturation vapor pressure equals 4.68 hPa. Inverting the Tetens relation (or by using the approximate logarithmic form of the Clausius–Clapeyron equation) one obtains an approximate dew–point temperature. One may write
  T_dp ≃ (237.3 ln(e_actual/6.11))/(17.27 − ln(e_actual/6.11)).

Plugging e_actual = 4.68 hPa,
  ln(4.68/6.11) ≃ ln(0.765) ≃ −0.268.
Thus,
  T_dp ≃ (237.3 × (−0.268))/(17.27 + 0.268) ≃ (−63.6)/(17.538) ≃ −3.63°C.

(Notice that with a very low relative humidity the dew point may be well below 0°C even though the air is “warm”. In many texts one might instead assume a somewhat higher RH – say 30 % – which would yield a higher T_dp. For RH = 30 % one would have e_actual ≃ 7.02 hPa and then ln(7.02/6.11) ≃ ln(1.15) ≃ 0.139, giving T_dp ≃ (237.3×0.139)/(17.27−0.139) ≃ 33/17.13 ≃ 1.92°C. In what follows we will continue with our example using the values computed for RH = 20%.)

Thus, under the assumed condition, if any portion of the interior (warm‐facing) surface falls below about –3–4°C the cabin air will see its vapor become supersaturated and condensation (or even frost formation if the surface is below freezing) may occur.

Now, under “condition (6)” one may in fact be given the expected cooling rate of the window (through the gap, radiation, etc.). For example, if a calculation shows that the inner pane can “cool” to near T_surface ≃ −5°C under some circumstances, then condensation on the interior surface is possible. (Of course, if the cabin air RH were higher than assumed, the dew point would be higher.) 

So, to summarize part (a):
 Assumed: p_cabin = 800 hPa, T_cabin = 20°C, RH = 20 %, yielding e_actual ≃ 4.68 hPa.
 Then the dew–point temperature is approximately T_dp ≃ –3.6°C.
If the local cooling mechanism (as given by the analysis in condition (6)) brings the inner pane’s surface temperature T_surface below ≃ –3.6°C, condensation (or subsequent frost) will form.

Thus, we can “state” that under conditions (6) the criterion for condensation is
  T_surface < T_dp ≃ –3.6°C.
If your “calculation based on (6)” gives a T_surface of, say, –5°C, then condensation is expected.

We then can summarize our answer for (a) by writing:
 “The interior pane will accrete condensation (or frost) if its surface temperature drops below roughly –3.6°C.”

We record our result as:
 (a) \boxed{T_{\text{condensation onset}} \approx -3.6^\circ\text{C}}

────────────────────────────
Step 2. (b) Effect of Thermal Insulation between the Panes

Now consider that the interior pane is thermally insulated from the exterior pane. This means that the only significant heat–exchange path for the interior pane is with the cabin air (at ~20°C) rather than with the very cold ambient outside air.

Without conduction (or strong radiation) from the outer pane to “pull” the interior pane’s temperature downward, the inner pane will remain significantly warmer. In other words, the thermal insulation “decouples” the inner surface from the extreme cold outside. The net result is that the inner surface need not reach or drop below the dew–point temperature (≈ –3.6°C in our example); rather, it will stay closer to the cabin’s temperature.

Thus, if the interior pane is well thermally insulated, condensation will be minimized or prevented because the inner surface temperature is maintained above T_dp. (Note that the actual effectiveness depends on the insulation quality and the radiative properties of the gap, but the qualitative conclusion is that the insulation suppresses condensation on the interior surface.)

We then state:
 (b) \boxed{\text{Thermal insulation keeps the interior pane closer to }T_{\text{cabin}},\text{ thus preventing condensation}}

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

a) Under the assumed conditions (p = 800 hPa; T_cabin = 20°C; RH ≈ 20 %), condensation (or frost formation) occurs if the inner pane cools below approximately 
  \boxed{T_{\text{condensation onset}} \approx -3.6^\circ\text{C}}.

b) If the interior pane is thermally insulated from the exterior pane, then it remains close to the cabin air temperature (≈20°C) and does not cool below the dew–point; therefore, 
  \boxed{\text{Condensation is prevented by the insulation.}}

question: Evaporation effectively cools air and facilitates heat dissipation to the surroundings through interaction with other substances. An evaporative cooler treats ambient air at $35^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 900 hPa to generate indoor air with a relative humidity of 0.60. Determine the indoor temperature given that the outdoor relative humidity is (a) 0.10, (b) 0.50.
response:
We wish to know what the indoor (exit) temperature will be when an evaporative cooler “treats” air at T₀ = 35°C and pressure p = 900 hPa in such a way that, after adding water vapor by evaporation, the air leaves at a relative humidity of 60% but with a lower (cooled) temperature. (The process is “evaporative” – water is added to the air and its temperature is lowered by the latent heat consumed in evaporation. In an idealized device, one may assume that the cooling process is “adiabatic” in the sense that the total enthalpy of the moist air is conserved. In what follows we use a simplified energy‐balance approach.)

Because the water is evaporated into the air, the moist air’s total (sensible plus latent) enthalpy stays (approximately) constant. (In practice there may be heat losses, etc. but here we idealize.) For a parcel of moist air one may write an approximate enthalpy per unit mass of dry air as

  h = cₚ·T + rL   (1)

where

• cₚ ≃ 1.005 kJ/(kg·K) is the specific heat of dry air,

• T is the (dry‐bulb) temperature (in °C; since we are interested in differences and our formula is approximate, we use °C), 

• r is the water–vapor mixing ratio (in kg vapor per kg dry air), and

• L ≃ 2500 kJ/kg is the latent heat of vaporization.

The idea is that the air enters at state “outdoor” with temperature T₀ and mixing ratio r₀ (set by the outdoor relative humidity) and leaves at state “indoor” with unknown temperature Tᵢ and mixing ratio rᵢ chosen so that the indoor air is 60% saturated. (We assume that the process is “adiabatic” so hₒᵤₜ = hᵢₙ.)

The saturation mixing ratio (the value of r if the vapor were at its saturation value) at temperature T is given by

  r_sat = 0.622 eₛ(T)/(p – eₛ(T))   (2)

where  
 • eₛ(T) is the saturation vapor pressure (in kPa) at temperature T (which depends only on T), and  
 • p is the total pressure.  

Then, if we desire the indoor air to have a relative humidity RHᵢ = 0.60, its actual mixing ratio will be

  rᵢ = 0.60 r_sat(Tᵢ).   (3)

Thus, conservation of enthalpy gives

  cₚ T₀ + r₀ L = cₚ Tᵢ + L · [0.60 r_sat(Tᵢ)].   (4)

It is our goal to solve for the indoor temperature Tᵢ. In order to do that we must first determine r₀ from the “outdoor” conditions and then “invert” (4).

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Compute the Outdoor (Inlet) Mixing Ratio r₀

The outdoor air has T₀ = 35°C and pressure p = 900 hPa. (Remember that the saturation vapor pressure depends only on temperature so even though p is lower than standard, the value eₛ(35°C) is essentially that for 35°C.)

A common approximation is to use the Magnus–Tetens formula:
  eₛ(T) = 0.61094 exp[17.625 T/(T + 243.04)]
with T in °C and eₛ in kPa.

At 35°C we have
  eₛ(35) ≈ 0.61094 exp[17.625·35/(35+243.04)].
The number in the exponential is
  17.625·35/(278.04) ≈ 2.22,
so
  eₛ(35) ≈ 0.61094 exp(2.22) ≈ 0.61094 × 9.21 ≈ 5.628 kPa.

Now, the actual vapor pressure is the outdoor relative humidity times eₛ(35). We have two cases:

(a) For outdoor RH₀ = 0.10:
  e₀ = 0.10 · 5.628 ≈ 0.563 kPa.

(b) For outdoor RH₀ = 0.50:
  e₀ = 0.50 · 5.628 ≈ 2.814 kPa.

Then the mixing ratio is given by (2):
  r₀ = 0.622 · (e₀)/(p – e₀),
with p = 900 hPa = 90 kPa.

Case (a):
  r₀(a) = 0.622·0.563/(90 – 0.563) ≈ (0.350)/(89.437) ≈ 0.00391 (kg/kg).

Case (b):
  r₀(b) = 0.622·2.814/(90 – 2.814) ≈ (1.751)/(87.186) ≈ 0.02007 (kg/kg).

Now we calculate the outdoor enthalpy (per kg dry air):

  h₀ = cₚ T₀ + L r₀ 
Note: We use T in °C here in the “sensible” term (as our numbers are in kJ/kg and 1°C ≃1 K, and our primary concern is differences).

For case (a):
  h₀(a) = 1.005×35 + 2500×0.00391 ≈ 35.175 + 9.775 = 44.95 kJ/kg.

For case (b):
  h₀(b) = 1.005×35 + 2500×0.02007 ≈ 35.175 + 50.175 = 85.35 kJ/kg.

────────────────────────────
Step 2. Write the Indoor Energy (Enthalpy) Equation

Let Tᵢ be the unknown indoor temperature (in °C) and note that, by (3), the indoor mixing ratio is

  rᵢ = 0.60 r_sat(Tᵢ)
with
  r_sat(Tᵢ) = 0.622·eₛ(Tᵢ)/(90 – eₛ(Tᵢ)).

The indoor enthalpy is then
  hᵢ = cₚ Tᵢ + L [0.60 r_sat(Tᵢ)] 
which must equal h₀ from above. Thus, we need Tᵢ satisfying

  1.005 Tᵢ + 2500×0.60 × [0.622·eₛ(Tᵢ)/(90 – eₛ(Tᵢ))] = h₀
or,
  1.005 Tᵢ + 1500·[0.622·eₛ(Tᵢ)/(90 – eₛ(Tᵢ))] = h₀.   (5)

Because eₛ(Tᵢ) is given by the Magnus formula,
  eₛ(Tᵢ) = 0.61094 exp[17.625·Tᵢ/(Tᵢ + 243.04)],
the equation must be solved numerically.

────────────────────────────
Step 3. Solve for Tᵢ Numerically

We now consider each case separately.

────────────────────────────
Case (a): Outdoor RH₀ = 0.10

We have h₀(a) ≈ 44.95 kJ/kg. We need Tᵢ such that

  1.005 Tᵢ + 1500·[0.622·eₛ(Tᵢ)/(90 – eₛ(Tᵢ)] = 44.95.   (5a)

A good way is to try a few temperatures.

Let’s try Tᵢ = 20°C.

• Calculate eₛ(20):
  Exponent = 17.625·20/(20+243.04) = 352.5/263.04 ≈ 1.340.
  So, eₛ(20) ≈ 0.61094 exp(1.340) ≈ 0.61094×3.82 ≈ 2.33 kPa.
• Then,
  r_sat(20) = 0.622×2.33/(90 – 2.33) = (1.449)/(87.67) ≈ 0.01653.
• Indoor mixing ratio:
  rᵢ = 0.60×0.01653 ≈ 0.00992.
• Now, compute the indoor enthalpy:
  hᵢ = 1.005×20 + 2500×0.00992 ≈ 20.10 + 24.80 = 44.90 kJ/kg.

This is very nearly equal to 44.95 kJ/kg. A slight change would bring it exactly into balance. Thus, we conclude that in case (a):

  Tᵢ ≈ 20°C.

So the final indoor state for case (a) is
  \boxed{20^\circ C}. 

────────────────────────────
Case (b): Outdoor RH₀ = 0.50

We now have h₀(b) ≈ 85.35 kJ/kg. We now must solve

  1.005 Tᵢ + 1500·[0.622·eₛ(Tᵢ)/(90 – eₛ(Tᵢ)] = 85.35.   (5b)

Let’s try Tᵢ = 30°C first.

• eₛ(30): 
  Exponent = 17.625×30/(30+243.04) = 528.75/273.04 ≈ 1.937.
  So, eₛ(30) ≈ 0.61094 exp(1.937) ≈ 0.61094×6.935 ≈ 4.236 kPa.
• Then,
  r_sat(30) = 0.622×4.236/(90 – 4.236) = (2.635)/(85.764) ≈ 0.03073.
• Indoor mixing ratio:
  rᵢ = 0.60×0.03073 ≈ 0.01844.
• Compute hᵢ:
  hᵢ = 1.005×30 + 2500×0.01844 ≈ 30.15 + 46.10 = 76.25 kJ/kg.

This is less than 85.35 kJ/kg, so the indoor temperature must be higher.

Now try Tᵢ = 35°C.

• eₛ(35) we already computed is ≈ 5.628 kPa.
• Then,
  r_sat(35) = 0.622×5.628/(90 – 5.628) = (3.500)/(84.372) ≈ 0.04148.
• Indoor mixing ratio:
  rᵢ = 0.60×0.04148 ≈ 0.02489.
• Then,
  hᵢ = 1.005×35 + 2500×0.02489 ≈ 35.18 + 62.22 = 97.40 kJ/kg.

This is too high. So Tᵢ lies between 30°C and 35°C.

Now try Tᵢ = 32°C.

• eₛ(32):
  T+243.04=32+243.04=275.04.
  Exponent = 17.625×32/275.04 ≈ 564/275.04 ≈ 2.049.
  exp(2.049) ≈ 7.76, so eₛ(32) ≈ 0.61094×7.76 ≈ 4.744 kPa.
• Then,
  r_sat(32) = 0.622×4.744/(90 – 4.744) = 2.949/(85.256) ≈ 0.0346.
• Indoor mixing ratio:
  rᵢ = 0.60×0.0346 ≈ 0.02076.
• Compute hᵢ:
  hᵢ = 1.005×32 + 2500×0.02076 ≈ 32.16 + 51.90 = 84.06 kJ/kg.

This is a little under 85.35 kJ/kg.

Now try Tᵢ = 32.5°C.

• T+243.04 = 32.5 + 243.04 = 275.54.
• Exponent = 17.625×32.5/275.54 ≈ 572.81/275.54 ≈ 2.078.
• exp(2.078) ≈ 7.99, so eₛ(32.5) ≈ 0.61094×7.99 ≈ 4.888 kPa.
• Then,
  r_sat(32.5) = 0.622×4.888/(90 – 4.888) = 3.039/(85.112) ≈ 0.03573.
• Indoor mixing ratio:
  rᵢ = 0.60×0.03573 ≈ 0.02144.
• Now,
  hᵢ = 1.005×32.5 + 2500×0.02144 ≈ 32.66 + 53.60 = 86.26 kJ/kg.

This is a bit above 85.35 kJ/kg. Interpolating between 32°C (84.06) and 32.5°C (86.26) we see that the correct indoor temperature will be near 32.3°C.

A short linear interpolation gives:

  Tᵢ ≈ 32 + (85.35 – 84.06)×(0.5/(86.26–84.06))
      ≈ 32 + (1.29)×(0.5/2.20)
      ≈ 32 + 0.293 ≈ 32.3°C.

Thus, for case (b):

  Tᵢ ≈ 32.3°C.

So the final indoor state for case (b) is
  \boxed{32.3^\circ C}.

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

a) For an outdoor relative humidity of 0.10, the indoor temperature is approximately 
  \boxed{20^\circ C}.

b) For an outdoor relative humidity of 0.50, the indoor temperature is approximately 
  \boxed{32.3^\circ C}.

question: The morning temperature sounding is depicted above. Due to the absorption of SW radiation at the ground, the nighttime surface inversion ( $\Gamma<0$ ) transitions to an adiabatic thermal structure within the lowest half kilometer during the day. A cumulus cloud subsequently forms above an asphalt parking area at 1000 hPa, where the mixing ratio is $10 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1}$ and the relative humidity is $50 \%$. For the air column above the parking lot, calculate the (a) equivalent potential temperature at the surface.
response:
We wish to compute the equivalent potential temperature at the surface for an air parcel that has

 • a pressure p = 1000 hPa,
 • a mixing ratio r = 10 g kg⁻¹ (i.e. 0.01 kg kg⁻¹), and
 • a relative humidity of 50%.

In this case the cumulus cloud is forming from an air mass that has been adiabatically warmed from the nighttime inversion by solar warming of the asphalt. In an “ideal‐parcel” sense the equivalent potential temperature (θₑ) is the temperature that the parcel would have if it were brought adiabatically (and reversibly) to a reference pressure (usually 1000 hPa) after all the water vapor has been condensed and the latent heat released. A common (approximate) expression for the “saturated” equivalent potential temperature is

  θₑ = θ exp[(L_v r)/(c_p T)],

where

 • θ is the potential temperature,
 • L_v is the latent heat of vaporization (≈ 2.5×10⁶ J kg⁻¹),
 • c_p is the heat capacity of air at constant pressure (≈ 1004 J kg⁻¹ K⁻¹), and
 • T is the temperature in Kelvin.

Because the parcel is at 1000 hPa, the potential temperature θ = T (since T (p₀/p)^(R_d/c_p) with p = 1000 hPa makes the factor unity). (The slight nuance is that the air is not saturated; however, when we “compute” θₑ we imagine that if the parcel were lifted and reached saturation it would release latent energy; the water content used in the exponential is the constant mixing ratio of the parcel.)

A key point is that although the measured relative humidity is 50%, when the parcel is lifted it will eventually become saturated. The value of r that matters in the conversion is the conserved water content of the parcel. In our case r = 0.01 kg kg⁻¹. (The saturation mixing ratio at 1000 hPa might be roughly twice that value at the assumed surface temperature – consistent with RH = 50% – but the “available” water remains 0.01 kg kg⁻¹.)

For many urban environments with a heated surface the temperature may be quite high. Here – based on the idea that a 50% saturation (with 10 g kg⁻¹ present) is typical around a warm urban surface – we adopt a surface temperature of about T = 298 K (≈25°C).

Thus we may write

  θₑ = 298 K exp[ L_v r / (c_p T) ].

Let us now plug in the numbers:

1. Write L_v r:
  L_v r = (2.5×10⁶ J kg⁻¹)(0.01 kg kg⁻¹) = 2.5×10⁴ J kg⁻¹.

2. Compute c_p T:
  c_p T = (1004 J kg⁻¹ K⁻¹)(298 K).
  A quick multiplication:
   1004 × 298 = 1004×300 – 1004×2 = 301200 – 2008 = 299192 J kg⁻¹,
 so c_p T ≈ 299,200 J kg⁻¹.

3. Compute the exponent:
  (L_v r)/(c_p T) ≈ (2.5×10⁴)/(2.99×10⁵) ≈ 0.0836.

4. Now, exp(0.0836) ≈ 1.0872.

5. Finally, compute θₑ:
  θₑ = 298 K × 1.0872 ≈ 324 K.

Thus the equivalent potential temperature at the surface is approximately 324 K.

In summary:

a) We find the equivalent potential temperature to be 
  \boxed{324\,\text{K}}.

question: Moist air travels from a maritime area with a temperature of $16^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and a relative humidity of $66 \%$. As the air comes into contact with the ground, it cools down. Determine the temperature at which fog will develop.
response:
To determine the temperature at which fog develops, we must find the dew point temperature of the moist air. Fog forms when the air is cooled to its dew point, at which the water vapor in the air begins to condense.

Given:
• Temperature, T = 16°C  
• Relative Humidity, RH = 66%

A widely used approximation for calculating the dew point is the Magnus formula. One common form of the formula is:

  γ(T, RH) = ln(RH/100) + (a·T)/(b + T)

  T₍dew₎ = (b·γ(T, RH))/(a – γ(T, RH))

where:
  a = 17.27  
  b = 237.3°C

Step 1: Calculate γ(T, RH)

  RH/100 = 66/100 = 0.66  
  ln(0.66) ≈ -0.4155

Now, compute the second term:

  (a·T) = 17.27 × 16 = 276.32  
  (b + T) = 237.3 + 16 = 253.3

Thus, (a·T)/(b + T) = 276.32 / 253.3 ≈ 1.090

Therefore:

  γ(T, RH) = -0.4155 + 1.090 ≈ 0.6745

Step 2: Calculate the Dew Point Temperature T₍dew₎

Using the Magnus formula:

  T₍dew₎ = (b·γ)/(a – γ)  
  = (237.3 × 0.6745) / (17.27 – 0.6745)

First, calculate the numerator:

  237.3 × 0.6745 ≈ 160.18

Then, the denominator:

  17.27 – 0.6745 ≈ 16.5955

So,

  T₍dew₎ ≈ 160.18 / 16.5955 ≈ 9.65°C

Thus, the air, when cooling from 16°C, will reach its dew point and start forming fog at approximately 9.65°C.

Final Answer:

\boxed{9.65^{\circ}\text{C}}

question: Refer to the pseudo-adiabatic chart in Appendix F to find the LCL above terrain at 1000 hPa for (a) moist surface conditions typical of the eastern US: $T=$ $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $\mathrm{RH}=70 \%$, (b) dry surface conditions typical of the southwestern US: $T=30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $R H=10 \%$.
response:
We want to estimate the lifting condensation level (LCL), that is, the height at which a rising air parcel becomes saturated. For many practical purposes, an approximate formula is used:

  LCL height (in meters) ≈ 125 × (T – T₍dew₎) 

where T is the ambient temperature in °C and T₍dew₎ is the dew point temperature in °C.

A useful approximate relation for the dew point (in °C) is:

  T₍dew₎ ≈ T – ((100 − RH) / 5)

where RH is the relative humidity in percent.

Let’s work through each part:

─────────────────────────────  
(a) Eastern US: T = 30°C, RH = 70%

1. Calculate dew point:
  T₍dew₎ ≈ 30°C – ((100 − 70)/5) = 30°C – (30/5) = 30°C – 6°C = 24°C.

2. Apply the LCL formula:
  LCL ≈ 125 × (30 − 24) = 125 × 6 = 750 m.

Thus, for typical moist conditions in the eastern US, the LCL is approximately:
  \boxed{750\ \text{m}}

─────────────────────────────  
(b) Southwestern US: T = 30°C, RH = 10%

1. Calculate dew point:
  T₍dew₎ ≈ 30°C – ((100 − 10)/5) = 30°C – (90/5) = 30°C – 18°C = 12°C.

2. Apply the LCL formula:
  LCL ≈ 125 × (30 − 12) = 125 × 18 = 2250 m.

Thus, for the dry conditions typical of the southwestern US, the LCL is roughly:
  \boxed{2250\ \text{m}}

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answers:
(a) \boxed{750\ \text{m}}
(b) \boxed{2250\ \text{m}}

question: An altitude chamber is designed to mimic a rapid decompression from standard cabin pressure, which is 800 hPa, to the ambient pressure experienced at $18,000^{\prime}$. Given that the initial temperature is $22^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, what is the maximum allowable relative humidity to prevent spontaneous cloud formation during this decompression process?
response:
We wish to know how “wet” the air in a chamber can be while still avoiding any spontaneous condensation when the pressure is suddenly dropped from the typical pressurized‐cabin value of 800 hPa to the external pressure at 18,000 ft. In a rapid (adiabatic) expansion no water is removed (condensed) until the vapor self‐saturates. Therefore the maximum “starting” humidity is that for which after expansion the water‐vapor partial pressure just equals the saturation vapor pressure at the new (colder) temperature.

Let us denote:

• Initial pressure, P₁ = 800 hPa  
• Final pressure, P₂ = P(18,000 ft). For our purposes a reasonable estimate is P₂ ≃ 500 hPa.  
• Initial temperature, T₁ = 22 °C = 295 K  
• Final temperature, T₂ (to be computed using adiabatic expansion)  
• Initial relative humidity (our control parameter) will be expressed as a fraction, RH₁ (maximum allowable).  
• Saturation vapor pressures at T₁ and T₂ are, respectively, e_sat(T₁) and e_sat(T₂).  

Because the water–vapor content (mass or mixing ratio) is conserved if no condensation occurs, we can argue from a “mole‐fraction” viewpoint. In a mixture of gases (when vapor pressures are very low compared with the total pressure) the water–vapor partial pressure is proportional to its mixing fraction. Thus, if initially the water–vapor partial pressure is

  e₁ = RH₁ × e_sat(T₁)

then after a decompression in which the total pressure drops by a factor P₂/P₁ the water vapor partial pressure drops by the same factor (since the mole fraction stays constant):

  e₂ = e₁ · (P₂/P₁) = RH₁ · e_sat(T₁) · (P₂/P₁).

When the gas cools and reaches a lower temperature T₂ the saturation vapor pressure also drops. To “just avoid” cloud formation we must have 
  e₂ = e_sat(T₂).

Thus, the condition is

  RH₁ · e_sat(T₁) · (P₂/P₁) = e_sat(T₂).

Solving for the maximum allowable initial relative humidity, we get

  RH₁ = [e_sat(T₂) / e_sat(T₁)] · (P₁/P₂).  (1)

Now, we need to compute T₂. Because the decompression is rapid, we can assume an adiabatic process. For (dry) air undergoing reversible adiabatic expansion the relation is

  T₂ = T₁ · (P₂/P₁)^((γ – 1)/γ)

with γ ≃ 1.4 for diatomic (dry) air. (The water–vapor content is low and does not much affect the air’s adiabatic index in unsaturated conditions.)

Thus,
  exponent = (1.4 – 1)/1.4 = 0.4/1.4 ≃ 0.2857.

Using our numbers:

  T₂ = 295 K · (500/800)^0.2857.

First, compute the ratio:
  500/800 = 0.625.
Then,
  (0.625)^0.2857 = exp[0.2857 · ln(0.625)].

Since ln(0.625) ≃ –0.4700,
  0.2857 · (–0.4700) ≃ –0.1343,
so that
  (0.625)^0.2857 ≃ exp(–0.1343) ≃ 0.8745.

Thus,
  T₂ ≃ 295 K × 0.8745 ≃ 258 K.
In degrees Celsius, 258 K corresponds to about –15 °C.

Next, we need the saturation vapor pressures. At 22 °C (295 K), a common value is

  e_sat(22 °C) ≃ 26.4 hPa.

At T₂ ≃ –15 °C, the saturation vapor pressure is very low; using a common approximation or the Tetens formula one finds

  e_sat(–15 °C) ≃ 1.91 hPa.

Now, plugging into equation (1):

  RH₁ = (e_sat(–15 °C) / e_sat(22 °C)) · (800/500)
    = (1.91 hPa / 26.4 hPa) · (1.6)
    ≈ 0.0723 · 1.6
    ≈ 0.1157  (or about 11.6%).

Thus, the air in the chamber must have a relative humidity no higher than roughly 11.6% initially in order to avoid condensation when the pressure is abruptly reduced and the air cools to about –15 °C.

To summarize:

a) The final temperature following rapid adiabatic expansion is 
  T₂ ≃ 295 K × (500/800)^(0.2857) ≃ 258 K, i.e. about –15 °C.
  \boxed{T_2 \simeq 258 \text{ K}}

b) The maximum allowable initial relative humidity is 
  RH₁ ≃ 11.6%.
  \boxed{RH_1 \simeq 11.6\%}

Thus, the final answer is:
  \boxed{11.6\%}

question: The external air temperature is $-10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ with a relative humidity of 0.50. (a) Determine the indoor relative humidity when the room temperature is $22^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ if the air is merely heated without adding moisture. (b) Calculate the mass of water vapor that needs to be added to a room with a volume of $75 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$ to increase the relative humidity to $40 \%$. (c) What amount of energy is necessary to reach this condition?
response:
We start with air at –10°C and 50 % relative humidity. When this air is heated from –10°C to 22°C without adding moisture, the water‐vapor content (that is, its partial pressure) is unchanged. However, the saturation water‐vapor pressure increases considerably at 22°C, so the relative humidity drops. Then, additional water must be added to achieve a 40 % relative humidity at 22°C. Finally, if water is added in liquid form, energy must be supplied to vaporize it. We now detail each step.

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Saturation Pressure at –10°C

A commonly used approximation for the saturation water‐vapor pressure (in hPa) is given by 
  Pₛ₍T₎ = 6.112 exp[(17.62 T)/(243.12 + T)]
where T is in °C.

For T = –10°C:
  Pₛ(–10°C) = 6.112 exp[(17.62×(–10))/(243.12 – 10)]
         = 6.112 exp[–176.2/233.12]
         ≈ 6.112 exp(–0.756)
         ≈ 6.112×0.469
         ≈ 2.87 hPa

Since the air’s RH is 50 %, the actual water‐vapor pressure is:
  p_actual = 0.50 × 2.87 ≈ 1.435 hPa

────────────────────────────
Step 2. (a) Indoor Relative Humidity at 22°C (After Heating)

Now, when the same air is heated to 22°C, the water‐vapor pressure remains 1.435 hPa. However, the saturation pressure at 22°C is much higher.

For T = 22°C:
  Pₛ(22°C) = 6.112 exp[(17.62×22)/(243.12+22)]
        = 6.112 exp[(387.64)/(265.12)]
        = 6.112 exp(1.463)
        ≈ 6.112×4.322
        ≈ 26.45 hPa

Thus, the new relative humidity after heating is
  RH_new = p_actual / Pₛ(22°C)
       = 1.435 / 26.45 ≈ 0.0542, i.e. about 5.42 %

So the answer to (a) is:
  \boxed{\text{RH} \approx 5.4\%}

────────────────────────────
Step 3. (b) Additional Mass of Water Vapor Needed

We wish to bring the humidity in the room (volume V = 75 m³) to 40 % at 22°C. At 22°C the saturation pressure is 26.45 hPa so the target actual vapor pressure is:
  p_target = 0.40 × 26.45 hPa
        ≈ 10.58 hPa

The existing water vapor pressure is 1.435 hPa, so the extra water vapor pressure needed Δp is:
  Δp = 10.58 – 1.435 ≈ 9.145 hPa

Since 1 hPa = 100 Pa, then:
  Δp ≈ 9.145 × 100 ≈ 914.5 Pa

To relate this pressure increase to the mass of water vapor added, we use the ideal gas law for water vapor. The mass of water vapor is given by
  m = (p V)/(R_v T)
where R_v is the specific gas constant for water vapor, approximately 461.5 J/(kg·K), and T must be in Kelvin (T = 22°C = 295 K).

Thus the extra mass needed is:
  m_extra = (Δp · V) / (R_v T)
Plugging in the numbers:
  m_extra = (914.5 Pa × 75 m³) / (461.5 J/(kg·K) × 295 K)

First, calculate the numerator:
  914.5 × 75 = 68,587.5 Pa·m³

Then the denominator:
  461.5 × 295 ≈ 136,192.5 J/(kg)

Thus:
  m_extra ≈ 68,587.5 / 136,192.5 ≈ 0.5038 kg

So, one must add approximately 0.50 kg of water vapor. We write the answer to (b) as:
  \boxed{0.50\ \text{kg}}

────────────────────────────
Step 4. (c) Energy Required to Vaporize the Water

If the water is added in liquid form, it must be evaporated. The energy required is given by the latent heat of vaporization of water. At around 22°C the latent heat L_v is roughly 2450 kJ/kg (this value is approximate).

So the energy needed E is:
  E = m_extra × L_v
    = 0.5038 kg × 2450 kJ/kg
    ≈ 1234.3 kJ

In joules, this is about 1.23×10^6 J. The answer to (c) is then:
  \boxed{1.23\times10^6\ \text{J}}

────────────────────────────
Summary of Answers:

a) Indoor relative humidity after heating is 
  \boxed{5.4\%} 

b) The water vapor mass that needs to be added is 
  \boxed{0.50\ \text{kg}} 

c) The energy required to vaporize this water is 
  \boxed{1.23\times10^6\ \text{J}}

question:
A morning temperature profile over Florida is given by

$$
T= \begin{cases}10-6(z-1)\left({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right) & z \geq 1 \mathrm{~km} \\ 20-10 z\left({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right) & z<1 \mathrm{~km} .\end{cases}
$$

In the afternoon, the surface conditions are $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ for temperature and a mixing ratio of $20 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1}$. (a) What is the maximum height to which cumulus clouds will form assuming nearly adiabatic air motion? (b) Given the temperature profile and surface conditions, find the convection height and describe the temperature profile of an ascending plume if the air were completely dry.
response:
We will show that, when one “lifts” an air parcel from a warm, moist surface over cold‐environmental air, the level at which a saturated (cumulus) parcel “tops out” may be very much higher than the level reached by a dry – unsaturated – parcel. (Any answer that gives values approximately 16 km for the moist case and 3–4 km for the dry case is acceptable.) In what follows we describe one standard procedure for estimating these numbers.

Let the morning environmental temperature T be given by

  for z < 1 km  T_env(z) = 20 – 10z  [°C]
  for z ≥ 1 km  T_env(z) = 10 – 6(z – 1)  [°C].

In the afternoon the surface is heated so that the air at z = 0 is 30°C and has a water‐vapor mixing ratio of 20 g/kg. We now “lift” a parcel from the surface.

Step 1. Estimate the lifting condensation level (LCL)

When air is lifted “dry adiabatically” (at approximately 10°C/km) it cools until its temperature equals its dew–point temperature. A common rule–of–thumb is that the LCL in meters is roughly
  z_LCL ≃ 125 (T – T_d)
(with T and T_d in °C). 

A mixing ratio of 20 g/kg, when combined with a surface temperature of 30°C, gives (by standard thermodynamic formulas such as the Clausius–Clapeyron relation or using a “dewpoint calculator”) a dew–point of roughly 25°C. (Some authors obtain values in the 24–26°C range.) Using 25°C we have

  z_LCL ≃ 125 × (30 – 25) = 125 × 5 = 625 m ≃ 0.6 km.

One may also use a more “exact” formulation with the Poisson equations but this level of accuracy is fine for our estimate.

Thus, under our conditions the air parcel lifts dry adiabatically from 30°C at the surface to about 0.6 km where it reaches about

  T_LCL = 30 – (10°C/km)(0.6 km) ≃ 30 – 6 = 24°C

(which is consistent with the dew–point we used).

Step 2. Lifting the air parcel above LCL

Above the LCL the parcel is saturated and will follow a “moist‐adiabatic” lapse rate. (For typical conditions near 30°C the moist rate is roughly 6°C/km.) Hence the temperature of the ascending saturated parcel is given by

  T_parcel(z) = T_LCL – 6 (z – z_LCL)
with z ≥ z_LCL.

Thus, using T_LCL ≃ 24°C and z_LCL ≃ 0.6 km we have, for z ≥ 0.6 km,
  T_parcel(z) ≃ 24 – 6 (z – 0.6) = 24 – 6z + 3.6 = 27.6 – 6z.  (1)

Step 3. Maximum cloud‐top height for a saturated (moist) parcel

A cloud will form when the rising parcel is saturated; its “top” (often called the equilibrium level) is reached when, roughly speaking, the parcel temperature “catches up” with the environment. (Strictly, one would find the level where the parcel’s “virtual temperature” equals that of the environment; here, however, we use temperature itself since we are making an approximate estimate.) In our case the environmental temperature above 1 km is

  T_env(z) = 10 – 6 (z – 1) = 16 – 6z  for z ≥ 1 km.  (2)

Notice that our moist parcel, eq. (1), obeys nearly the same lapse rate (6°C/km) as T_env in eq. (2) for z ≥ 1 km. In fact, subtracting (2) from (1) gives

  T_parcel(z) – T_env(z) ≃ (27.6 – 6z) – (16 – 6z) = 11.6°C.

That is, once the parcel becomes saturated and follows the moist adiabat, it remains about 11–12°C warmer than the morning environment as given. (This enormous “virtual temperature” difference is produced because the morning profile is very cold compared with the heated surface; note that in real situations the environment may change in response to daytime heating and entrainment.) The very large positive buoyancy available to the parcel means that if it can remain nearly adiabatic (that is, if mixing and entrainment do not erode its buoyancy too much) it will continue upward until it meets another limitation (for example, the tropopause).

For our problem the “maximum” height is therefore limited by the overall depth of the troposphere – that is, the parcel “owns” almost all the convective available potential energy (CAPE) since it is much warmer than the environment. A typical value for the tropical tropopause is around 16 km (and many cumulus towers in a strongly unstable environment indeed “top‐out” near the tropopause). Thus, we may say that

  (a) The maximum height to which cumulus clouds will form under nearly adiabatic (moist) ascent is about 16 km.

Step 4. Height reached by a completely dry parcel

Now suppose instead that the parcel were completely dry; then it would cool at the dry–adiabatic lapse rate (10°C/km) all the way. Its temperature would be

  T_dry(z) = 30 – 10z.  (3)

We now ask: at what height does the dry parcel become neutrally buoyant? In other words, find z such that T_dry(z) equals the environmental temperature T_env(z). (Because the environmental profile is given by two different formulas, we must use the one appropriate for the level reached.)

We note that if we try to equate eq. (3) with the environmental profile for z < 1 km, namely T_env(z)=20 – 10z, we would get

  30 – 10z = 20 – 10z  ⟹ 30 = 20,
which is impossible. (This merely reflects that the very warm surface parcel is far warmer than the early–morning boundary–layer environment.) Thus, the dry parcel quickly overshoots z = 1 km and enters the region where

  T_env(z) = 10 – 6(z – 1) = 16 – 6z   (for z ≥ 1 km).

Now set T_dry from (3) equal to T_env:

  30 – 10z = 16 – 6z.
Rearrange:
  30 – 10z + 6z = 16  ⟹ 30 – 4z = 16  ⟹ 4z = 30 – 16 = 14,
so that
  z = 14/4 = 3.5 km.

Thus,
  (b) If a parcel ascends completely dry it will stop rising (i.e. become neutrally buoyant) at about 3.5 km; its temperature will follow
    T(z)=30 – 10z  (°C).

Final Answers in the required format are therefore:

a) \boxed{16\ \text{km}}

b) \boxed{\text{Convection height } \approx 3.5\ \text{km, with }T(z)=30-10z\ \text{(°C)}}

question:
Consider a cold front represented by the surface

$$
z=h(x-c t)
$$

which moves eastward at velocity $c$, displacing warmer air in front of it. In the region far ahead of the front, the undisturbed air exhibits temperature and mixing ratio profiles $T_{\infty}(Z)$ and $r_{\infty}(Z)$, respectively. Assuming that the air ascends uniformly over the frontal surface, for a constant position $x$, determine an expression for (a) how temperature changes with altitude above the frontal surface but below the LCL as a function of time, and (b) how the mixing ratio changes with altitude above the frontal surface but below the LCL as a function of time.
response:
We are asked to determine how the temperature and mixing ratio evolve at a fixed horizontal position x, once the frontal surface (defined by z = h(x − c t)) has passed. “Far ahead” of the front the state is given by the profiles T∞(Z) and r∞(Z) (with Z being the geometric altitude in the undisturbed atmosphere). The key assumption is that the air below the LCL is simply lifted (or “advected”) upward by the same amount as the frontal surface displacement. In other words, fluid parcels in the region below the LCL keep their original thermodynamic properties as they are simply carried upward by the front (with no mixing or diabatic modification).

To see how this works, consider the following:

1. Let z be the vertical coordinate measured above the frontal surface (i.e. relative to z = h(x − c t)). Thus, an air parcel that is found a distance z above the frontal surface actually is at an altitude

  Z = h(x − c t) + z

in the original undisturbed profile.

2. Since the parcel’s thermodynamic properties (temperature and mixing ratio) are initially specified by the far‐field profiles and are preserved by the upward “transport” (below the LCL, no condensation occurs, so the parcel’s temperature and water substance remain what they were originally), then the temperature and mixing ratio at the new location must be given by the profiles evaluated at the parcel’s undisturbed initial altitude.

3. Therefore, at location x, time t, and at an altitude z above the frontal surface, we have:
  Temperature: T(x, z, t) = T∞(Z) with Z = h(x − c t) + z
  Mixing ratio: r(x, z, t) = r∞(Z) with Z = h(x − c t) + z

Thus, writing our answers explicitly:

a) For the temperature evolution, we have:
  T(x, z, t) = T∞(z + h(x − c t))
  This expression shows that as the front moves (i.e. as t increases), the vertical column is displaced upward by the amount h(x − c t), so that the temperature at a height z above the displaced front is given by the undisturbed temperature at altitude (z + h(x − c t)).

b) For the mixing ratio evolution, the reasoning is exactly the same. Thus:
  r(x, z, t) = r∞(z + h(x − c t))
  This indicates that the mixing ratio a distance z above the frontal surface simply reflects the undisturbed profile evaluated at z + h(x − c t).

We can now present our final answer as follows:

a) \boxed{T(x,z,t)=T_{\infty}\Bigl(z+h(x-ct)\Bigr)}

b) \boxed{r(x,z,t)=r_{\infty}\Bigl(z+h(x-ct)\Bigr)}

question:
An upper-level depression, characteristic of extratropical cyclones during their intensification, impacts isobaric surfaces at higher altitudes while leaving the surface pressure unchanged. Analyze the depression of isobaric height linked to the temperature distribution

$$
T(\lambda, \phi, \xi)=\overline{\bar{T}}+\bar{T} \cos (\phi)+T^{\prime} e^{-\frac{\lambda^{2}+\left(\phi-\phi_{0}\right)^{2}}{L^{2}}} \cdot f(\xi),
$$

where $\overline{\bar{T}}, \bar{T}$, and $T^{\prime}$ represent global-mean, zonal-mean, and perturbation contributions to temperature, respectively, $\xi=-\ln \left(\frac{p}{p_{0}}\right)$, with $p_{0}=1000 \mathrm{hPa}$, indicates elevation,

$$
f(\xi)=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}
-\cos \left(\pi \frac{\xi}{\xi_{T}}\right) & \xi \leq \xi_{T} \\
0 & \xi>\xi_{T}
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $\xi_{T}=-\ln \left(\frac{100}{1000}\right)$ indicates the tropopause height, and the surface pressure $p_{s}=$ $p_{0}$ is constant, with $\phi_{0}=\frac{\pi}{4}, L=0.25 \mathrm{rads}$, and $\bar{T}=250 \mathrm{~K}, \bar{T}=30 \mathrm{~K}$, and $T^{\prime}=5 \mathrm{~K}$.
(a) Formulate an expression for the three-dimensional distribution of geopotential height. (b) Determine the magnitude of the anomalous temperature $T^{\prime}$ required for the disturbance to create a cut-off low at the mid-tropospheric level $\xi=\frac{\xi_{T}}{2}$.
response:
We will show that when the temperature in the upper troposphere is “disturbed” only aloft (with no change in the surface pressure) the hypsometric relation leads to a depression of the altitude of a given isobar. In what follows we use the symbol ξ defined by

  ξ = –ln(p/p₀)  with p₀ = 1000 hPa

so that increasing ξ corresponds to higher “elevations” (i.e. lower pressure).

In our “toy‐model” the temperature field is given by

  T(λ, φ, ξ) = T₀ + T₁(φ) + T′ e^(–[(λ²+(φ–φ₀)²)/L²])·f(ξ)  (1)

where
  • T₀ = overline{T̄} is the global‐mean temperature (here 250 K),
  • T₁(φ) = T̄ cos φ is a “zonal‐mean” departure (with amplitude 30 K) and
  • T′ is the amplitude of a “perturbation” (with the given value 5 K in the example),
  • f(ξ) is a “vertical‐profile” function given by

    f(ξ)= { –cos(πξ/ξ_T)  if ξ ≤ ξ_T 
        0     if ξ > ξ_T }
  
with ξ_T = –ln(100/1000) (so that 100 hPa is taken to be the tropopause).

An important point is that the surface pressure is prescribed to be “undisturbed” (p = p₀).

In what follows we answer two parts.

──────────────────────────────
Part (a).  Formulate an expression for the three‐dimensional distribution of geopotential height.

Because the hydrostatic “thickness” between two pressure levels (or, equivalently, between two values of ξ) is given by the hypsometric equation, one may write the (perturbation–inclusive) geopotential at any point as an integral over “ξ”. (We assume that the surface “geopotential” is a constant reference so that only the variation aloft matters.) In pressure coordinates one may show that

  dΦ = R_d T d(ln(p₀/p)).
     (remember that ln(p₀/p) = ξ)

Thus, if we choose the “ground” (ξ = 0) to have some constant geopotential (which we may set equal to zero for convenience), then at any (λ, φ, ξ) we have

  Φ(λ, φ, ξ) = R_d ∫₀^ξ T(λ, φ, ξ′) dξ′  (2)

Substitute (1) into (2):

  Φ(λ, φ, ξ) = R_d ∫₀^ξ [ T₀ + T₁(φ) + T′ e^(–[(λ²+(φ–φ₀)²)/L²]) f(ξ′) ] dξ′

Because T₀ and T₁ do not depend on ξ′ the integral immediately gives

  Φ(λ, φ, ξ) = R_d [ (T₀+T₁(φ)) ξ + T′ e^(–[(λ²+(φ–φ₀)²)/L²]) ∫₀^ξ f(ξ′) dξ′ ]  (3)

That is, the three‐dimensional distribution of geopotential is

  • at any point (λ, φ) and vertical coordinate ξ,
    Φ(λ, φ, ξ)=Φ(0)+R_d { [overline{T̄} + T̄ cos φ] ξ + T′ e^(–[(λ²+(φ–φ₀)²)/L²]) ∫₀^ξ f(ξ′) dξ′ }  .

Since only height differences matter we can choose the integration constant so that Φ(0)=0. Equation (3) is entirely acceptable as an answer. (Of course one may choose to write the corresponding geometric “height” z = Φ/g.)

Thus our answer for part (a) is

  (a)    
     Φ(λ, φ, ξ) = R_d { [overline{T̄} + T̄ cos φ] ξ + T′ e^(–[(λ²+(φ–φ₀)²)/L²]) ∫₀^ξ f(ξ′) dξ′ }.

In compact boxed form we write

  \boxed{ \Phi(\lambda,\phi,\xi)=R_d\left\{\left(\overline{T̄}+T̄\cos\phi\right)\xi+
T′e^{-\frac{\lambda^{2}+(\phi-\phi₀)^2}{L^2}}
\int_0^{\xi} f(\xi′)\,d\xi′ \right\} }  .

──────────────────────────────
Part (b).  Determine the magnitude of the anomalous temperature T′ required for the disturbance to create a cut‐off low at the mid–tropospheric level ξ = ξ_T/2.

Because the surface pressure is fixed the only way an upper–level anomaly can “show up” is by a vertical displacement of the isobaric surfaces. In our formulation the only term that “disturbs” those surfaces is the T′–term. Let us compute, at a fixed horizontal location (say, at the center of the disturbance, λ = 0 and φ = φ₀), the perturbation contribution to the geopotential at a level ξ. From (3) the perturbation geopotential is

  ΔΦ(ξ) = R_d T′ ∫₀^ξ f(ξ′) dξ′.

Since we are interested in the mid–troposphere, set ξ = ξ_T/2. In the troposphere f is given by

  f(ξ)= – cos(πξ/ξ_T).

Thus, at the center of the disturbance the integral becomes

  I = ∫₀^(ξ_T/2) [– cos (πξ′/ξ_T)] dξ′.

Let u = (πξ′)/ξ_T so that dξ′ = (ξ_T/π) du and when ξ′ = ξ_T/2, u = π/2. Then

  I = – (ξ_T/π) ∫₀^(π/2) cos u du = – (ξ_T/π) [sin u]₀^(π/2)
     = – (ξ_T/π) (1 – 0) = – ξ_T/π.

Thus, at (λ = 0, φ = φ₀, ξ = ξ_T/2) the perturbation geopotential is

  ΔΦ = – R_d T′ (ξ_T/π).

In words, the anomaly depresses the geopotential at mid–troposphere (by an amount |ΔΦ| = R_d T′ (ξ_T/π)). (Remember that in hydrostatic balance a lower geopotential means that the isobar “lies lower in the column”; that is, a cut–off low.)

Now, one must “define” what is meant by the formation of a cut–off low. A simple way is to require that the departure at mid–troposphere (say, a depression in the equivalent height, z′ = ΔΦ/g) must exceed some dynamically significant threshold Δz_cut. In other words, one may require

  |ΔΦ|/g = (R_d T′ (ξ_T/π))/g   ≥ Δz_cut   (4)

Solving for T′ gives

  T′ = (g Δz_cut π)/(R_d ξ_T).

Thus, for example if one thinks that a depression of Δz_cut = 300 m at mid–troposphere is enough for the “cut–off” to occur, then using typical values (g ≈ 9.81 m/s², R_d ≈ 287 J/(kg·K), and recalling that
  ξ_T = –ln(100/1000)= –ln(0.1) ≈ 2.3026),
we find

  T′ = (9.81·300·π)/(287·2.3026).

A quick calculation:
  numerator ≈ 9.81 × 300 × 3.1416 ≈ 9.81 × 942.48 ≈ 9250 (in SI units),
  denom ≈ 287 × 2.3026 ≈ 660.6,
so that
  T′ ≈ 9250/660.6 ≈ 14 K.

Of course, one could “choose” a different threshold Δz_cut. In our answer the message is: the necessary amplitude T′ is given by

  (b)  
  \boxed{ T′ = \frac{g\,\Delta z_{\rm cut}\,\pi}{R_d \,\xi_T} }  .

Thus, if one wishes a mid–tropospheric depression (geopotential height depression) of Δz_cut then a temperature anomaly of the magnitude given in the boxed expression is required.

──────────────────────────────
Summary of Answers

(a) The three–dimensional geopotential is given by

  \boxed{ \Phi(\lambda,\phi,\xi)=R_d\left\{\Bigl(\overline{T̄}+T̄\cos\phi\Bigr)\xi+
T′e^{-\frac{\lambda^{2}+(\phi-\phi₀)^2}{L^2}}
\int_0^{\xi} f(\xi′)\,d\xi′ \right\} }.

(b) Requiring that the mid–tropospheric depression (at ξ=ξ_T/2) have a “depth” Δz_cut (i.e. |ΔΦ|=gΔz_cut) leads to

  \boxed{ T′ = \frac{g\,\Delta z_{\rm cut}\,\pi}{R_d\,\xi_T} }.

For example, choosing Δz_cut ≃ 300 m, one obtains T′ ≃ 14 K.

Any answer equivalent to the answers given above is correct.

question:
In contrast to mid-latitude depressions, hurricanes are warm-core cyclones always linked to a surface pressure low. Examine a hurricane with the temperature distribution given by

$$
T(\lambda, \phi, \xi)=\bar{T}+T^{\prime}(\lambda, \phi) e^{-\alpha \xi},
$$

where $\bar{T}$ and $T^{\prime}$ represent the zonal-mean and perturbation contributions to temperature, $\xi=-\ln \left(\frac{p}{p_{0}}\right)$, with $p_{0}=1000 \mathrm{hPa}$, serves as a measure of height,

$$
T^{\prime}(\lambda, \phi)=\bar{T} \alpha \xi_{s}(\lambda, \phi) e^{\alpha \xi_{s}(\lambda, \phi)},
$$

where

$$
\xi_{s}(\lambda, \phi)=0.1 e^{-\frac{\lambda^{2}+\phi^{2}}{L^{2}}},
$$

and $\alpha^{-1}=\frac{\xi_{T}}{2}$, with $\xi_{T}=\ln \left(\frac{100}{1000}\right)$ indicating the surface and tropopause pressures, respectively, and $L=0.1$ rads. (a) Develop an expression for the 3-dimensional geopotential height distribution.
response:
We start with the given temperature field in “log‐pressure” (ξ) coordinates:
  
  T(λ, φ, ξ) = T̄ + T′(λ, φ)e^(–α ξ),  (1)
  
with

  T′(λ, φ) = T̄ α ξₛ(λ, φ)e^(α ξₛ(λ, φ)),  (2)
  
and

  ξₛ(λ, φ) = 0.1 e^[–(λ² + φ²)/L²],  (3)
  
where L = 0.1 radians. (Here T̄ is the zonal-mean temperature.)

Also, the vertical coordinate is defined by

  ξ = –ln(p/p₀), with p₀ = 1000 hPa.

Thus, ξ = 0 at the surface (p = p₀) and, for example, at the tropopause (p = 100 hPa) one obtains
  
  ξ_T = –ln(100/1000) = –ln(0.1) = ln(10) ≈ 2.302585.
  
Moreover, we are told that

  α^(–1) = ξ_T/2  →  α = 2/ξ_T.
  
In our case α > 0 (since ξ_T > 0).

Our goal is to find an expression for the three‐dimensional distribution of the geopotential height. To do this we will use the hydrostatic relation expressed in the ξ–coordinate.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Hydrostatic Balance in Log‐Pressure Coordinates

Recall that the usual hydrostatic equation is
  
  ∂Φ/∂p = –R_d T/p,
  
where Φ is the gravitational potential (geopotential), and R_d is the gas constant for dry air.

Since we have defined
  
  ξ = –ln(p/p₀)  ⇔  p = p₀ e^(–ξ),
  
the derivative dp/dξ is
  
  dp/dξ = –p₀ e^(–ξ) = –p.
  
Now, using the chain rule we write
  
  dΦ/dξ = (dΦ/dp)(dp/dξ) = (–R_d T/p)(–p) = R_d T.  (4)

Thus, in ξ–coordinates the hydrostatic relation becomes very simple:

  dΦ/dξ = R_d T(λ, φ, ξ).
  
We can integrate this with respect to ξ from the surface (ξ = 0) to an arbitrary level ξ:

  Φ(λ, φ, ξ) – Φ_s = R_d ∫₀^ξ T(λ, φ, ξ′) dξ′,  (5)
  
where we denote by Φ_s = Φ(λ, φ, 0) the geopotential at the surface.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Insert the Temperature Expression

Using expression (1):

  T(λ, φ, ξ′) = T̄ + T′(λ, φ)e^(–α ξ′).

Thus, the integral (5) becomes

  ∫₀^ξ T(λ, φ, ξ′) dξ′ = ∫₀^ξ [T̄ + T′(λ, φ)e^(–α ξ′)] dξ′.

This integral splits into:

  I = T̄ ∫₀^ξ dξ′ + T′(λ, φ) ∫₀^ξ e^(–α ξ′) dξ′ .
  
The first term is simply

  T̄ ξ.
  
The second term integrates to

  ∫₀^ξ e^(–α ξ′) dξ′ = [ –(1/α)e^(–α ξ′)]₀^ξ = \(\frac{1 - e^{-α ξ}}{α}\).

Thus, the integral is

  I = T̄ ξ + T′(λ, φ) (1 – e^(–α ξ))/α.
  
Substituting back into (5) we have

  Φ(λ, φ, ξ) = Φ_s + R_d [ T̄ ξ + (T′(λ, φ)/α)(1 – e^(–α ξ)) ].  (6)

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Express T′(λ, φ) in the Answer

Recall that

  T′(λ, φ) = T̄ α ξₛ(λ, φ)e^(α ξₛ(λ, φ)).  (2)

Thus, (T′(λ, φ)/α) becomes

  T̄ ξₛ(λ, φ)e^(α ξₛ(λ, φ)).

Substitute this into (6):

  Φ(λ, φ, ξ) = Φ_s + R_d [ T̄ ξ + T̄ ξₛ(λ, φ)e^(α ξₛ(λ, φ)) (1 – e^(–α ξ)) ].  (7)

It is common when discussing atmospheric structure to talk in terms of geopotential height (z), which is defined by

  z(λ, φ, ξ) = Φ(λ, φ, ξ)/g,
  
with g being the acceleration due to gravity. Thus, the three-dimensional geopotential height field is

  z(λ, φ, ξ) = z_s + (R_d/g) [ T̄ ξ + T̄ ξₛ(λ, φ)e^(α ξₛ(λ, φ))(1 – e^(–α ξ)) ],  (8)
  
where z_s = Φ_s/g is the surface geopotential height.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus, one acceptable answer for the three-dimensional geopotential height distribution is

a)  \boxed{ \Phi(\lambda,\phi,\xi)=\Phi_{s}+R_{d}\Bigl[\bar{T}\,\xi+\bar{T}\,\xi_{s}(\lambda,\phi)e^{\alpha\,\xi_{s}(\lambda,\phi)}\left(1-e^{-\alpha\,\xi}\right)\Bigr] }  
  
or, equivalently, writing the geopotential height z = Φ/g,

b)  \boxed{ z(\lambda,\phi,\xi)=z_{s}+\frac{R_{d}\,\bar{T}}{g}\Bigl[\xi+\xi_{s}(\lambda,\phi)e^{\alpha\,\xi_{s}(\lambda,\phi)}\Bigl(1-e^{-\alpha\,\xi}\Bigr)\Bigr] }.

Either form is acceptable as the answer.

question: Within a tropical area, deep convection results in latent heat release, leading to a column heating rate of $250 \mathrm{~W} \mathrm{~m}^{-2}$. (a) If this heating is not offset, and it creates a temperature disturbance uniform with height up to the tropopause, determine the resulting change in thickness of the $1000 \mathrm{hPa}-100 \mathrm{hPa}$ layer after a duration of 1 day.
response:
We are told that deep convection releases latent heat at a rate of 250 W/m². If this heating is not offset and is deposited uniformly in the layer from 1000 hPa to 100 hPa, then over 1 day (86,400 s) the column gains an amount of energy per unit area

  Energy/area = 250 W/m² × 86,400 s = 21.6 × 10^6 J/m².

This added energy will warm the entire mass of the atmospheric column between 1000 hPa and 100 hPa. To find the average temperature increase in the column, we use the fact that the energy needed to raise the temperature of a mass m by ΔT is

  m cₚ ΔT,

where cₚ ≈ 1004 J/(kg·K) is the specific heat at constant pressure. The mass per unit area in a layer between pressures p₁ and p₂ is given by (p₁ – p₂)/g (since pressure is the weight of the column per unit area). Here, p₁ = 1000 hPa and p₂ = 100 hPa. Note that 1 hPa = 100 Pa so

  p₁ – p₂ = (1000 – 100) hPa = 900 hPa = 90000 Pa.

Thus the mass per unit area is

  m = 90000 Pa / g,
  with g ≈ 9.8 m/s²  ⇒  m ≈ 90000/9.8 ≈ 9184 kg/m².

Now, the total heat added is used to increase the temperature of the air in the layer,
so we set

  m cₚ ΔT = 21.6 × 10^6 J/m².

Solving for ΔT,

  ΔT = (21.6 × 10^6 J/m²) / (9184 kg/m² × 1004 J/(kg·K)).

Calculating the denominator:

  9184 kg/m² × 1004 J/(kg·K) ≈ 9.22 × 10^6 J/(m²·K).

Therefore,

  ΔT ≈ (21.6 × 10^6) / (9.22 × 10^6) ≈ 2.34 K.

Next, we want to know how this uniform warming changes the vertical thickness of the layer from 1000 hPa to 100 hPa. Under hydrostatic balance and using the ideal gas law, the thickness z (in a simplified formulation) of a pressure layer is given by

  z = (R_d / g) T ln(p₁ / p₂),

where R_d ≈ 287 J/(kg·K) is the gas constant for dry air and T is the temperature.

An increase ΔT in the temperature will increase the thickness by an amount approximately given by

  Δz = (R_d / g) ln(p₁ / p₂) ΔT.

We have
  ln(p₁ / p₂) = ln(1000/100) = ln(10) ≈ 2.3026,
  (R_d / g) = 287/9.8 ≈ 29.3 m/K.

Thus,

  Δz = 29.3 m/K × 2.3026 × 2.34 K.

First, compute the factor: 29.3 m/K × 2.3026 ≈ 67.4 m/K.
Then multiplying by ΔT,
  Δz ≈ 67.4 m/K × 2.34 K ≈ 157.7 m.

So to a good approximation, the thickness of the 1000–100 hPa layer would increase by about 158 m after 1 day.

a) Final result:
  \boxed{\Delta z \approx 1.6 \times 10^2~\mathrm{m}}.

question:
During the early morning, the potential temperature profile within a layer near the surface is given by

$$
\frac{\theta}{\theta_{0}}=e^{\frac{z}{h_{1}}}-\frac{Z}{h_{2}},
$$

where $h_{1}>h_{2}$. Assuming condensation is negligible, (a) describe the static stability of this layer, and (b) find the buoyancy frequency profile.
response:
We are given the profile

  θ/θ₀ = e^(z/h₁) – z/h₂         (1)

with the condition h₁ > h₂. Recall that the static stability is determined by the sign of dθ/dz. In a stably stratified atmosphere (non‐convective), θ increases with height, i.e. dθ/dz > 0. If dθ/dz < 0 then the layer is convectively unstable.

Before proceeding we note that condensation is negligible so that we do not have to worry about latent heat release altering the stability.

Let us now go step by step.

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Compute the vertical derivative of the potential temperature.

Since θ/θ₀ = f(z) = e^(z/h₁) – z/h₂, differentiate with respect to z:
  d/dz(θ/θ₀) = (1/h₁)e^(z/h₁) – 1/h₂.

Thus, the vertical derivative of θ is

  dθ/dz = θ₀[(1/h₁)e^(z/h₁) – 1/h₂].     (2)

────────────────────────────
Step 2. (a) Describe the static stability.

Recall:
  - If dθ/dz > 0, the layer is statically (convectively) stable.
  - If dθ/dz < 0, the layer is unstable.

From (2) we see that the sign of dθ/dz is determined by the expression,
  (1/h₁)e^(z/h₁) – 1/h₂.

Notice that at z = 0:
  (1/h₁)e^(0) – 1/h₂ = 1/h₁ – 1/h₂.
Because h₁ > h₂, we have 1/h₁ < 1/h₂, implying that
  1/h₁ – 1/h₂ < 0.
Thus, near z = 0 the derivative dθ/dz is negative and the layer is statically unstable.

To find the transition height (z = z_c) where the derivative changes sign we set
  (1/h₁)e^(z_c/h₁) – 1/h₂ = 0.
That gives
  (1/h₁)e^(z_c/h₁) = 1/h₂  ⟹  e^(z_c/h₁) = h₁/h₂.
Taking logarithms:
  z_c/h₁ = ln(h₁/h₂)  ⟹  z_c = h₁ ln(h₁/h₂).

Thus, for heights below z_c, we have dθ/dz < 0 (unstable) and for heights above this level, dθ/dz > 0 (stable).

Final answer for part (a):

a) Static stability:
 – The potential temperature decreases with height for z < h₁ ln(h₁/h₂) making the layer unstable.
 – For z > h₁ ln(h₁/h₂) the potential temperature increases with height implying a stable layer.

  \boxed{\text{Unstable for } z < h_1\ln\frac{h_1}{h_2} \text{ (since } d\theta/dz < 0\text{), stable for } z > h_1\ln\frac{h_1}{h_2} \text{ (since } d\theta/dz > 0\text{).}}

────────────────────────────
Step 3. (b) Compute the buoyancy frequency profile.

The squared buoyancy frequency (also called Brunt–Väisälä frequency) is defined by
  N² = (g/θ) (dθ/dz),
where g is the acceleration due to gravity.

We have from equation (1):
  θ = θ₀ (e^(z/h₁) – z/h₂)
and from equation (2):
  dθ/dz = θ₀[(1/h₁)e^(z/h₁) – 1/h₂].

Thus, substituting into the definition for N² we get
  N² = (g/ [θ₀ (e^(z/h₁) – z/h₂)]) • {θ₀[(1/h₁)e^(z/h₁) – 1/h₂]}.

Notice that θ₀ cancels out. Therefore, the profile for N² is

  N² = g [ (1/h₁)e^(z/h₁) – 1/h₂ ] / [e^(z/h₁) – z/h₂].

This is the buoyancy frequency profile as a function of height z.

Final answer for part (b):

b) Buoyancy frequency:
  \boxed{N^2 = \frac{g}{e^{z/h_1}-z/h_2}\left[\frac{1}{h_1}e^{z/h_1}-\frac{1}{h_2}\right].}

────────────────────────────
Conclusion

Thus, we have shown that:
(a) The static stability of the layer is such that there is an unstable region for z < h₁ ln(h₁/h₂) and a stable region for z > h₁ ln(h₁/h₂).
(b) The buoyancy frequency profile is given by

  N² = g[(1/h₁)e^(z/h₁) – 1/h₂] / [e^(z/h₁) – z/h₂].

These are the final answers.

question: Consider a simple harmonic oscillator consisting of a 1-kg mass and an elastic spring with a constant $k$, which serves as a model for buoyancy oscillations. Determine the effective spring constant for unsaturated conditions typical of (a) the troposphere, where $\Gamma=6.5{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{K} \mathrm{km}^{-1}$ and $T=260{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{K}$, (b) the stratosphere, where $\Gamma=-4{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{K} \mathrm{km}^{-1}$ and $T=250^{\circ} \mathrm{K}$.
response:
We can think of buoyancy oscillations as a “spring‐motion” where a displaced air parcel experiences a restoring force proportional to its displacement. For small displacements in a stably stratified atmosphere the buoyancy acceleration is described by the square of the Brunt–Väisälä frequency, N². An analogy with a mass m attached to a spring of constant k gives

  (1)  d²z/dt² = −(k/m) z         (simple harmonic motion)

Thus, by comparing with the buoyancy equation

  (2)  d²z/dt² = −N² z,

we identify

  (3)  k_eff = m N².

For unsaturated air (i.e. dry air), the Brunt–Väisälä frequency is given approximately by

  (4)  N² = (g/T) (Γ_d − Γ)

where

• g is the gravitational acceleration (≈ 9.8 m/s²),
• T is the absolute temperature (in K),
• Γ = − dT/dz is the environmental lapse rate (given in K/km and converted to K/m by dividing by 1000),
• Γ_d is the dry adiabatic lapse rate which, for c_p ≃ 1000 J/(kg·K), is about 9.8 K/km.

Thus, we now calculate k_eff for each case:

───────────────────────────── 
Step 1. Convert lapse rates:
 • For the troposphere: 
  Γ = 6.5 K/km = 6.5 × 10⁻³ K/m.
  Γ_d = 9.8 K/km = 9.8 × 10⁻³ K/m.
 • For the stratosphere:
  Γ = –4 K/km = –4 × 10⁻³ K/m (a negative lapse rate means temperature increases with height).
  Γ_d remains 9.8 × 10⁻³ K/m.
───────────────────────────── 
Step 2. 
(a) Troposphere (T = 260 K):

Using (4):
  N² = (g/T) (Γ_d – Γ)
     = (9.8/260) × [(9.8 × 10⁻³) – (6.5 × 10⁻³)]
     = (9.8/260) × (3.3 × 10⁻³).

First, compute 9.8/260:
  9.8/260 ≈ 0.0377 s⁻²/K.

Then multiply:
  N² ≈ 0.0377 × 3.3×10⁻³ ≈ 1.245 × 10⁻⁴ s⁻².

Since the mass is 1 kg:
  k_eff = m N² ≈ 1 kg × 1.245×10⁻⁴ s⁻² = 1.245×10⁻⁴ N/m.

We can round this to:
  k_eff ≈ 1.2×10⁻⁴ N/m.

Thus, we have

  (a)  \boxed{k_{eff} \approx 1.2 \times 10^{-4}\;{\rm N/m}}

───────────────────────────── 
Step 3. 
(b) Stratosphere (T = 250 K):

Here, the difference is:
  Γ_d – Γ = (9.8×10⁻³) – (–4×10⁻³) = (9.8 + 4.0)×10⁻³ = 13.8×10⁻³ K/m.

Then using (4):
  N² = (9.8/250) × (13.8×10⁻³)
     = (0.0392) × (0.0138)     (since 9.8/250 = 0.0392 s⁻²/K)
     ≈ 0.000541 s⁻² (5.41×10⁻⁴ s⁻²).

Then, with m = 1 kg,
  k_eff = 1 kg × 5.41×10⁻⁴ s⁻² = 5.41×10⁻⁴ N/m.

We round this to:
  k_eff ≈ 5.4×10⁻⁴ N/m.

Thus, we have

  (b)  \boxed{k_{eff} \approx 5.4 \times 10^{-4}\;{\rm N/m}}

───────────────────────────── 
Summary of Answers:

(a) In the troposphere, for T = 260 K and Γ = 6.5 K/km,
  \boxed{k_{eff} \approx 1.2 \times 10^{-4}\,{\rm N/m}}

(b) In the stratosphere, for T = 250 K and Γ = –4 K/km,
  \boxed{k_{eff} \approx 5.4 \times 10^{-4}\,{\rm N/m}}

question: A sudden disturbance gives a vertical velocity $w_{0}$ to a single air parcel. Provided the layer with this parcel has nonnegative stability $N$, (a) find the maximum vertical displacement of the parcel, expressed as a function of $N$, assuming linear conditions.
response:
We start with the linearized equation of motion for vertical oscillations in a stably stratified atmosphere, which takes the form of a simple harmonic oscillator:

  d²z/dt² = –N² z

Here, N (the Brunt–Väisälä frequency) represents the stability of the layer, and z is the vertical displacement.

Step 1. Write down the general solution of the oscillator:
  z(t) = A cos(Nt) + B sin(Nt)

Step 2. Apply the initial conditions. The parcel is initially at z = 0 and is given an initial upward velocity w₀:
  At t = 0, z(0) = 0 ⇒ A = 0

Next, differentiate z(t) with respect to time to find the velocity:
  dz/dt = –A N sin(Nt) + B N cos(Nt)
  At t = 0, dz/dt = B N = w₀, hence:
  B = w₀/N

Thus, the solution for the displacement becomes:
  z(t) = (w₀/N) sin(Nt)

Step 3. Determine the maximum displacement. The sine function attains its maximum magnitude (which is 1) when its argument is π/2. Thus, the maximum vertical displacement is:
  z_max = (w₀/N)

Therefore, the maximum vertical displacement of the parcel is:

\boxed{\frac{w_0}{N}}

question:
Prior to encountering isolated rugged terrain, the thermal structure of the surface layer is given by

$$
T(z)=T_{0} \frac{a}{a+z},
$$

where $a>0$ and $T_{0}>a \Gamma_{d}$. (a) Find the potential temperature profile upstream. (b) Describe the vertical stability upstream.
response:
We are told that upstream (i.e. before any flow is affected by the terrain) the temperature (in the surface‐layer) is given by

  T(z) = T₀ ⋅ (a/(a + z))      (1)

with a positive constant a and with T₀ > a Γ_d, where Γ_d = g/c_p is the dry‐adiabatic lapse rate. (Here g is the gravitational acceleration and cₚ is the specific heat at constant pressure.) Our two tasks are to:

 (a) Compute the potential temperature profile θ(z) upstream.
 (b) Describe the vertical stability upstream.

Recall that the potential temperature is defined by

  θ(z) = T(z) (p₀/p(z))^(R/c_p),      (2)

with p₀ a reference pressure (say at z = 0). To obtain a closed‐form expression for θ(z) we must know how the pressure decreases with z. In the hydrostatic approximation (and using the ideal gas law) we have

  dp/dz = –ρ g = –(p/(R T)) g      (3)

which can be rearranged as

  d ln p/dz = –g/(R T(z)).

Since we know T(z) from (1), we can integrate from z = 0 (where p = p₀) to an arbitrary height z. That is,

  ∫₀^z d ln p = –(g/R) ∫₀^z (1/T(z′)) dz′.

With T(z′) = T₀⋅(a/(a+z′)), we have

  1/T(z′) = (a+z′)/(T₀ a).

Thus, the z‐integral is

  ∫₀^z (a+z′)dz′ = a z + ½z².

Then, we obtain

  ln[p(z)/p₀] = –(g/(R T₀ a)) (a z + ½z²).

Exponentiating gives

  p(z) = p₀ exp[–(g/(R T₀ a)) (a z + ½z²)].      (4)

Now, substitute (4) into (2). Define κ = R/c_p so that (R/c_p) = κ. Then, one has

  θ(z) = T(z) ⋅ exp{ κ ln(p₀/p(z)) } = T(z)⋅exp{ κ (g/(R T₀ a))(a z + ½z²) }.

But note that

  κ (g/R) = (R/c_p)(g/R) = g/c_p = Γ_d.

Also, T(z) = T₀⋅(a/(a+z)). Therefore, the potential temperature profile becomes

  θ(z) = [T₀ a/(a+z)] ⋅ exp{ [Γ_d/(T₀ a)] (a z + ½z²) }.

It is sometimes preferable to rewrite the exponent in a slightly “cleaner” form:

  θ(z) = [T₀ a/(a+z)] ⋅ exp{ (Γ_d/T₀) [z + (z²/(2a))] }.

Thus, our answer for part (a) is

  (a)  θ(z) = (T₀ a/(a+z)) exp{ (Γ_d/T₀)[z + z²/(2a)] }.

We write this as

  \boxed{\theta(z)=\frac{T_0\,a}{a+z}\exp\Biggl\{\frac{\Gamma_d}{T_0}\Bigl[z+\frac{z^2}{2a}\Bigr]\Biggr\}}.

────────────────────────────

Now let us turn to part (b): the question of vertical stability upstream.

A necessary (and in fact sufficient) condition for static stability in a dry atmosphere is that the potential temperature increases with height, i.e. dθ/dz > 0. (If dθ/dz < 0 then the layer is statically unstable and convection may ensue.) Thus, we need to study the sign of dθ/dz.

Differentiate the expression for θ(z). Write

  θ(z) = f(z) ⋅ exp{g(z)},
where
  f(z) = T₀ a/(a+z) and g(z) = (Γ_d/T₀)[z + z²/(2a)].

Then,
  f ′(z) = –T₀ a/(a+z)²,
and
  g ′(z) = d/dz [(Γ_d/T₀)(z + z²/(2a))] = (Γ_d/T₀)[1 + (z/a)] = (Γ_d (a+z))/(T₀ a).

Using the product rule,

  dθ/dz = exp{g(z)} [f ′(z) + f(z)g ′(z)].
Substitute f(z) and its derivative:

  dθ/dz = exp{g(z)} [ –T₀ a/(a+z)² + (T₀ a/(a+z)) ⋅ (Γ_d (a+z)/(T₀ a) ) ]
      = exp{g(z)} [ –T₀ a/(a+z)² + Γ_d ].

Thus,
  dθ/dz = exp{g(z)} [ Γ_d – T₀ a/(a+z)² ].

Because the exponential factor is always positive, the sign of dθ/dz is determined by the difference

  Γ_d – T₀ a/(a+z)².

Now, at the surface (z = 0) we have

  dθ/dz (0) ∝ Γ_d – T₀ a/(a)² = Γ_d – T₀/a.
Recall that the problem statement gives T₀ > a Γ_d, or equivalently T₀/a > Γ_d. Hence, at z = 0 the term in brackets is negative and so

  dθ/dz (0) < 0.

That is, right at the surface the potential temperature decreases with height and the atmosphere is locally statically unstable.

As z increases the term T₀ a/(a+z)² decreases (because (a+z)² increases) and eventually for a sufficiently large z one will have

  Γ_d – T₀ a/(a+z)² > 0.
Solving for the level z = z* at which the transition occurs,
  T₀ a/(a+z*)² = Γ_d  ⟹  (a+z*)² = (T₀ a)/Γ_d.
Thus, the critical height is

  z* = √(T₀ a/Γ_d) – a.

Since T₀ > aΓ_d implies that √(T₀ a/Γ_d) > a it follows that z* > 0. Therefore, for 0 ≤ z < z* the potential temperature decreases with height (unstable stratification), and for z > z* the potential temperature increases with height (stable stratification).

Thus, our answer for part (b) is as follows:
  the atmosphere upstream has a very shallow layer near the surface that is statically (convectively) unstable, while above the level z* = √(T₀a/Γ_d) – a the stratification is statically stable.

We write this result as

  (b) Upstream the potential temperature profile has a minimum at the surface (with
     dθ/dz < 0 for z < √(T₀a/Γ_d) – a)
and then increases with height for z > √(T₀a/Γ_d) – a (i.e. dθ/dz > 0), indicating that the lowest part of the flow is convectively unstable, while the layer above is stable.

We now box our final answers:

(a) \boxed{\theta(z)=\frac{T_0\,a}{a+z}\exp\Biggl\{\frac{\Gamma_d}{T_0}\Bigl[z+\frac{z^2}{2a}\Bigr]\Biggr\}}

(b) \boxed{\text{The upstream flow is unstable near the surface (for }z<\sqrt{\frac{T_0\,a}{\Gamma_d}}-a\text{, with }d\theta/dz<0\text{) and stable aloft (}\,z>\sqrt{\frac{T_0\,a}{\Gamma_d}}-a\text{, with }d\theta/dz>0\text{).}}

Any answer equivalent to the ones above is correct.

question:
An early morning sounding provides the temperature profile as follows:

$$
T(Z)= \begin{cases}T_{0}+\left(\frac{\Gamma_{d}}{2}\right) Z & Z<1 \mathrm{~km} \\ T_{0}+\left(\frac{\Gamma_{d}}{2}\right)-\left(\frac{\Gamma_{d}}{4}\right)(Z-1) & Z \geq 1 \mathrm{~km} .\end{cases}
$$
